articles.title: Why Russia’s economy is unlikely to collapse even if oil prices fall | Phillip Inman
articles.trailText: Hopes that tougher sanctions and lower oil prices could derail Putin’s war effort underestimate how far the Kremlin has rewired its economy
articles.summary: Despite US sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil, rising rouble and potential Venezuelan output, Russia’s oil revenues have fallen from 50% to 25% of state income without triggering collapse. Putin has rewired the economy through a ‘medically induced coma’ of low growth (IMF forecasts ~0.6–1%), high interest rates (~20%), modest deficits (~3.5% of GDP) and low debt (~20%), funded by higher household and business taxes. Alternative buyers (China, India) and domestic reserves bolster war spending. Tougher EU insurance restrictions could bite, but no imminent economic breakdown—Europe must tighten sanctions and bolster Ukraine militarily.

articles.title: Wessex Water bosses handed £50,000 in extra pay despite Labour government’s bonus ban
articles.trailText: Utility admits parent company paid CEO Ruth Jefferson and CFO Andy Pymer but denies bonus payments
articles.summary: Despite a government ban on bonuses for water firms with pollution convictions, Wessex Water CEO Ruth Jefferson and CFO Andy Pymer each received undisclosed extra pay totalling £50,000 from parent company YTL’s UK arm in 2024–25. Jefferson was paid £24,000 and Pymer £27,000 via Wessex Water Ltd—omitted from the regulated unit’s accounts and initially misattributed by YTL. Critics, including MPs and Lib Dem rural affairs spokesperson Sarah Dyke, decry the opaque executive pay amid renewed scrutiny of water company bonuses after criminal pollution fines.

articles.title: US hiring held firm in December capping weakest year of growth since pandemic
articles.trailText: White House is meanwhile facing questions about an apparent embargo breach over Trump’s social media post
articles.summary: US employers added 50K jobs in December, marking 2025’s weakest annual payroll gain since the pandemic. October and November figures were revised down by 76K. The unemployment rate fell to 4.4% from 4.6%, while private payrolls rose just 37K. Total hires totaled 584K in Trump’s first year versus 2M under Biden in 2024. Trump’s pre-embargo Truth Social post prompted a White House review. Senator Warren decried sluggish growth and rising costs. Economists describe a “no hire, no fire” labor market. Fed officials, weighing a possible pause or cut at end-January meeting, remain cautious amid 2.7% inflation.

articles.title: Glencore and Rio Tinto are at it again – and it seems the markets smell action
articles.trailText: Many of the old challenges remain but there are a number of reasons why this time a deal of some kind could be possible
articles.summary: Rio Tinto and Glencore have entered preliminary talks on a possible $260bn combination after aborted 2024 negotiations. Cultural mismatches—Rio’s 2018 coal exit versus Glencore’s trading roots—and how to treat coal and trading assets remain hurdles. Glencore shares rose 9% and Rio fell 2%, signaling market anticipation. New Rio CEO Simon Trott’s appetite for megadeals, a mining M&A wave driven by copper demand (Anglo-Teck $50bn tie-up) and BHP’s potential interest underpin momentum. Jefferies forecasts one-third of earnings from copper if coal is carved out. Rio has four weeks to decide on premium levels amidst investor caution over overpaying.

articles.title: High costs, falling returns: what could go wrong for Trump’s Venezuela oil gamble?
articles.trailText: US faces big challenges in trying to unlock ‘tremendous wealth’ from Venezuela’s long-neglected oil industry
articles.summary: After claiming $3bn of stranded crude and planning indefinite control of Venezuela’s 20% of proven reserves to curb prices to $50/bbl, the Trump administration confronts daunting barriers: decades of infrastructure decay, $183bn estimated cost to lift output from under 1mbd to 2mbd by 2040, and the need for $30bn–35bn in early international investment. Falling oil prices, looming demand peak, and risk-averse majors suggest initial gains will go to service providers and smaller US independents.

articles.title: Charity watchdog opens inquiry into City & Guilds’ sale of business arm
articles.trailText: Bosses at body that trained chef Jamie Oliver were awarded million-pound bonuses after sale to private firm
articles.summary: The Charity Commission has opened a statutory inquiry into City & Guilds’ sale of its awarding arm to PeopleCert after the Guardian revealed £1.7m and £1.2m bonuses and salary hikes for the CEO and finance director. It will examine trustees’ decision-making, information provided, and a £22m cost-cutting plan that has reduced UK headcount. The sale raised £180m–£200m to fund the charity’s vocational grants. Trustees say they acted properly but the Commission may widen the probe.

articles.title: Starmer rules out EU financial services alignment talks
articles.trailText: City firms welcome clarity as government signals it will not reopen Brussels-era rules, despite closer cooperation elsewhere
articles.summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer ruled out re-aligning UK financial services with EU rules, a move welcomed by City lobbyists fearful of upheaval from reversing post-Brexit deregulation. The government says Brussels-era rulebook won’t return, though it will seek targeted cooperation where beneficial. Peel Hunt CEO Steve Fine warns scrapping reforms—bigger bonuses, lower capital buffers, looser listing rules—could derail London’s IPO rebound. TheCityUK chief Miles Celic adds that single-market access would cost regulatory flexibility. A spring 2025 summit with Brussels identified cooperation areas but excluded financial services, despite the EU being the UK’s second-largest market for the sector.

articles.title: Sainsbury’s blames ‘significant headwinds’ for drop in Argos sales at Christmas
articles.trailText: Online competition and weak consumer confidence behind fall, although sales at group’s supermarkets rose
articles.summary: Sainsbury’s reported a 1% drop in Argos sales over the Christmas quarter, blaming ‘significant headwinds’ from weak consumer confidence, heavy online competition (Temu, Shein) and discounting, especially on big-ticket items like furniture and gaming. Meanwhile, supermarket like-for-like sales rose 3.4% (fresh food +8%, Taste the Difference +15%, online grocery +14%). CEO Simon Roberts urged faster government action on import tax breaks for cut-price goods, said food inflation has peaked but shopper value focus persists. Profit guidance remains >£1 bn underlying and over £800 m cash returns (including £250 m special dividend). Argos divestment speculation resurfaces amid JD.com interest.

articles.title: Mining firms Rio Tinto and Glencore restart $260bn merger talks
articles.trailText: Deal would create world’s largest mining company and come almost a year after previous discussions failed
articles.summary: Rio Tinto and Glencore have resumed preliminary talks on a possible all-share merger that would create a global mining group with an enterprise value exceeding $260bn, after 2024 discussions collapsed over valuation, management and coal assets. The proposed court-sanctioned scheme would see Rio (EV $162bn) acquire Glencore, combining iron ore, copper, cobalt and lithium portfolios. The move follows sector consolidation including Anglo-Teck’s $53bn deal, amid record copper prices. Key uncertainties include Glencore’s coal business, governance, sustainability credentials and the Feb 5 UK offer deadline. Rio’s new CEO Simon Trott and Glencore’s Gary Nagle lead talks; Rio shares fell while Glencore rallied.

articles.title: What is Modella Capital? Firm in spotlight as Claire’s and The Original Factory Shop face collapse
articles.trailText: Investment firm that also bought WH Smith’s high street business has reputation for rapid and hard-nosed restructuring
articles.summary: Modella Capital, a UK restructuring investor founded in 2022, is under scrutiny as Claire’s Accessories UK (154 stores) and The Original Factory Shop (140 stores) face imminent collapse, putting 2,550 jobs at risk. The firm’s rapid CVA-led turnarounds—seen in Hobbycraft (18 closures) and TG Jones (WH Smith’s high-street arm)—have earned a hard-nosed reputation. Modella holds secured charges on Claire’s UK assets from a £7.5m loan and expects limited debt recovery. Despite weak returns, it continues targeting distressed mid-market retailers amid fierce competition from Temu, Shein and fast-fashion rivals.

articles.title: Treasury has ‘limited grasp’ of concerns over booming shadow banking sector, peers say
articles.trailText: Report says officials seem unprepared for potential risks that unregulated industry poses to UK financial stability
articles.summary: A Lords financial services committee warns the UK Treasury has a “limited grasp” of risks from the $16 trn shadow banking sector—private equity and credit firms outside bank regulation. The report highlights scarce data, potential contagion as US-dominated private markets grow fourfold since 2008, and entanglement with insurers and high-street banks. It cites Andrew Bailey’s worries over weak lending in private credit after two US auto borrowers collapsed, and signals the Bank of England’s planned stress test. Regulators urge vigilant monitoring while Treasury says it’s bolstered non-bank oversight.

articles.title: Reeves’s promise of pub business rates U-turn averts Labour rebellion
articles.trailText: Change in England largely welcomed by industry and Labour MPs but represents another climbdown
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves dodged a Labour revolt after months of complaints by promising to reverse planned 76% average business-rates hikes for English pubs, unveiling a support package under development that will cut pub rates and tackle licensing, opening hours and red tape. Industry groups led by the BBPA and UKHospitality applauded, while Tonia Antoniazzi MP—who had drafted an amendment to the finance bill—said she’d reserve rebellion if reliefs prove inadequate. Details are due once Treasury minister Dan Tomlinson finalises the scheme.

articles.title: The Primark machine suffers a continental splutter at a bad moment | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Big fall in sales in rest of Europe means split from owner’s food businesses would be distraction best avoided for year or two
articles.summary: ABF’s Primark saw its share price fall 14% after warning that like-for-like sales in continental Europe plunged 5.7% over a 16-week peak period, while UK sales rose 1.7% thanks to sharper marketing and click-and-collect. Analysts doubt whether those remedies can reverse weakness in France, Germany and Italy amid soft consumer demand and fierce online competition. AB Foods now expects group profits to decline vs earlier guidance, with mixed food trading and Hovis deal scrutiny prompting any demerger to be delayed.

articles.title: ‘Shadow fleet’ ships moving sanctioned oil reflagged to Russia at rising rate
articles.trailText: Lloyd’s List analysis suggests 40 suspicious vessels joined Russian registry last year, with 17 reflagged last month
articles.summary: Lloyd’s List analysis identifies 40 vessels linked to a ‘shadow fleet’ of sanction-busting tankers reflagging to Russia in 2025, including 17 in December alone, up from 15 in the prior five months. The surge follows Donald Trump’s blockade declaration on Venezuelan oil exports. These ships use deceptive practices—false registries, name changes—to evade US and EU sanctions. US special forces recently seized the Marinera (formerly Bella 1), M/T Sophia and the Skipper. Russia’s shadow fleet moves 3.7m barrels daily—65% of its seaborne exports—generating up to $100bn annually.

articles.title: Software firm belonging to Tory donor Frank Hester pays out £50m dividend
articles.trailText: Sales and profits surge at TPP Group, whose software is said to be used by 7,800 NHS organisations
articles.summary: TPP Group, founded by Tory donor Frank Hester, paid a record £50m dividend after a 13% rise in turnover to £97.1m and pre-tax profits jumping to £47.4m in the year to March 2025. Its SystmOne software serves 7,800 NHS organisations, holding 61m patient records, and has expanded internationally. Hester, still majority owner and paid £520k salary, donated £10.2m to the Conservative party in 2024, part of over £20m since 2023. The firm has secured £591m in NHS contracts since 2016. The payout comes amid scrutiny of Hester’s past racist remarks published in 2024.

articles.title: Tesco aiming for bumper 2026 after best Christmas market share in decade
articles.trailText: Chain reports strong sales but shares drop 5% after analysts say third quarter performance was behind expectations
articles.summary: Tesco seized a 29% UK grocery share over Christmas—the highest in a decade—by boosting fresh food and its Finest range, outpacing struggling Asda. Yet shares slid 6% after Q3 sales underperformed: UK +3.2% vs 3.9% expected, central Europe +0.8% vs 1.6%, and Booker wholesale fell 2.1% vs +0.8%. CEO Ken Murphy stressed a low-price strategy on 3,000 everyday items, keeping inflation below the sector’s 4.3%. Tesco reaffirmed full-year profit guidance of £3.1bn and, with resilient consumer spending and calls for business rates reform, targets further share growth in 2026.

articles.title: CMA begins full review of Kingsmill owner’s planned takeover of bread rival Hovis
articles.trailText: Move by UK competition regulator comes as Associated British Foods, which owns Primark, issues profit warning
articles.summary: UK competition regulator has launched an in-depth Phase 2 review of Associated British Foods’ planned £75m acquisition of Hovis, raising concerns that combining the UK’s second and third largest bread brands could reduce choice and drive up prices. ABF, owner of Primark, has fast-tracked the merger while issuing a profit warning that sent shares down 11%. The CMA will assess competitive pressure from supermarket labels and Warburtons in its review running to at least June 2026, with deal closure unlikely before September 2026.

articles.title: Greggs puts up price of sausage roll by 5p to £1.35 amid rising costs
articles.trailText: Bakery chain also adds 10p to a latte, bringing it to £2.25, as CEO warns of ‘a tough, challenging market’
articles.summary: Greggs has raised its sausage roll price by 5p to £1.35 and lattes by 10p to £2.25 to offset higher wages, energy and packaging costs, and expects no further hikes in the near term. CEO Roisin Currie warns of a tough market, citing weaker Christmas sales, subdued consumer confidence and weather extremes. Q4 same-store sales rose just 2.9%, driving shares down 8%. Annual sales grew 6.8% to £2.15bn with 207 openings but profits are set to fall by ~£17m to £173m. The chain plans 120 new outlets this year amid a cautious outlook as inflation eases.

articles.title: Trump plans to use Venezuela’s huge crude reserves ‘to cut US oil price to $50 a barrel’
articles.trailText: President reportedly hopes falling price will cut domestic consumer energy bills
articles.summary: Donald Trump aims to harness Venezuela’s vast 300bn-barrel reserves to flood markets and push US oil prices to $50 a barrel, easing consumer energy bills while cutting Russia and China out of South American crude. The administration has claimed 50m under-sanctioned barrels—potentially worth $3bn—for sale proceeds to “benefit the Venezuelan people” and mandate profits buy only US goods. Boosting Venezuela’s output from ~1m to 3m barrels a day could lift total US production to 14m bpd, one-third of Opec+ capacity. However, decades of underinvestment, corruption and policy volatility leave Chevron, ExxonMobil and ConocoPhillips demanding strong guarantees before committing billions to upgrade facilities. Industry leaders met US officials in Miami and will brief Trump at the White House.

articles.title: Tunbridge Wells residents without water again as supplier blames cold weather
articles.trailText: South East Water says 6,500 households have no water due to burst mains, a month after drinking water outage
articles.summary: South East Water blamed cold-induced burst mains for cutting supply to 6,500 Tunbridge Wells homes and causing intermittent flow for thousands more, a month after a 24,000-house outage at the aging Pembury treatment works. Low reservoir levels halted boosters; SEW has set up water stations, tankers and repair crews but warns disruptions may persist for days. MPs Mike Martin and Alistair Carmichael have criticised its underinvestment, questioned CEO David Hinton’s comments at a Westminster inquiry and demanded a governance review.

articles.title: M&S Christmas food sales soar but clothing suffers from cyber-attack fallout
articles.trailText: Poor festive fashion sales deepen fears of squeeze on UK household budgets and falling high street footfall
articles.summary: Marks & Spencer reported a strong Christmas trading period, with food sales at established stores up 5.6% in the three months to December 27 and total group sales up 3.3% to £4.15bn (excluding its Ocado JV). Clothing, homeware and beauty sales fell 2.9%, hit by last year’s cyber-attack that halted online orders for six weeks, alongside weak consumer confidence, mild weather and reduced footfall. Underlying half-year profits to September 27 halved to £184.1m. M&S will accelerate its reshaping strategy—downsizing full-line clothing outlets and expanding its 800 food-only stores—while non-food recovers.

articles.title: Trump says he plans crackdown on defense firms over executive pay and stock buybacks
articles.trailText: President says he wants to raise military budget to $1.5tn and accuses US defense companies of delivery failures
articles.summary: President Donald Trump announced intentions to limit defense contractors’ executive pay to $5m and ban dividends and stock buybacks until firms like Lockheed Martin, RTX and Northrop Grumman accelerate delivery of vital military equipment and invest in new production plants. He’s proposing a military budget increase to $1.5 trn by 2027 and warned Raytheon to boost volume or lose Pentagon contracts. Top CEOs drew over $18–24m in 2024, prompting Trump’s directive on Truth Social despite no formal legislative plan. He made the announcement following recent US strikes in Venezuela and proposals to acquire Greenland.

articles.title: Starmer vows to review franchise legislation in response to Vodafone case
articles.trailText: Prime minister to ‘look closely’ at outcome of legal claims against FTSE 100 telecoms group
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer pledged to review UK franchising laws after the alleged suicide of ex-Vodafone franchisee Adrian Howe, who family say was pressured into a failing store. The Commons debate followed a Guardian investigation and testimony from two other former franchisees—Rachael Beddow-Davison and Dan Attwal—whose commission cuts sparked debts and suicide attempts. A group of 62 claimants are suing Vodafone for “unjust enrichment,” and MPs compared it to the Post Office scandal. Starmer said he’ll examine the case outcome as ministers weigh stronger franchise protections.

articles.title: Venezuela to continue supplying oil to US ‘indefinitely’, White House says
articles.trailText: US to remove some sanctions to allow it to keep selling country’s supplies after laying claim to blockaded crude
articles.summary: The US has seized control of 50m barrels of Venezuelan crude, capturing two tankers and plans to market both stockpiled and future Venezuelan oil indefinitely, with proceeds routed to benefit citizens, US energy secretary Chris Wright said. By retaining all sales and dictating terms via sanctions relief, Washington aims to drive regime change. The move, seized over objections from China and amid falling Brent to around $60/bl, risks Kremlin confrontation and complicates Beijing imports. PDVSA and US oil firms led by Chevron are negotiating deals despite Venezuela’s output slump from 3.5m to 1m bpd.

articles.title: ‘We’re in limbo’: the garden centre ‘golden mile’ that may be lost to a new town
articles.trailText: Crews Hill near Enfield in north London could become a victim of Labour’s ambitious housebuilding goal
articles.summary: Crews Hill, Enfield’s green-belt ‘golden mile’ of family-run garden centres, greenhouses and a golf course faces potential redevelopment as one of a dozen new towns proposed by Labour’s taskforce to deliver 21,000 homes (50% affordable), part of a 1.5 million target. The 884 ha site, served by limited rail links, would expand services and transport but local traders fear forced relocation, uncertain compensation and infrastructure strain. Critics call for brownfield-first planning, while Enfield council and MHCLG back the scheme as vital investment pending a spring decision.

articles.title: Surprise dip in inflation a lightbulb moment – but RBA unlikely to deliver interest rate bargains | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: Reserve Bank will not find any reason in the new figures to cut rates next month, but the unexpected lower rate should prevent an increase
articles.summary: November’s annual inflation unexpectedly eased to 3.4% (from 3.8%), driven by a 0% monthly price change and falls in both headline CPI and the trimmed mean. Electricity rebate timing fuelled state divergence – Brisbane saw 5.1% inflation versus 2.8% in Perth – while rents and power together accounted for 20% of the rise. Black Friday discounts had little net impact. Despite the dip, the RBA is set to hold rates in February, though a hike is now unlikely until after the next CPI release.

articles.title: UK construction hit by worst run since global financial crisis
articles.trailText: Output shrank for 12th month in a row in December, while housebuilding in deepest slump since 2020
articles.summary: In December, UK construction output fell for the 12th consecutive month—its worst run since the 2007-09 crisis—with the S&P Global/CIPS PMI at 40.1. Housebuilding sank to 33.5, a low since May 2020, while commercial work dropped at the fastest pace in over five years and civil engineering stayed weak. Firms blamed weak demand, fragile client confidence and budget delays. Yet confidence rose to its highest in six months: 37% expect output gains, buoyed by lower borrowing costs, fiscal clarity and infrastructure plans. Economists foresee only modest growth in 2026 amid lingering policy headwinds.

articles.title: FCA fines two former Carillion directors for misleading investors before collapse
articles.trailText: Richard Adam and Zafar Khan knew about serious problems but failed to alert the market, UK regulator finds
articles.summary: The FCA has fined ex-Carillion directors Richard Adam (£232,800) and Zafar Khan (£138,900) after finding they knew of critical issues before the group’s £7bn collapse in January 2018 but failed to alert investors, board or audit committee; both dropped their appeals. Months earlier, Carillion had stunned markets with an £845m write-down. Its liquidation cost 3,000 jobs, disrupted 450 public projects—including two major hospitals—and overran budgets by hundreds of millions. KPMG was fined £21m for audit failures; Khan faces an 11-year director ban and former CEO Richard Howson is contesting related FCA findings.

articles.title: Australia Post apologises for losing Aboriginal artist’s painting worth $4,000
articles.trailText: Bobbi Lockyer says she sent the item express post with tracking as the national postal service says the search continues
articles.summary: Aboriginal artist Bobbi Lockyer shipped a custom $4,000 painting to a collector via Australia Post’s express service with tracking and a protective sleeve recommended by staff. The artwork never arrived—her client received an empty cardboard tube on Christmas Eve. Both Lockyer and the collector filed complaints; Australia Post closed the case, blamed improper packaging and provided generic “cut-and-paste” responses. Lockyer insists she followed instructions and has repeatedly reopened the investigation. Australia Post has since apologised, says it continues to search its network and notes standard services insure only up to $100, recommending extra cover for valuable items.

articles.title: The FTSE at 10,000: a missed opportunity for some marketing razzmatazz | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: If Rachel Reeves and the London Stock Exchange want to encourage investing, they should have milked this moment
articles.summary: The FTSE 100’s first breach of 10,000 is largely symbolic, given its value-weighted construction, reinvested dividends and multinational-heavy membership (c.75% revenues abroad). Chancellor Reeves’ tweet lauding it as a vote of confidence in Britain’s economy overstates its significance, while the London Stock Exchange Group missed a marketing opportunity to spotlight long-term equity returns: no celebratory cap giveaways or razzmatazz to nudge savers from cash ISAs. Instead, City participants are funding a £15m national campaign on investing benefits, yet passed up the chance to capitalise on the 10,000 landmark as a promotional milestone.

articles.title: Kent water failure was foreseen and could have been stopped, regulator says
articles.trailText: Problem at water treatment centre left 24,000 Tunbridge Wells homes without drinking water for two weeks
articles.summary: Regulators told MPs at the Efra committee that a foreseeable failure at South East Water’s Pembury treatment plant left 24,000 Tunbridge Wells households without potable water and under a boil‐water notice for two weeks from 30 November. DWI inspectors flagged a November 9 deterioration, but the company skipped required tests and didn’t fit an aluminium filter or real‐time monitors. CEO David Hinton blamed rare raw‐water chemistry shifts, climate pressures and single‐asset supply, while regulator Marcus Rink warned proper testing would have averted the crisis. DWI now lacks further sanction powers, and South East Water recently required a £200m rescue.

articles.title: US will be exempt from global tax deal targeting profits of large multinationals
articles.trailText: Agreement finalised by the OECD waters down a landmark 2021 deal that set a minimum global corporate tax of 15%
articles.summary: Nearly 150 countries backed an OECD plan to enforce a 15% minimum global corporate tax to curb profit shifting to havens, but large US-based multinationals are exempt following Trump-era negotiations. OECD chief Mathias Cormann hailed it as landmark tax cooperation, and US Treasury secretary Scott Bessent called it a victory for sovereignty. Critics, including the Fact Coalition, warn the amended deal undermines a decade of progress, allowing America's biggest firms like Apple and Nike to continue parking earnings in low-tax jurisdictions.

articles.title: Deep in the vaults: the Bank of England’s £1.4bn Venezuelan gold conundrum
articles.trailText: Nicolás Maduro’s seizure by US reopens question of who controls country’s reserves held in the UK
articles.summary: After Nicolás Maduro’s US seizure, control of Venezuela’s 31 tonnes of gold (worth at least £1.4bn) in the Bank of England vaults has resurfaced. Held since the 1980s, these bullion bars haven’t been repatriated amid UK and US sanctions imposed after Maduro’s disputed 2018 election. A London court battle between Maduro’s and Juan Guaidó’s camps remains unresolved even after Guaidó lost recognition. UK refuses to release the gold pending democratic transition, calling the freeze vital to maintaining pressure on Caracas. The dispute highlights a broader trend of sovereign assets immobilised abroad amid geopolitical tensions and underpins gold’s recent price rally.

articles.title: Next expects profits to top £1.1bn after bumper festive sales
articles.trailText: Retailer warns that growth this year will be slower amid continuing pressures on UK employment
articles.summary: Next has raised its annual profit forecast to £1.15bn (+13.7%) and sales to £5.6bn (+10.7%) after UK festive trading delivered a 5.9% like-for-like boost over nine weeks to Dec 27, aided by higher stock availability and a £30m stronger end-of-year sale. Overseas revenues surged 38%, driven by increased marketing and its Zalando partnership. Despite four upgrades in eight months, Next warns 2026 growth will moderate to 4.5% amid UK employment pressures, one-off 2025 tailwinds (sunny summer, M&S cyber-attack pause) and scaled-back overseas marketing.

articles.title: Trump suggests US taxpayers could reimburse oil firms for Venezuela investment
articles.trailText: President says a ‘tremendous amount of money’ will need to be spent repairing country’s infrastructure
articles.summary: Donald Trump said US taxpayers could reimburse energy firms for rebuilding Venezuelan oil infrastructure after US intervention ousts Nicolás Maduro. He expects Chevron, ExxonMobil and ConocoPhillips to invest billions, then recoup costs through government payments or future revenue. Energy Secretary Chris Wright plans talks with these majors at a Miami conference. It marks a bid to revive output from 1.1m bpd to former highs, despite legal, political and infrastructural hurdles. Only Chevron currently operates, while Exxon and Conoco await clarity on US policy. Venezuela’s output has slumped from 3.5m bpd in 1999 to about 1.1m, underscoring the scale of required investment.

articles.title: Aldi and Lidl grab record Christmas sales share as Asda and Co-op slide
articles.trailText: Shoppers hit by rising bills switch to discount chains, supermarket own-label products and buying fewer items
articles.summary: Aldi and Lidl captured a record 16.8% of Britain’s Christmas grocery market in the four weeks to 28 Dec (up from 16.3% a year earlier) as shoppers, squeezed by rising bills, switched to discounters, own-label products and smaller baskets. Total food-at-home spend hit £13.8 bn (average £476 per household). Lidl was the fastest-growing store, closing in on Morrisons, while Aldi narrowed the gap with Asda (11.4% share, down 4.2%). Premium own-label sales topped £1 bn (+9%) in 92% of baskets. Tesco led with 28.7% share, Sainsbury’s 16.3% and Waitrose rose 4.5%. Online grocery sales grew 7.5% to 12.2% of the market as inflation eased to 4.3%.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover sales slump sharply amid US tariffs and cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Shares in owner Tata Motors fall after carmaker confirms impact of devastating hack
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover’s Q4 wholesale volumes plunged 43.3% to 59,200 and retail sales tumbled 25.1% to 79,600, resulting in a near £500 m loss after a late-August cyber-attack halted production in the UK, Slovakia, Brazil and India through September, with full output only restored by mid-November. Incremental US tariffs and the wind-down of older models ahead of a new Jaguar EV launch further dented performance. Retail sales fell across all markets (UK −13.3%, North America −37.7%, Europe −26.9%, China −18.4%); full-year volumes dropped about 19%, and Tata Motors shares fell around 4%.

articles.title: Taxpayers miss out on millions after ‘phoenixism’ at UK recruitment firms
articles.trailText: Practice where companies are liquidated and reacquired, free of debts, thought to cost taxpayers about £800m a year
articles.summary: Insolvent UK recruitment firms use “phoenixism” – pre-pack liquidation then reacquisition by former directors – to wipe debts, costing HMRC around £800m–£840m annually. Cases: Russell Taylor rebought twice, leaving ~£1m unpaid; Silven Recruitment sold to its majority shareholder for £150k, cutting a £600k tax debt to £400k; Qualiteach sold for £27k with £305k owed. Challenge Recruitment left £90m and Premier Group £647k unpaid. Experts warn this cycle encourages repeat insolvencies, unfair competition and hinders tax recovery.

articles.title: FTSE 100 CEOs earn more than average worker’s yearly pay by noon on 6 January
articles.trailText: High Pay Centre calculates bosses will pass milestone on third working day of 2026 with median pay of £1,353 an hour
articles.summary: FTSE 100 chief executives now earn a median £4.4 m—113 times the £39 039 median worker salary—so by about 11.30 am on 6 Jan they’ve out-earned the average UK employee’s full-year pay. High Pay Centre data show a £1 353/hr rate. Melrose’s Peter Dilnot & Simon Peckham led with nearly £59 m, AstraZeneca’s Pascal Soriot £14.7 m. TUC’s Paul Nowak and the High Pay Centre urge worker board seats, tougher corporate governance and higher taxes on excessive pay, while the new Employment Rights Act aims to strengthen unions. Boards counter that such pay is needed to compete globally.

articles.title: UK car sales top 2m in 2025 as Chinese brands boom
articles.trailText: Electric car sales rose by nearly a quarter to a record 473,000, or 23.4% of the overall market, says SMMT
articles.summary: UK car sales exceeded 2m in 2025, driven by a surge in Chinese brands—196,000 registrations (9.7% share versus 4.9% in 2024)—led by MG (85,000), BYD (51,000) and Chery (54,000). Electric vehicles reached a record 473,000 units (23.4% of the market), cutting average emissions by 10%. Discounts averaged £11,000 on EVs and £6,000 on ICE cars. Industry pressure to meet a 28% zero-emission vehicle mandate and government pay-per-mile plans prompted calls from SMMT chief Mike Hawes to review targets early amid geopolitical and economic headwinds.

articles.title: Claire’s and The Original Factory Shop near collapse, putting 2,550 jobs at risk
articles.trailText: Owner Modella starts insolvency proceedings for both chains, saying trading is ‘extremely challenging’
articles.summary: Modella Capital has initiated insolvency proceedings for its Claire’s and The Original Factory Shop chains, imperiling 2,550 jobs. The group’s 154 Claire’s stores (1,350 roles) and 140 cut-price homewares outlets (1,200 roles) will likely enter administration under advisers Kroll and Interpath. Modella blamed a steep pre-Christmas footfall decline, weak consumer confidence, adverse fiscal policies and rising costs. The move follows recent buys—WH Smith’s TG Jones arm and Hobbycraft—and comes after losses and restructuring efforts failed to restore profitability.

articles.title: Despite Trump’s hopes, big oil will be wary of rushing back to Venezuela | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: The US might aim to unlock the country’s reserves, but cost and political uncertainty make it look an uncertain option
articles.summary: Trump wants major US oil companies to invest billions to repair Venezuela’s crumbling oil infrastructure and boost output, but apart from Chevron, firms remain hesitant. Analysts estimate $115 bn to restore production to 2 m b/d by the early 2030s, while Trump’s push for $50 oil caps long-term rewards. Unclear sanctions, fiscal terms, political stability and high heavy-oil costs, plus past double nationalizations, make Gulf, Guyana and Brazil more appealing. Majors favor share buy-backs over high-risk projects, and SocGen notes re-entry risks remain high.

articles.title: Novo Nordisk launches Wegovy weight-loss pill in US, triggering price war
articles.trailText: First and only GLP-1 pill on the market costs significantly less than injectable versions
articles.summary: Novo Nordisk has launched Wegovy, the first oral GLP-1 weight-loss pill, in the US at $5/day ($149/mo starting dose), undercutting injectable jabs (~$1,000/mo) and triggering a price war with rivals like Eli Lilly. Cash-paying patients pay $149–$299/mo by dose; insured pay from $25/month. Approved pre-Christmas, it mimics the appetite-suppressing GLP-1 hormone, promises ~17% weight loss, and is stocked in 70,000+ pharmacies and telehealth platforms. Shares rose 4% on launch news as Novo seeks to regain share after profit warnings, job cuts and competition from Mounjaro and Zepbound. UK approval pending.

articles.title: Dense, sticky and heavy: why Venezuelan crude oil appeals to US refineries
articles.trailText: South American nation’s tar-like oil is what many Gulf coast facilities were built for but ramping up production to 3m barrels a day will be a long game
articles.summary: US Gulf Coast refineries built for dense, high-sulphur Venezuelan crude stand to benefit from Trump's push to unblock cheap oil for reindustrialisation. Imports plunged from almost 2m to 135k b/d under Maduro and US sanctions, but analysts say refineries could absorb an extra 1m b/d, displacing costlier Canadian heavy oil and denting China's supply. However, restoring Venezuela's output to 3m b/d demands $185bn over 16 years, plus political and institutional stability to lure foreign investment. Short-term recovery remains unlikely amid infrastructure decay and workforce losses.

articles.title: Prax Lindsey oil refinery bought out of administration by US rival
articles.trailText: Insolvency Service says 250 staff remaining at Lincolnshire site will be guaranteed jobs until the end of March
articles.summary: US energy major Phillips 66 has acquired the Prax Lindsey oil refinery in North Killingholme after its June administration, integrating the site into its neighbouring Humber refinery rather than re-launch standalone operations. The Insolvency Service said the undisclosed-price sale guarantees jobs for 250 remaining staff until end-March, though their longer-term future is unclear. Administrators judged the deal best for creditors after no bids could fund a return to refining. Government and Phillips 66 hailed the move for bolstering UK fuel supply and energy security, while unions warn against mothballing a plant that once supplied 10% of domestic diesel.

articles.title: US energy stocks rise as Trump vows to unlock Venezuela’s oil
articles.trailText: Oil price rises despite fears US president’s pledge could deepen global supply glut
articles.summary: After Trump’s pledge to tap Venezuela’s 17%-global crude reserves following Maduro’s ousting, US energy stocks surged—Chevron +5%, Exxon Mobil +2.2%, Halliburton +7.8%—lifting the Dow Jones above 49,000. Brent rose 1.5% to $61.76, WTI 1.4% to $58.32. Although Venezuela now supplies just 1% of output, investments to rehabilitate aging oilfields could take until 2030. US firms remain cautious, but ex-Chevron exec Ali Moshiri is raising $2bn. Venezuelan bonds jumped amid regime-change bets, China probes lender exposure, Opec+ holds cuts, while gold, silver and bitcoin also rally.

articles.title: Aldi reports record Christmas sales after shoppers moved to cut festive grocery bills
articles.trailText: UK’s fourth-largest supermarket’s sales rose 3% with 5.5m bottles of fizz and 500,000 turkeys sold
articles.summary: Aldi UK posted record Christmas 2025 sales, rising 3% to £1.65 bn in the four weeks to 24 Dec and 5% (£500 m) in the final week, driving 57 m transactions. It opened 40 stores (now 1 081, targeting 1 500) and saw a 12% jump in its Specially Selected premium range—including wagyu roast potatoes, double-wrapped pigs in blankets and white chocolate pinecones. Shoppers bought 5.5 m bottles of fizz, 500 k turkeys, 56 m potatoes and 37 m carrots. CEO Giles Hurley stressed affordable quality amid cost pressures. Rival Lidl recorded a 10% sales rise to £1.1 bn, aided by early buying, new stores and its Lidl Plus scheme.

articles.title: HSBC becomes first big UK lender to cut its mortgage rates in 2026
articles.trailText: Reduction follows Bank of England’s base cut in December, with further cuts expected this year
articles.summary: HSBC has become the first major UK mortgage lender to cut rates in 2026 across residential and buy-to-let products, following the Bank of England’s December base rate cut to 3.75%. Effective Monday, the reductions could prompt a “January rate war” as rivals vie for roughly 1.8m remortgagers leaving pre-2022 fixed deals. With two further BoE cuts expected, average two-year fixes sit at 4.83% (4.7% for buy-to-let), and sub-3.5% offers may emerge by spring.

articles.title: Battery electric cars will overtake diesels in Great Britain by 2030, analysis suggests
articles.trailText: London predicted to be the first UK city to go diesel-free, largely because of the ultra-low emission zone
articles.summary: Analysis by New AutoMotive finds that battery electric cars will surpass diesel vehicles on Great Britain’s roads by 2030, with diesel registrations down 21% from their 12.4m peak to 9.9m in mid-2025. EV market share is rising from 4%, though van electrification lags as diesel vans hit a 4.4m record. Diesel car sales fell below 100,000 in the first 11 months of 2025 after tax breaks fuelled a 2000s “dash for diesel” and the 2015 Dieselgate scandal. London, driven by ULEZ charges, and Scottish low-emission zones are poised to be diesel-free first, boosting urban air quality, reducing NOx, and reshaping fuel networks.

articles.title: The government probably took too much of your paycheck this year – here’s how to get it back
articles.trailText: Trump’s tax bill carved out several areas for tipped workers and older adults, among others, to lower their tax bills
articles.summary: Taxpayers can expect record refunds in Q1 2026 as many overpaid under-withheld payroll taxes after new deductions from the Trump administration’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act. Service workers can deduct up to $25,000 of tipped income; overtime earners up to $12,500 ($25,000 joint); seniors an extra $6,000. Small businesses gain higher first-year depreciation, R&D write-offs, flexible spending account boosts and a $5,000-per-child Trump savings account. Deductions phase out above $150,000; state and payroll taxes still apply. File by April 15 and adjust 2026 withholdings, verifying W-2 calculations to avoid errors.

articles.title: The cost of AI slop could cause a rethink that shakes the global economy in 2026
articles.trailText: Revenues may be rising rapidly, but not by nearly enough to cover the wild levels of investment under way
articles.summary: In 2025, AI-generated 'slop'—low-quality content—highlighted cracks in the sector’s unit economics: $400bn+ poured into R&D and datacentre debt (c.$178.5bn), yet revenues lag, says Ed Zitron and Cory Doctorow. Rising iteration costs, limited chip lifespans and bubble-style financial engineering compound risk. High-profile errors—from fictitious legal citations to flawed police transcriptions—undermine hype about superintelligence and may cap productivity gains. A market correction in tech giants (now 35% of the S&P500) could shave 0.6% off UK GDP and spill losses across global investors, exporters and lenders.

articles.title: From the AI bubble to Fed fears: the global economic outlook for 2026
articles.trailText: Analysts and investors voice caution about tech valuations and Trump’s influence on the US central bank
articles.summary: Investors forecast global equities to climb roughly 15% in 2026 despite headwinds from a potential AI bubble burst, Fed turmoil under a Trump-appointed chair and private credit strain. A Deutsche Bank poll of 440 professionals ranks AI valuation declines (57%), aggressive rate cuts by the next Fed chair and shadow-banking crises as the top market risks. UBS, Deutsche Bank and Oppenheimer predict double-digit S&P 500 gains, while UK stocks and government bonds could benefit from profit growth and dovish BoE policy. Strong US and Chinese growth, controlled inflation and rising AI capex underpin optimism, though skeptics like Michael Burry warn of a downturn.

articles.title: What role could the US play in Venezuela’s ‘bust’ oil industry?
articles.trailText: Experts say lifting production to former levels could take decades and huge investment will be needed
articles.summary: After seizing Caracas, Trump vowed to deploy ExxonMobil, Chevron and ConocoPhillips to inject tens of billions into Venezuela’s dilapidated oil sector—home to an estimated 300 bn-barrel reserve but crippled by underinvestment, corruption and ageing infrastructure. Output has plunged from 3.5 m to about 1 m barrels a day. US majors would likely partner state PDVSA for profit‐sharing, though success isn’t assured—Libya and Iraq offer cautionary tales. Currently China takes 80% of exports as loan repayment; Washington could redirect crude to US refineries. A full revival could span a decade or more.

articles.title: End of the line for diesel fumes at London St Pancras as new trains arrive
articles.trailText: East Midlands railway will switch to bi-mode Aurora fleet to cut emissions and noise but elsewhere electrification is delayed
articles.summary: East Midlands Railway will cease diesel operations at London St Pancras by late 2026, deploying a £400m Hitachi-built Aurora bi-mode fleet—three years behind schedule—cutting carbon emissions by 66% on electrified track south of Leicester and reducing noise and NOx exposure. Midland main line electrification has been scaled back amid cost overruns on Great Western, leaving bi-modes to switch to diesel northwards. Wider UK rail decarbonisation relies on partial wiring, battery-hybrids and targeted upgrades as only 39% of routes are electrified.

articles.title: Feeling the bite: is Greggs on a roll or is its expansion overbaked?
articles.trailText: UK pastry chain has plans for two new factories and 800 more branches, despite sales falling in 2025 and analysts questioning brand’s direction
articles.summary: Greggs, the UK’s leading bakery chain with 2,675 outlets, produces 1m sausage rolls daily at its Newcastle plant and is investing £300m in new automated factories in Derby and Kettering by 2027 to fuel a target of 3,500 stores. Despite rapid expansion, 2025 saw like-for-like sales fall, a 40% share-price slump and status as the UK’s most-shorted stock. Analysts and activist Lauro Asset warn of market saturation, while CEO Roisin Currie insists Greggs hasn’t peaked. The chain is testing smaller “Bitesize” shops, a festive pop-up pub and healthier menu options to boost growth.

articles.title: ‘Sunshine Saturday’: UK firms expect 5% January rise in holiday bookings
articles.trailText: Quieter destinations, such as Malta’s sister island, Gozo, and long-haul locations are expected to be popular
articles.summary: UK travel firms anticipate a 5% January uptick in package bookings—200k more than the 4.3m recorded last year—as 'Sunshine Saturday' weekend demand peaks. CAA and TravelSupermarket data indicate a pivot to quieter/long-haul spots: Gozo searches soared 1,900%, Sri Lanka 605%, while Tenerife, Malta, Egypt, Dubai and Fuerteventura hold top overall. Abta notes many trips are booked into summer 2026 and 2027, with families favoring short breaks and shoulder-season stays. Average flight duration has climbed 20+ minutes, reflecting mid-/long-haul interest, even as Menorca, Lake Como and Sicily cool. Which? Travel advises consumers to shop around rather than rush.

articles.title: China’s BYD overtakes Tesla as world’s biggest electric car seller
articles.trailText: Sales at Elon Musk’s company slump after Donald Trump’s withdrawal of EV subsidies
articles.summary: In 2025 China’s BYD sold 2.26 million battery EVs, overtaking Tesla’s 1.63 million as the world’s top electric carmaker. Tesla’s deliveries slumped 9 percent year-on-year amid Donald Trump’s EV subsidy cuts, relaxed emissions rules and consumer backlash over Elon Musk’s politics, dragging Q4 sales to 418,200. BYD’s EV output rose 28 percent despite stiff domestic competition; its plug-in hybrids slipped 8 percent to 2.29 million. Tesla, still valued at $1.4 trillion, bets on AI-driven robotics and robotaxis, while BYD expands commercial vehicles and rolls out “God’s Eye” driver-assist tech.

articles.title: Ørsted files legal challenge against US government over windfarm lease freeze
articles.trailText: Europe’s biggest offshore wind developer seeking to overturn White House decision to suspend work on a $5bn wind farm project
articles.summary: Europe���s largest offshore wind firm Ørsted has sued the Trump administration over its December 22 suspension of the $5 bn Revolution Wind lease off the US northeast coast, part of a broader halt on five offshore wind projects citing unspecified national security risks. Ørsted and Skyborn Renewables argue the pause violates federal law and threatens a project 90% built and due to supply power by 2026. Shares dipped 12% post-suspension but rose 4% on news of the injunction. Critics, including Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, warn the freeze undermines jobs, raises energy costs, and stalls climate goals.

articles.title: UK house prices unexpectedly fell at end of year, Nationwide says
articles.trailText: Average property price drops by 0.4% in December to £271,068 after forecasts of 0.1% month-on-month rise
articles.summary: Nationwide reports UK house prices unexpectedly fell 0.4% month-on-month in December to £271,068, confounding forecasts of a 0.1% rise. Annual growth slowed to 0.6%, the weakest since April 2024. Quilter’s Ian Futcher attributes the drop to an amplified seasonal slowdown amid delayed fiscal decisions, while Nationwide’s Robert Gardner highlights resilient mortgage approvals near pre-Covid levels. First-time buyer share remains above the long-run average, and low-deposit loans are at a decade-high. Halifax notes affordability is strongest since 2015. After the Bank of England cut rates to 3.75%, further cuts could unlock postponed housing plans.

articles.title: FTSE 100 breaks 10,000 mark for first time, capping stellar year for UK market
articles.trailText: Blue-chip share index, created in 1984, has risen by more than 20% over past 12 months
articles.summary: The FTSE 100 jumped past 10,000 for the first time on Jan 2, 2026, after a 21.5% gain in 2025, hitting 10,046 before easing. Engineering giant Rolls-Royce and luxury group Burberry led Friday’s rally, part of the lightweight “Santa Claus rally” around year-end. Chancellor Rachel Reeves hailed it as a vote of confidence in Britain’s economy. The surge helped Europe’s Stoxx 600 reach a record high amid hopes of rate cuts, an AI boom and easing trade tensions. Mining, energy and defence stocks outperformed, with Fresnillo up 450% in 2025. UK equities benefited from diversification away from the US amid global recovery.

articles.title: Mini-revival of London stock market listings is relief to Rachel Reeves | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Payments firm Wise snubbed the UK in 2025 but the RAC and software giant Visma are forecast to float this year
articles.summary: In 2025 London’s IPO market recovered modestly after a Trump-induced first-half slump, raising billions in H2—led by Fermi’s dual Nasdaq launch, Princes Group’s £1.2bn float and Shawbrook. The rebound offers relief to the LSE and chancellor Rachel Reeves, who promotes equity markets and introduced a three-year post-IPO stamp duty holiday. A stronger pipeline for 2026 includes Visma’s €20bn software IPO, IVC Evidensia veterinary group, RAC (and possibly AA), book chains Waterstones-Barnes & Noble, fintech Ebury and Loveholidays. Challenges remain: Wise shifted to a US listing and total LSE main-market firms fell from 972 to 930.

articles.title: UK government should end rail outsourcing ‘racket’, says union
articles.trailText: RMT estimates six cleaning, security and catering suppliers made £150m profits last year
articles.summary: RMT research shows six major facilities-management firms—Mitie, OCS, Bidvest Noonan, Churchill, Carlisle Support Services (owned by ex-peer Michael Ashcroft) and ABM—raked in £152m profits last year on average 11% margins, with cost-increase clauses shifting wage and tax hikes onto the Treasury. Mitie’s CEO Phil Bentley earned £20.5m over two years. Unions and Labour urge a sweeping insourcing drive under GBR to reinvest in staff and services. Rail Minister Peter Hendy backs fresh reviews of 30-year outsourcing arrangements, leaving final choices to GBR management.

articles.title: UK law firms get ready for crackdown on money laundering
articles.trailText: Harsher penalties and a ‘reshaping’ of the sector predicted when Financial Conduct Authority takes over as regulator
articles.summary: From 2026 the FCA will centralize anti-money-laundering oversight of UK law firms, consolidating power from nine bodies including the SRA. In a bid to repair the City’s FATF record ahead of a 2027 review, the FCA’s “sharper” sanctions—ranging from £289k to £39.3m versus the SRA’s £1.5m total in 2023–24—and tougher vetting (44% of 2023–24 licence applications rejected) signal a data-driven, stricter regime that could reshape the sector.

articles.title: Oil prices record steepest annual fall since Covid pandemic
articles.trailText: After biggest loss for producers since 2020 the slide could continue, with global output expected to remain high
articles.summary: Oil prices slumped nearly 20% in 2025, recording the steepest annual fall since 2020 and a third straight year of losses as supply outstripped demand. Brent dipped below $60 a barrel amid "cartoonishly" oversupplied markets, despite OPEC deferring production cuts and a possible Russia-Ukraine peace lifting sanctions. The IEA sees a 3.8m b/d surplus in 2026, with banks forecasting Brent in the $50s by spring. Cheaper crude may ease pump prices and inflation, though retail fuel costs remain high. In Great Britain, Ofgem has raised the energy price cap by 0.2% for January–March.

articles.title: Wall Street ends 2025 near record highs after year of economic upheaval
articles.trailText: US markets buoyed by sustained rise in tech stocks as investors largely shrug off concerns over Trump tariffs
articles.summary: Wall Street closed 2025 near record highs as the S&P 500 rose 16.4% to 6,845.50, while the Dow gained 13.4% and Nasdaq rallied 20.5%. London’s FTSE 100 posted its biggest annual gain since 2009, up 21.5%. Markets were buoyed by a tech-led AI frenzy—Nvidia capped the year up 34.8% with a historic $4.55 trn valuation—despite geopolitical jitters, Trump’s highest tariff rates since 1935 and the longest US government shutdown. Inflation, stalled jobs growth and bubble concerns fueled a widening “K-shaped” economy, leaving many Americans uneasy about their financial security.

articles.title: Waitrose urges customers not to drink Deeside water over shards of glass risk
articles.trailText: Food Standards Agency issues product alert for still and sparkling 750ml bottles of Waitrose No 1 Deeside mineral water
articles.summary: Waitrose has issued a recall of still and sparkling 750 ml Waitrose No 1 Deeside mineral water after the Food Standards Agency (FSA) launched a product alert warning certain batches bottled near Balmoral Castle in Scotland’s Cairngorms may contain glass fragments. Priced at about £1.60, affected codes (e.g. still: NOV2027 28, DEC2027 01/02/10; sparkling: DEC2027 01/03/12) have been pulled from shelves. Customers are urged to check batch numbers, stop consumption, and return bottles for a full refund or contact customer care. Waitrose apologises for the inconvenience. This follows recent recalls of a Santa-themed drinks bottle, a plant-based meat product, and Disaronno spirits over shard risks.

articles.title: Eurostar slowly resumes but passengers face more cancellations and delays
articles.trailText: Passengers told to expect knock-on impacts after power supply problem and broken-down train halted services on Tuesday
articles.summary: Eurostar services through the Channel Tunnel resumed gradually on New Year’s Eve after an overhead power line failure and a broken LeShuttle train on Tuesday halted London–Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam routes, leaving thousands stranded in powerless carriages overnight. Knock-on impacts triggered widespread cancellations, six-hour waits at Folkestone and Calais terminals and last-minute timetable changes. Passengers reported total darkness, no heating or toilets and exhausted crew. Eurostar urged travelers to postpone trips amid delays, as it faces criticism over fares and looming competition from Virgin and Trenitalia by 2029.

articles.title: ITV agrees to invest £3m in fitness app created by Joe Wicks
articles.trailText: The Body Coach app, launched in pandemic, will advertise on ITV’s channels and video platform ITVX under deal
articles.summary: ITV to invest up to £3m in Joe Wicks' Body Coach fitness app via its AdVentures Invest fund, taking an equity stake in exchange for ad slots on ITV channels and streaming platform ITVX. Launched in 2020, the app offers personalized workouts, healthy recipes and community support, building on Wicks' Covid lockdown popularity. A TV commercial will debut 1 January during Wicks' ITV1/ITVX show. The deal comes as ITV faces acquisition talks with Comcast and taps AdVentures to scale digital consumer brands through targeted TV advertising.

articles.title: London stock exchange beats Wall Street with best FTSE 100 year since 2009
articles.trailText: FTSE index closes up 21.5% on New Year’s Eve at end of strong year for global equity markets
articles.summary: FTSE 100 rose 21.5% in 2025, its strongest annual gain since 2009, outpacing the S&P 500’s 17%. Precious-metals stocks led: Fresnillo +450%, Endeavour Mining +170%; gold surged 65%. Airtel Africa climbed 210%. Defence names Babcock and Rolls-Royce gained nearly 150% and 100% on higher European military spending. Over one fifth of components fell, led by Bunzl and Diageo (-33%). World equities rallied 21%, their best year since 2019, despite China’s AI-driven $1trn tech sell-off and US tariffs. Hopes of Fed rate cuts sent the US dollar down 9%, while Europe’s Stoxx 600 rose 17% on German stimulus.

articles.title: Fed up: inside Trump’s unprecedented bid to exert control over the US central bank
articles.trailText: The US president and his allies spent 2025 attacking the Federal Reserve amid a rollercoaster year for the US economy
articles.summary: In 2025, President Trump waged an unprecedented public campaign to sway Federal Reserve policy, confronting Chair Jerome Powell over a $3.1bn HQ renovation, threatening legal action and dismissal, and firing Fed governor Lisa Cook—who successfully sued to stay—triggering a Supreme Court showdown over central bank independence. Amid Fed rate cuts from 5.5% to 3.5–3.75%, tariffs and labor-market volatility, Trump is now eyeing Fed chair successors Kevin Warsh or Kevin Hassett to pressure rates down to 1%, risking market stability.

articles.title: How the FTSE 100 ‘dinosaur’ roared back to life | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Uptick of more than 20% in 2025 was fuelled by share buybacks and helpful breezes in key constituent parts such as defence and mining
articles.summary: In 2025 the FTSE 100 rose 21.5%, its best annual gain since 2009, slightly beating the S&P 500. Gains were fuelled by share buybacks and sector tailwinds in defence (Rolls-Royce), mining (Fresnillo nearly 5×, precious metals, copper), banking (low defaults, falling rates), pharmaceuticals (AstraZeneca +30%) and utilities (National Grid, SSE). Cheap valuations—around 10× forward earnings in early 2024—plus corporate reforms such as Unilever’s Magnum spin-off, Anglo American’s Teck merger and BP’s strategic pivot boosted returns. With 55% of large UK firms repurchasing shares versus 40% in the US and deep foreign ownership, London has shed its income-only image even as sector concentration poses risks.

articles.title: One pub a day closed permanently in England and Wales in 2025
articles.trailText: Data shows 366 pubs have been demolished or converted for other uses this year as cost pressures take toll on sector
articles.summary: Government stats show a net loss of 366 pubs in England & Wales in 2025—about one per day—bringing the total to 38,623, down from 38,989 a year earlier. Ryan tax experts warn many conversions (housing, offices, nurseries, cafés) are permanent. Hardest-hit regions include the East Midlands, Northwest, and Yorkshire & Humber. Rising minimum wage, national insurance, and a large business rates revaluation from April 2026 threaten further closures. Industry leaders urge targeted business rates relief to prevent more losses and job cuts. The Treasury counters that a £4.3bn support package limits pub bill increases to 4% and eases licensing.

articles.title: China forecast to have sold one in every 10 new cars in UK in 2025
articles.trailText: Carmakers such as MG, BYD and Chery are set to pass 200,000 mark in sales, analysis suggests, double 2024’s total
articles.summary: Chinese brands MG, BYD and Chery are set to sell over 200,000 new cars in the UK in 2025—about 10% of the market—driven by EV subsidies, battery-chain dominance and no UK tariffs. Analyst Matthias Schmidt notes Chinese share in western Europe averages 6%, reaching 10% in Spain and Norway. EU levies of 17–38% on battery EVs exclude hybrids, allowing Chinese makers to undercut rivals with plug-in models. With local incumbents like Nissan and Toyota losing ground, forecasts see Chinese marques peaking near 10% of EU sales by 2028–30, sparking job-loss concerns in Germany and France.

articles.title: Is ‘coasting’ the perfect way to enjoy an alcoholic drink this New Year’s Eve?
articles.trailText: Retailers say appetite for alcoholic drinks that are about half the strength of the traditional versions is soaring
articles.summary: Retailers report soaring demand for “coasting”—choosing mid-strength drinks (3–9% ABV wine, 2–3% beer, 15–20% spirits) to enjoy more rounds with less hangover. Ocado saw mid-strength wine sales jump 4,000% in 2025 as UK average weekly alcohol intake fell to a record low. Major supermarkets now stock brands like La Felicite rosé, Nice Session sauvignon, Quarter Proof gin alongside nolo options such as Botivo and Mother Root. A mid-strength collective and poll found 21% of drinkers have fewer drinks per session, 13% “coast” and 6% “zebra stripe” between strengths, reflecting evolving cautious drinking habits.

articles.title: Coral Adventurer passengers return with diverging accounts of cruise ship drama
articles.trailText: One passenger tells the ABC it was ‘chaos’ and she felt her life was in danger, but others shrug off the incident
articles.summary: Coral Adventurer grounded Saturday on a reef 90 km off Lae, PNG; refloated Tuesday with a tug and detained by AMSA over hull-damage concerns. None of the 80 passengers and 43 crew were injured. Passengers diverged in accounts—Ursula Daus described “chaos” and fearing for her life, while Marilyn Walter called it a minor jar. The ATSB is investigating, with a preliminary report due in two months. The vessel remains at anchor under diver inspections. Coral Expeditions apologised, cancelled the voyage, flew passengers to Cairns and offered refunds or future credits. This follows an October incident in which 80-year-old Suzanne Rees died after allegedly being left on Lizard Island.

articles.title: Oasis reunion and Taylor Swift vinyls fuel boom year for UK music industry
articles.trailText: BPI figures show music lovers listened to equivalent of 210.3m albums by UK artists in 2025 in 11th consecutive year of growth
articles.summary: BPI annual report: UK music hit 210.3m album equivalents in 2025, up 4.9%, marking its 11th year of growth. Vinyl drove the physical comeback with 7.6m albums (13.3% rise) vs 189m streaming equivalents (5.5%). Taylor Swift’s The Life of a Showgirl sold 147k vinyl copies—her fourth year as top vinyl artist. CDs fell 7.6% to 9.7m, cassettes rose 80% to 330k, and overall physical sales edged up 1.4% to 17.6m. Oasis and Coldplay reunions revived classic albums, Fleetwood Mac remained strong, and breakout acts like Olivia Dean, Sleep Token and Mercury winner Sam Fender impressed. BPI chief Jo Twist urged stronger copyright and AI safeguards to sustain UK music’s global success.

articles.title: Channel tunnel power outage disrupts thousands of journeys
articles.trailText: Engineers still struggling to restore full rail service on Tuesday evening as car passengers face seven-hour delays
articles.summary: Engineers racing to fix a power-supply fault in the Channel Tunnel have suspended all Eurostar passenger and LeShuttle vehicle services since Monday night, stranding thousands at St Pancras and Folkestone with delays up to seven hours. By Tuesday evening trains ran alternately on a single track, but Eurostar cancelled all December 30 departures before 18:00, urging customers to rebook free of charge. Getlink and Eurostar offer free exchanges, refunds or 12-month e-vouchers, plus hotel, food and taxi compensation under EU regulations. Shuttle waits remain around six hours.

articles.title: Fashion brand LK Bennett on brink of collapse
articles.trailText: Clothing chain acquired by China-based backers out of 2019 insolvency applies to appoint administrators
articles.summary: Upmarket fashion chain LK Bennett has applied to the high court for administrators, risking collapse for the second time in six years. The 280-staff business, founded in 1990 by Linda Bennett and acquired by Chinese franchisee Rebecca Feng after 2019 insolvency, failed to secure a rescue ahead of Christmas. Its nine UK stores and 13 concessions come under strain after a £3.2 m loss and £22 m debt by Jan 2024, with auditor Grant Thornton warning of going-concern doubts and looming covenant breaches despite a bank letter extending facilities to January 2026.

articles.title: Jhoots Pharmacy chain could face insolvency after Lloyds Bank high court application
articles.trailText: Struggling company, which has run more than 100 outlets, has been criticised by MPs over claims it failed to pay locum pharmacists
articles.summary: Lloyds Bank has applied to the high court to appoint an administrator to Jhoots Chemist, the Walsall-based chain trading as Jhoots Pharmacy. Facing insolvency, it owes locum pharmacists £670k, reported over £5m of creditors and £1.9m losses in its year to December 2024. MPs rebuked it for unpaid staff, missed openings and drug management failures. Sarbjit Jhooty’s business is targeted, while his brother Manjit’s rebranded JHL branches and 60 stores acquired by Allied Pharmacies escape the filing.

articles.title: Five charts that explain the global economic outlook for 2026
articles.trailText: Inflation is predicted to cool but uncertainty over AI-driven growth and trade policy poses risks in the year ahead
articles.summary: Despite 2025’s headwinds—from trade wars to geopolitical conflicts—the global economy held up and central banks foresee inflation cooling in 2026 as rate cuts begin. Growth may moderate amid lingering trade uncertainty and China’s slowdown, with the US leading G7. AI investment offers productivity upside but bubble fears top risk surveys. Tariff-driven trade fragmentation and fiscal strains (bond-market pressures) persist. Unemployment ticks up in rich economies, pressuring wages, while policymakers navigate fragile conditions and the risk of renewed inflation shocks. In the UK, disinflation lags despite fiscal adjustments, while the ECB stays cautious near its 2% target.

articles.title: Octopus Energy to sell stake in software spin-off Kraken at $8.65bn valuation
articles.trailText: CEO of Britain’s biggest household energy supplier says technology arm could float in the medium term
articles.summary: Octopus Energy agreed to sell a $1bn stake in its Kraken software arm to investors including Fidelity International and Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, valuing Kraken at $8.65bn and leaving Octopus with 13.7%. Kraken, licensed by UK rivals E.ON, EDF and Good Energy and international firms like Tokyo Gas and Origin Energy, underpins billing, smart meter management, EV charging and home battery integration to enable real-time tariff pricing. Founder Greg Jackson is pursuing an independent spin-off, potential London IPO and using proceeds for new takeovers and tech ventures. Octopus posted a £260m pre-tax loss amid warm weather and expansion costs but its balance sheet stands at £1.5bn boosted by the Kraken deal.

articles.title: Renewable energy project approvals hit record high in GB in 2025, data shows
articles.trailText: Applications to build battery storage drive boom as offshore wind projects given go-ahead jump sevenfold year on year
articles.summary: In 2025, planning approvals for renewable power projects in Great Britain surged 96% year-on-year to 45GW, driven by battery storage (up to 28.6GW) and offshore wind (9.9GW, a sevenfold rise), Cornwall Insight data shows. Energy secretary Ed Miliband credits this boom with cutting fossil fuel dependence and lowering bills. Analysts warn grid connection delays and queues threaten delivery, despite reforms to fast-track ‘first ready’ schemes. Up to £40 bn of shovel-ready projects were prioritised, but significant grid upgrades and investment remain essential to hit the 2030 zero-carbon target.

articles.title: Marks & Spencer launches ‘nutrient dense’ range for people on weight-loss jabs
articles.trailText: New M&S salads, breads, yoghurt bowls and chicken dinners come as more Britons turn to Mounjaro and Wegovy
articles.summary: Marks & Spencer will launch on January 5 a "nutrient dense" product line—salads, breads, yoghurt bowls and chicken dinners—formulated to deliver high micronutrient content per calorie, targeting UK consumers using GLP-1 weight-loss injections (Wegovy, Mounjaro, Saxenda) who experience appetite suppression. Annette Peters, M&S head of food innovation, says the range addresses reduced intake by packing essential nutrients in smaller portions. The move parallels Morrisons’ GLP-1-friendly meals rollout. Retailers are adapting as pharmaceutical firms like Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk expand injectable and emerging pill-based obesity therapies, amid safety and regulatory scrutiny.

articles.title: ‘Be fearful when others are greedy’: Warren Buffett’s sharpest lessons in investing
articles.trailText: As the billionaire retires, he leaves memorable advice from his annual letters that include pithy takes on bubbles, discipline and long-term goals
articles.summary: Over six decades of annual Berkshire Hathaway letters since 1965, Warren Buffett chronicled the transformation of a struggling $25 m textile outfit into a $1 trn empire, imparting core investing doctrines: allocate capital into whole quality businesses at fair prices, pay cash rather than stock, and combine stakes in public firms with outright buyouts. Embrace contrarian timing—“be fearful when others are greedy” and vice versa—while maintaining discipline against ego-driven acquisitions. Harness low-cost insurance float, shun derivative “time bombs,” hoard dry powder to “rush outdoors with washtubs” in downturns, delegate to proven managers, and plan succession thoughtfully.

articles.title: UK consumers still reluctant to spend going into 2026, KPMG survey finds
articles.trailText: Combination of concern about economy and household cost pressures will continue to limit spending, report suggests
articles.summary: UK consumers’ spending outlook remains muted despite stable personal finances, KPMG’s Q4 2025 survey of 3,000 finds. 56% feel secure, yet 58% see the economy worsening (up from 43%), curbing big-ticket and discretionary outlays on cars, furniture and eating out. CPI inflation eased to 3.2% but cumulative rises since 2021 hit 23%. Over-65s are most pessimistic; 35-44 year-olds twice as likely as average to spot improvement. Political uncertainty over delayed budgets and tax leak speculation weighs against upcoming rate cuts and wage boosts. HM Treasury cites income gains, energy-bill relief and wage hikes as offsetting headwinds.

articles.title: Australian cruise ship stuck off PNG ‘detained’ amid investigation into why it ran aground
articles.trailText: Coral Adventurer, separately being investigated for allegedly leaving behind passenger who died on Lizard Island, ordered not to leave PNG waters
articles.summary: Coral Adventurer, carrying 80 passengers and 43 crew, ran aground on a reef 30 km off Lae, Papua New Guinea, and has been detained by PNG authorities over potential hull damage and unseaworthiness. PNG’s National Maritime Safety Authority and Australia’s AMSA, citing Safety Management System failures, and the Australian Transport Safety Bureau have launched probes. No injuries reported. Efforts to refloat the vessel continue under tug assistance. Coral Expeditions maintains initial inspections show no damage. The ship faces a separate ATSB inquiry over a passenger’s death on Lizard Island in October.

articles.title: Trump says he’d ‘love to fire’ Jerome Powell in latest attack on Fed chair
articles.trailText: Trump also repeated false claims about renovation costs for the Fed headquarters during a Monday press conference
articles.summary: At a press conference with Israel’s PM Netanyahu, former President Donald Trump labeled Fed Chair Jerome Powell a “fool,” threatened a “gross incompetence” lawsuit and said he’d “love to fire” him—omitting that he first appointed Powell in 2018. He repeated the false claim that the Federal Reserve HQ renovation cost $4.1bn (actually $2.5bn), contrasted this with his “under-budget, ahead-of-schedule” $400m White House ballroom, and said he’ll announce Powell’s successor in January.

articles.title: Sainsbury’s CEO among business leaders recognised in new year honours
articles.trailText: Simon Roberts, credited with helping to turn around grocer, made CBE along with former BAE Systems boss Ian King
articles.summary: Simon Roberts, Sainsbury’s CEO since 2020, was made CBE for leading the grocer through Covid and the cost-of-living crisis, boosting market share and a 75% stock gain despite controversies over facial-recognition trials, 3,000 job cuts and a £5m+ pay package. A former member of Rishi Sunak’s business council and current IGD president, his honour heads a business sector list also recognising CBEs for Alex Mahon, John Pettigrew, Ian King, Gary Hoffman, Matt Brittin and Mark Reynolds, and OBEs for Pamela Maynard, Jonathan Hague and Peter Higgins.

articles.title: DIY shops enjoy bumper year as UK property market slows
articles.trailText: Paint and sofas sell well as Britons are priced out of moving home or undertaking pricey renovations
articles.summary: Retailers of home improvement products including Kingfisher (B&Q), Topps Tiles, Wickes and DFS saw share price gains of up to 56% in 2025 as UK consumers, squeezed by stagnant house prices and high living costs, opted for DIY over moving or major renovations. Kingfisher jumped 26.5%, Topps Tiles 13%, DFS 23% and Wickes 56%, boosted also by Homebase exit. Halifax data show flat annual house price growth of 0.7% in November, while wage hikes and tax tweaks may drive further DIY spend. ONS data show household-goods spending outpaced wider retail, though 5.1% unemployment and weak building-materials stocks hint at caution.

articles.title: Copper price on track for biggest rise in 15 years amid global shortage fears
articles.trailText: Metal that underpins the renewable energy industry joins silver and gold as a safe haven asset for investors
articles.summary: Copper prices have surged over 35% this year���on track for their biggest annual gain since the post-2008 recovery—driven by electrification demand, US tariff-driven hoarding and fears of mining disruptions. Investors now view copper alongside silver and gold as safe-haven assets amid dollar weakness: silver hit record highs, gold jumped above $4,400/oz. China’s aggressive supply acquisitions—including Jiangxi Copper’s $1.2bn bid for SolGold—have exacerbated tightness. While Goldman Sachs expects near-term supply adequacy, ongoing hoarding, shutdowns at major mines and the long-term renewable-energy transition threaten sustained shortages.

articles.title: Nearly half of Americans believe their financial security is getting worse, poll finds
articles.trailText: Exclusive poll: Americans are also increasingly blaming the White House for their financial woes
articles.summary: A December 11–13 Harris poll of 2,180 US adults finds 45% say their financial security is worsening versus 20% improving; 57% believe the US is in recession, up 11% since February despite strong growth data. Pessimism spans parties: 52% of Democrats, 27% of Republicans and 54% of independents report worse finances; 76% of Democrats, 72% of independents and 55% of Republicans blame the White House for rising prices. Women (62%) and Black/Hispanic voters (66–67%) are most likely to see recession, and 59% of those earning under $50K report declining security versus 37% of those over $100K.

articles.title: Influx of cheap Chinese imports could drive down UK inflation, economists say
articles.trailText: As Trump���s tariffs take effect, Britain is likely alternative destination for cars, telecoms and sound equipment
articles.summary: Economists warn that as US tariffs curb Chinese exports to America, Beijing is redirecting shipments—particularly cars, telecoms and sound equipment—to the UK, driving a 9% year-on-year rise in Chinese exports to Britain. The Bank of England says this trade diversion, alongside sterling appreciation, has slightly disinflationary effects on UK import prices, helping push headline inflation from 3.2% down toward the 2% target by mid-2026. Recent rate cuts and fiscal measures may further ease price pressures, while EU manufacturers and UK steelmakers press for protective responses.

articles.title: UK accounting body to halt remote exams amid AI cheating
articles.trailText: Candidates will have to sit assessments in person unless there are exceptional circumstances, says ACCA
articles.summary: The ACCA, the world’s largest accounting body with 260,000 members, will suspend remote exams from March except in exceptional cases to curb sophisticated AI-enabled cheating. Introduced during Covid, online testing has become too hard to police amid rising misconduct flagged by the FRC in top audit firms, including Big Four players and EY’s $100m ethics exam scandal. FRC probes have levied multimillion-pound fines on Mazars, Grant Thornton and BDO. CEO Helen Brand warns technology has hit a tipping point. The ICAEW still permits some online tests, but most high-stakes assessments ban remote invigilation.

articles.title: Help UK ceramics industry or ‘lose piece of national identity’, government told
articles.trailText: Unions and thinktank urge action to save sector hit by sky-high energy bills, cheap imports and underinvestment
articles.summary: Unions (GMB, TUC) and Green Alliance warn Britain’s centuries-old ceramics sector—home to Staffordshire potteries and 20,000 jobs—faces collapse under sky-high industrial energy costs, cheap imports and chronic underinvestment. They urge urgent government action: gas-price relief, streamlined regulation, anti-dumping measures and targeted capital for decarbonisation and modernisation to protect national identity and strategic capabilities. Ministers point to a “supercharger” energy-price scheme and upcoming industrial competitiveness plan claiming up to 25% electricity cost cuts but face calls to go further, faster.

articles.title: Elon Musk warns of impact of record silver prices before China limits exports
articles.trailText: Metal ‘needed in many industrial processes’, says Tesla boss as supply fears grow over price surge and new rules
articles.summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk cautioned that manufacturers risk severe disruptions as silver prices soared to a record $79/oz amid a precious metals rally driven by expectations of Fed rate cuts in 2026, geopolitical safe-haven demand and looming Chinese export restrictions starting January 1.
