Industrial applications—from electrification and solar panels to EVs and data centers—are depleting inventories. Analysts warn of a structural supply-demand imbalance compounded by a US Commerce probe into mineral imports, while gold, platinum and palladium also hit multidecade peaks.

articles.title: AI is coming for young people’s office jobs. That’s good news for the construction industry | Gene Marks
articles.trailText: More young people are following the money and going into trades like construction where AI can’t easily replace them
articles.summary: Gene Marks argues that AI will eliminate many entry-level white-collar jobs, pushing young workers toward construction trades where automation can’t replace manual skills. The construction industry faces severe labor shortages—92% of firms struggle to fill positions, with estimates needing up to 723,000 new workers annually—and 41% of current workers will retire by 2031. Trade school enrollment rose 23% last year and is projected to grow 7% annually through 2030. As demand rebounds with falling rates and tax incentives, trades will attract more talent seeking stable, well-paid roles.

articles.title: The 2025 US economy – in charts: rising prices, hiring slowdown, rollercoaster growth
articles.trailText: Looking at the government’s own report cards, how did the US fare under the first year of Trumponomics 2.0?
articles.summary: Official data paint a mixed 2025 US economy under Trump: persistent post-pandemic inflation despite tariffs; Fed’s aggressive rate hikes then cautious cuts amid presidential pressure; a stalled labor market with job losses in summer and unemployment peaking at 4.6%; and rollercoaster GDP—from an import-driven Q1 contraction to an unexpected Q3 rebound—averaging ~2% growth. Fragile foundations challenge Trump’s promised boom.

articles.title: Labour must learn lessons from history as automation hits jobs market | Richard Partington
articles.trailText: Productivity is up in retail and other low-paying sectors as tech replaces relatively expensive humans
articles.summary: UK retailers’ adoption of self-service checkouts, electronic labels and AI has driven a modest productivity uptick (1.1% year-on-year) but at the cost of shedding over 350,000 low-paid roles and pushing unemployment to a decade high. Firms blame a £25bn national insurance hike, living wage rises and Labour’s employment bill for rising labour costs, prompting investment surveys to rank automation second only to price hikes. Retail vacancies have slumped 6% in November, reflecting weak consumer demand and online competition. Historical parallels with the Industrial Revolution’s “Engel’s pause” warn of social upheaval unless Labour pairs automation with training, rights protections and managed transitions.

articles.title: Former Wessex Water boss received £170,000 bonus despite ban on performance pay
articles.trailText: Company owners say bonus was unrelated to water business and complied with ban after pollution conviction
articles.summary: Despite a 2024 ban on performance-related bonuses after Wessex Water’s criminal conviction for a 2018 sewage pump failure that killed over 2,000 fish, a £500,000 fine and an £11m penalty for further sewage breaches, former CEO Colin Skellett received a £170,000 bonus in 2025 from parent YTL Utilities (UK), part of his £693,000 total pay. Ofwat ruled the payment legal as it related to his new YTL UK property development role at Brabazon. Lib Dem MP Anna Sabine and others criticize the loophole, demanding tougher transparency measures.

articles.title: US capitalism casts millions of citizens aside, yet Badenoch and Farage still laud it | Phillip Inman
articles.trailText: Rightwing parties want to follow in US’s footsteps of minimal government intervention, but at what cost?
articles.summary: Phillip Inman warns that the US’s low-intervention capitalism—lauded by UK figures like Kemi Badenoch and Nigel Farage—has driven rising poverty, opioid and mental-health crises, high obesity rates and exposed millions to financial crashes it exports globally. Unlike more regulated European economies, US policy shrinks social safety nets, imposes minimal taxation and deregulates markets, blaming individuals for hardship. While Mario Draghi’s proposals for deeper integration and funding a generous state are dismissed by Brexit-aligned conservatives, older voters fuel demand for laissez-faire finance. Inman argues a gradualist approach with stronger regulation builds resilience, protects most citizens and mitigates systemic risks.

articles.title: No longer ‘unloved’: retailers investing more in physical stores, UK data shows
articles.trailText: Knight Frank says shopping centres and food stores lead revival as retail outperforms other commercial property
articles.summary: Knight Frank data shows UK retailers and investors are reallocating capital to physical stores, notably shopping centres and food stores, which delivered 10.2% returns this year versus 9.1% for industrial and 3.2% for offices. Online retail share has plateaued at 26–28% since a 2020 peak. Retail assets saw £5.8bn invested in 2025; vacancy rates fell to 13.5%. Major players Landsec and British Land prioritise retail buys; forecasts predict 9.5% returns in 2026 as constrained supply meets strong demand and high-street trading jumps. Experiences like zipwires in large malls, while smaller centres lag. Frasers Group’s £220m Braehead acquisition and Landsec’s talks for £250m Silverburn deal illustrate strong investor appetite.

articles.title: Shoppers shun UK high streets despite lure of Boxing Day sales
articles.trailText: Footfall in central London down 7.7% on last year but Britain’s retail parks buck trend with 6.9% rise
articles.summary: On Boxing Day 2025 UK footfall fell 0.3% overall vs 2024, with high streets down 2.4% and shopping centres down 2.6%. Central London suffered a 7.7% drop vs 3.4% in other cities, while retail parks rose 6.9% and coastal towns saw a 10% gain. Outer London enjoyed a 4% rise. Poor weather and deep online discounts (up to 50% at M&S, Next) shifted more buyers online. Despite cost-of-living pressures, the average shopper plans to spend £253 (+£17 y/y) in sales projected at £3.6 bn, £1 bn below 2024.

articles.title: AI boom adds more than half a trillion dollars to wealth of US tech barons in 2025
articles.trailText: Elon Musk’s net worth increased by nearly 50% to $645bn with founders of Google and Amazon also seeing huge wealth gains
articles.summary: A surging AI-driven stock boom added over $500bn to the top 10 US tech founders’ net worth, lifting their combined wealth from $1.9tn to $2.5tn by Christmas Eve. Elon Musk led gains with a near 50% jump to $645bn—on track to be the first trillionaire—followed by Google’s Larry Page ($270bn) and Amazon’s Jeff Bezos ($255bn). Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang saw his fortune rise by $41.8bn to $159bn as Nvidia hit a $5tn valuation. Google co-founders Page and Sergey Brin gained $102bn and $92bn, respectively. The wealth concentration spurred calls for tougher wealth taxes amid Bank of England warnings of a sharp market correction. Luxury moguls Bernard Arnault (+$28.5bn) and Amancio Ortega (+$34.3bn) also featured among top gainers.

articles.title: VIP viewing: cinemas bet on luxury bars and beds to usher in a new film era
articles.trailText: Sector reinvests in high-end experiences, from front-row beds to premier pods and business class-style seats with built-in wine coolers
articles.summary: Cinemas like Vue and Odeon are transforming going-to-the-movies by rolling out premium seating—from Ultra Lux recliners with built-in champagne coolers to Luxe pods and VIP beds—to entice audiences back as UK box office nears £1bn in 2025. Everyman’s sofas-and-in-seat dining model sees membership and revenues surge. Operators face post-pandemic attendance drops, streaming rivals and experiential leisure trends, prompting luxury upgrades. Meanwhile, studios including Apple and Amazon MGM plan more blockbusters, signalling a revival of big-screen cinema.

articles.title: Sustainable aviation fuel take-up in UK unlikely to hit 2025 target, data suggests
articles.trailText: Provisional figures in government mandate’s first year show 20% shortfall in levels of SAF supplied for UK flights
articles.summary: Provisional DfT data shows UK sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) uptake reached 1.6% in 2025, missing the government’s 2% mandate by 20% (160m vs 200m of 10bn liters). All SAF so far is recycled cooking oil from Asia. The mandate ramps to 10% by 2030 and 22% by 2040 (including second-generation fuels). Figures are provisional; final data due Nov 2026. The government’s pending SAF bill promises price guarantees; Heathrow offers landing-charge rebates and targets 3% SAF in 2025. Airlines warn of limited supply outside hubs; IATA highlights global stalling.

articles.title: Renewed zeal for Boxing Day sales expected to ring up £3.8bn for retailers
articles.trailText: High streets and online sellers set to benefit as cash-strapped consumers eke out post-Christmas bargains
articles.summary: UK shoppers will spend £3.8bn on Boxing Day, up 2% year-on-year, with online sales driving most growth (+3.4% vs 1.5% for high streets) as bargain-hungry consumers seek deals after a lacklustre Black Friday. Christmas Day online trading now tops £1bn with 23m buyers. Rising inflation means sales value climbs even as volume dips (-0.3% over six weeks). Middle-aged online home goods purchases lead the surge. Pre-Christmas footfall fell 4.5% but recovered marginally on Christmas Eve. Boxing Day remains a key retail moment, now rivalled by 27 December’s Saturday shopping surge.

articles.title: End of shareholder revolt register ‘will help UK firms bury pay controversies’
articles.trailText: Fears for transparency and governance after closure of public log meant to curb ‘abuses and excess’ in boardrooms
articles.summary: After eight years, the Labour government has instructed the Investment Association to shut down the public register of shareholder revolts against executive pay, launched in 2017 to spotlight votes with 20% or more dissent at AGMs. The Treasury says the register “served its purpose” within its deregulation drive, but thinktank High Pay Centre warns closure will reduce transparency, bury controversies, hinder small investors and weaken scrutiny before the 2026 AGM season. Companies and the London Stock Exchange had lobbied for its removal. About 26% of FTSE 100 faced pay rebellions over the past three years, and critics warn the move may cede ground to US markets pursuing deregulation.

articles.title: ‘Nostalgic and calming’: lava lamps are groovy again as sales glow
articles.trailText: The British-made lamps have surged in popularity as younger audiences seek to recapture magic of the 1960s
articles.summary: Nostalgic lava lamps, invented in 1963 by Edward Craven Walker and still handmade by British pioneer Mathmos in Poole, are experiencing a third retail boom. MD Cressida Granger reports record sales and festive stock shortages as Gen-Z and mid-century enthusiasts embrace their analogue, calming glow for mindfulness and décor. The classic Astro and ’90s Telstar models, plus candle-lit designs, are filled by hand—led by Alan Staton, Europe’s sole “lava” filler—and frequently collectable. Limited-edition collaborations with Rankin, Duran Duran, Sabine Marcelis and the Rolling Stones have sold out instantly, fueling a vibrant community of repeat buyers and collectors.

articles.title: Security bosses warn of rise in UK building site thefts by organised crime
articles.trailText: Concerns thefts could accelerate over Christmas shutdown, with tools and equipment increasingly targeted
articles.summary: Security firm Kingdom Systems warns organised crime gangs are increasingly targeting copper cables, tools, telehandlers and diggers on UK construction sites, with thefts set to spike during the two-week Christmas shutdown. Long winter nights and cordless battery grinders aid break-ins, contributing to almost £100m in annual tool losses, according to the National Federation of Builders. The Chartered Institute of Building supports a new bill for harsher sentences, while experts advise improved lighting, centralized storage and temporary CCTV to deter thieves during festive closures.

articles.title: Alexander Wishart obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Banker who began work at 16 and became a director of Harrods Bank in the 1980s
articles.summary: Alexander Wishart (died aged 81) rose from a junior clerk at the National Commercial Bank at 16 to general manager and director of Harrods Bank in the 1980s, and regional managing director of Bank of Beirut in the 1990s. He led Harrods Bank’s rebranding, relocation, computer systems overhaul and bank card launch, then incorporated Beirut Riyad Bank before serving as financial controller at Gorland. A skilled carpenter, he founded Kelly’s Trust for Sick Children after his daughter’s death from leukaemia, raised funds via London marathons and volunteered with Demelza. Survived by wife Myra, two children, four grandchildren and two brothers.

articles.title: BP to sell majority stake in $10bn Castrol business to US investment firm
articles.trailText: Stonepeak will acquire 65% of lubricants business as part of wider plans for the oil company to pay down its debt
articles.summary: BP will sell 65% of its $10bn Castrol lubricants unit to US investor Stonepeak for a valuation of $10.1bn including debt, keeping a 35% joint-venture interest. The deal, due to close late next year, will generate about $6bn to reduce BP’s $26.1bn net debt, part of its $20bn divestment drive pushed by new chair Albert Manifold. Interim CEO Carol Howle says this marks over half of BP’s asset sales. Meg O’Neill succeeds Murray Auchincloss as CEO in April, and BP retains growth exposure via Castrol’s liquid-cooling fluids business, with an option to sell its stake after the two-year lock-up.

articles.title: ‘I’ll never say I’m popping to Jones’s’: shoppers yet to feel love for WH Smith’s high street replacement
articles.trailText: TG Jones took over stores six months ago but consumers have noticed little change or investment
articles.summary: Six months after Modella Capital acquired WH Smith’s 456 high-street outlets and rebranded them TG Jones, shoppers report minimal changes: identical layouts, blue signage and the same mix of books, cards and stationery. Only 14 stores have been refitted so far; 24 closures have happened since June. Modella plans 500 outlets by 2027, adding post offices and Hobbycraft, Claire’s and Toys R Us sections, but consumers still prefer supermarkets, online rivals or specialist chains. A full restructure is slated for July 2026 once a no-change clause expires amid pressure from trading struggles and rising costs.

articles.title: Bitcoin’s buzz is gone. Investors chose real gold in 2025 | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Gold is up 70% while the cryptocurrency is down 6% after it failed to bounce back from a rapid October sell-off
articles.summary: Gold rose 70% in 2025 while bitcoin slid 6%, defying its 'digital gold' thesis despite geopolitical tensions, high US deficits and AI-driven enthusiasm. Mainstream institutional adoption—via crypto ETFs and regulatory proposals—may have dampened its revolutionary appeal. A sharp October sell-off, triggered by leveraged liquidations amid Trump tariff fears, saw bitcoin fall from $126,000 to $87,000 and the broader market lose $1 trn, with gold and stocks rebounding. Deutsche Bank attributes the slump to risk-off sentiment, Fed hawkishness, weaker-than-expected regulation, thin liquidity, institutional outflows and profit-taking. Investors ultimately favoured real gold and silver as defensive hedges, highlighting bitcoin’s diminished speculative buzz and uncertain market depth.

articles.title: Bet365 boss receives at least £280m in pay and dividends despite profit slump
articles.trailText: Denise Coates’s gambling empire reports turnover of £4bn in year to March 2025, up from £3.7bn
articles.summary: Denise Coates, Bet365’s billionaire CEO, received £280m in 2025 (a £104m salary plus half of a £353.6m dividend) despite pre-tax profits plunging from £627m to £349m on £4bn turnover. Costs rose £325m as the firm exited China (incurring £59m restructuring) and expanded in the US and South America, entering five new US states. Since founding in Stoke she’s drawn over £2.5bn. Her payout, nearly double FTSE 100 CEO norms, comes with full UK taxation and follows a £130m donation to her foundation. Accounts omit discussion of a possible £9bn sale.

articles.title: CDs return to Christmas shopping lists as gen Z embrace ‘retro renaissance’
articles.trailText: Demand for CD players rises 74% this year amid deluxe releases from artists such as Taylor Swift and Pink Floyd
articles.summary: CD players and compact discs are experiencing a festive resurgence driven by 90s nostalgia and deluxe releases from Taylor Swift, Pink Floyd and others. John Lewis reports a 74% rise in CD player sales. While streaming dominates, physical formats are valued for artwork, sound quality and artist support. UK CD sales fell from 162m in 2004 to 10.5m in 2024 but orders at Key Production Group rose 15%. Gen Z now buy more CDs than older generations, half of Gen Alpha listen via physical media. Second-hand classics from Abba, Adele and Oasis top reseller charts.

articles.title: US economy grew strongly in third quarter, GDP report says
articles.trailText: GDP rose at an annualized rate of 4.3% over the third quarter, far higher than expected
articles.summary: US GDP expanded at a 4.3% annualized rate in Q3—the fastest pace in two years—driven by consumer spending, exports and government outlays despite weaker investment. Economists had forecast 3.2% growth after a 3.8% Q2 gain. The report, delayed by the October–November shutdown, arrives amid sliding consumer sentiment, AI-fueled business investment and uncertainty over Trump’s tariffs, which he claims boost results. Persistently high inflation and a cooling labor market complicate the Fed’s policy path as markets weigh further rate cuts. After a Q1 contraction amid tariff-driven import surges, growth rebounded thanks to AI investments and strong consumption.

articles.title: Ryanair fined €256m over ‘abusive strategy’ to limit ticket sales by online travel agencies
articles.trailText: Italy’s competition authority says Irish airline implemented technical obstacles to force sales through its own website
articles.summary: Italy’s competition authority fined Ryanair €256m for abusing its dominant market position between April 2023 and April 2025 by deploying technical obstacles—facial recognition, blocked payments and mass deletions of agency accounts—to thwart OTAs such as Booking.com, Kiwi and Kayak from selling bundled itineraries and forcing direct bookings via ryanair.com. CEO Michael O’Leary, who branded travel agents as “pirates,” has vowed to appeal the “legally flawed” ruling. Although agency sales dipped, Ryanair still climbed to a record €31bn valuation, second only to Delta.

articles.title: Four-day week may be considered a sign of failure, England councils told
articles.trailText: Local government secretary writes to town halls warning them against ‘part-time work for full-time pay’
articles.summary: Local government secretary Steve Reed told all English councils that adopting a four-day week could count as “part-time work for full-time pay” and trigger government intervention under updated best value guidance. Twenty-five councils have debated the model and South Cambridgeshire has piloted it; Reed warned its performance on rent collection and repairs slipped under the policy. Fears of failure indicators contrast with advocates like the 4 Day Week Foundation, which argues a 32-hour week boosts efficiency and morale.

articles.title: Tesla’s EU sales slump continues as Chinese rivals thrive
articles.trailText: Elon Musk’s brand sold 12,130 new cars across the EU last month, down from 18,430 in November 2024
articles.summary: In November Tesla registered 12,130 new cars across the EU, down 34% from 18,430 in November 2024, cutting its market share from 2.1% to 1.4%. Chinese rivals surged: BYD’s registrations nearly tripled to 42,500 and SAIC’s MG rose 26% to 217,000. Hybrids reached 44% of sales amid European OEM lobbying, prompting the EU to allow 10% ICE sales post-2035. Pure EV share grew to 18.8% (2.3m units). Tesla’s slump coincides with Musk’s political interventions; his net worth tops $647bn, with Tesla valued at $1.5tn.

articles.title: ‘We’ve seen it decimate areas’: Somerset town’s traders oppose parking charges
articles.trailText: Traders on Clevedon’s Hill Road say they fear the proposals could hasten the decline of independent retail as councils across Britain look to raise income by forcing shoppers to pay to park
articles.summary: On Clevedon’s Hill Road in Somerset, independent traders are campaigning against North Somerset council’s plan to introduce on-street parking charges—30 minutes free, then £1.50 for an hour, up to £3 for three hours. They warn fees will deter shoppers, cut footfall and threaten livelihoods, citing a petition of over 3,300 signatures and the summer trial in Nailsea. Bookshop, gallery and bridal store owners fear customers will choose free out-of-town or online alternatives. Conservatives and the town council may launch a legal challenge. The council argues charges will fund well-maintained facilities and support local economies, but no implementation date is set.

articles.title: Larry Ellison gives personal guarantee for Paramount takeover of Warner Bros Discovery
articles.trailText: WBD had urged shareholders to reject $108.4bn hostile takeover bid from Paramount, which is controlled by the Ellisons, following $82.7bn Netflix deal
articles.summary: Tech billionaire Larry Ellison has agreed to personally backstop $40.4bn in equity financing for Paramount Skydance’s $108.4bn hostile bid for Warner Bros Discovery, after WBD urged shareholders to reject the offer in favor of Netflix’s $82.7bn studios-and-HBO deal. WBD’s board deemed Paramount’s all-cash $30/share proposal “inadequate” and risky. Paramount CEO David Ellison insists his full-company bid—including CNN, Cartoon Network and Discovery—delivers greater content production and consumer choice, and maintains it outvalues Netflix’s narrower takeover. Earlier backers included Affinity Partners, Saudi Arabia’s PIF and Qatar’s QIA.

articles.title: UK consumers saving less as taxes squeeze incomes, data shows
articles.trailText: ONS finds households’ savings ratio has dropped to lowest rate for more than a year across third quarter
articles.summary: ONS data shows British households’ saving ratio fell by 0.7pp to 9.5% in Q3 – the lowest in over a year – as higher income and wealth taxes drove real disposable income down 0.8%. Pre‐budget uncertainty and a freeze on personal tax thresholds for three more years have squeezed spending, while ONS also revised Q3 GDP growth down to 0.1%. Businesses cite a £25 bn NIC rise and fiscal doubts for weak momentum. A 25bp BoE rate cut to 3.75% follows easing inflation, and economists expect stronger Q1 spending now income tax hikes are off the table.

articles.title: Bosses at City & Guilds handed million-pound bonuses after training firm is privatised
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Executives at body that trained chef Jamie Oliver awarded pay rises and bonuses after sale to private firm – as hundreds of jobs may be offshored
articles.summary: After privatising City & Guilds’ commercial arm and selling it to Greek firm PeopleCert in October, the charity’s chief executive Kirstie Donnelly received a £1.7m bonus and finance director Abid Ismail £1.2m, alongside pay rises—Donnelly’s salary now about £430,000, Ismail’s £300,000. The 147-year-old training and qualifications provider, founded in 1878 and serving 1.1m learners annually, is pursuing £22m of cost savings, including £13m in personnel cuts via job offshoring to Greece and non-replacement of UK leavers. The sale brought its charity owner £180-200m to underwrite future grants, while the newly private C&G retains its historic royal charter brand.

articles.title: US farmers say Trump’s $12bn package not enough to undo damage from tariffs
articles.trailText: Thousands of farms set to go bankrupt as grain farmers in particular hit by trade disruptions caused by price hikes
articles.summary: Despite Trump’s $12 billion aid—$11 billion for row-crop farmers—US producers face steep losses and debt. Grain growers, especially soybean farmers hit by tariff-fueled trade disruptions with China, lost $34.6 billion this year and risk over 1,000 farm bankruptcies. A one-time $50/acre payment does little to cover rising input costs and low crop prices. Farmers are altering planting plans under lender pressure and pin hopes on renewed Chinese purchases and expanded biofuel mandates under the Renewable Fuels Standard to stabilize incomes.

articles.title: Bourbon maker Jim Beam stops production at Kentucky site for 2026
articles.trailText: Whiskey brand, owned by Japanese drinks group Suntory, to close main distillery amid tariff uncertainty
articles.summary: Jim Beam’s owner Suntory will halt production at its Clermont, Kentucky distillery throughout 2026 to fund site upgrades amid falling demand and US tariff uncertainty. With warehouses holding a record 16m barrels and looming $75m in ageing-barrel taxes, the brand will keep its other Kentucky distillery, bottling and visitor center open and is negotiating workforce redeployment with unions. The pause reflects broader US spirits industry strains from Trump-era tariffs and declining alcohol consumption.

articles.title: Toy touts, random spins and frantic bidding: the murky side of live auction site Whatnot
articles.trailText: Quickfire lots help business hit $11.5bn, but critics point to its gambling-style features and popularity with ‘scalpers’
articles.summary: Live-auction app Whatnot, valued at $11.5bn after a 2025 funding round, fuses eBay-style listings with streamer-hosted, seconds-long bids and random “break” spins akin to blind boxes. Its fast-paced, variable-reward format has spurred addiction warnings—users report six-figure debts and mental-health harms—and drawn expert comparisons to gambling. Meanwhile, scalpers like Crep Chief Notify are cornering scarce Pokémon cards and hot toys, flipping stock at up to 250% mark-ups and stoking parent outrage over inflated secondary-market prices.

articles.title: UK economy entering 2026 amid sharp private sector downturn, says CBI
articles.trailText: Business lobby survey finds firms ‘put brakes on key spending decisions’ before autumn budget
articles.summary: CBI survey of 900+ firms between 24 Nov and 11 Dec finds UK private sector output set to decline in Q4 2025, as businesses delayed investment and hiring ahead of the autumn budget. Adzuna reports five consecutive months of falling vacancies, down 6.4% month-on-month and 15% year-on-year in November, alongside a 5.1% unemployment rate. Graduate roles plunged 45% annually, partly due to AI cuts. Yet advertised salaries rose 7.7%, led by a 12.7% gain in IT. Firms call on Labour to ease energy costs and simplify taxation to boost growth.

articles.title: Sir Alec Reed obituary
articles.trailText: Employment agency founder and philanthropist who raised hundreds of millions of pounds for charity
articles.summary: Sir Alec Reed (1934–2025) built Reed, one of the UK’s largest private recruitment firms, and pioneered online job ads in 1995. Through his Reed Foundation and Big Give platform he raised a record £44.7 m in Christmas 2024 match-funding—aiming for £1 bn by 2030. Knighted in 2011, he endowed 18% of Reed, launched ARC, Ethiopiaid and women’s rehabilitation charities, championed academy schools, and supported the arts. An “ideas man” who linked business success with philanthropy, Reed’s legacy spans employment, education and fundraising innovation.

articles.title: Top economists call for halt to Sri Lanka debt repayments after Cyclone Ditwah
articles.trailText: Group of 120 experts including Joseph Stiglitz urge fresh debt restructuring plan given scale of destruction
articles.summary: A coalition of 120 leading economists, including Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz, Jayati Ghosh, Thomas Piketty, Martín Guzmán and Kate Raworth, urges suspension and fresh restructuring of Sri Lanka’s $9 billion external debt after Cyclone Ditwah killed over 600 and destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes. With pre-cyclone repayments equal to 25% of government revenues and new IMF rapid-financing adding short-term liabilities, they warn fiscal space is exhausted. Debt Justice research shows creditors still set to earn 40% more profit than US bonds. They demand new terms for sustainable post-disaster recovery and international relief.

articles.title: There are reasons to be cheerful about UK plc in 2026. Here are four | Heather Stewart
articles.trailText: From better prospects for consumer spending to tentative signs of improving productivity, the doom and gloom of 2025 could be behind us
articles.summary: After 2025’s weak growth, sticky inflation and fiscal theatrics, four developments suggest a brighter 2026 for the UK. Rachel Reeves’s doubled fiscal headroom and a subdued spring statement should prevent another tax-and-spend saga. December’s flash PMI rose to 52.1, signalling expanding private-sector activity and firmer hiring sentiment. Bank of England rate cuts, a £150 energy rebate and above-average household savings could support consumer spending. Finally, productivity per worker climbed 1% in H1 2025—potentially from AI-driven gains and investment spurred by higher labour costs—lifting growth prospects.

articles.title: UK supermarkets turn to European turkeys as avian flu hits supply
articles.trailText: Asda, Lidl and Morrisons understood to be stocking imported branded turkeys to meet Christmas demand
articles.summary: Asda, Lidl and Morrisons are importing branded turkeys from mainland Europe (Bernard Matthews from Poland, Cherrywood crowns, Gressingham frozen) to offset a slump in UK output after an avian flu surge (70 confirmed cases, over 300,000 birds culled) squeezed festive supply. Non-British birds will account for under 10% of sales. Aldi is believed to be doing likewise, while Co-op, M&S, Sainsbury’s and Tesco stick to 100% British sourcing. The British Poultry Council warns smaller retailers may face shortages or higher prices; NFU highlights early housing rules and local sourcing to safeguard welfare and availability.

articles.title: ‘Bills keep going higher’: community ‘warm spaces’ on the rise in the UK
articles.trailText: As places such as Walworth Living Room step in to help people in need, charities lament lack of government help
articles.summary: Walworth Living Room, one of 50 council-registered ‘warm spaces’ in Southwark, offers free meals, activities and heated shelter to residents like Fatma Mustafa and cancer patient Nazma Khanom, who save on energy and groceries and find social support. Since 2022, the UK’s Warm Welcome Campaign reports hubs rose from 4,000 to almost 6,000, mirroring food bank growth. Volunteers warn these stopgaps mask deep poverty and demand government action, not charities. Pembroke House director Mike Wilson says such spaces foster community cohesion and aim to influence systemic policy solutions even as bills climb 44% since 2021.

articles.title: ‘The anxiety never disappears’: Monmouth businesses recover from severe flooding
articles.trailText: Restaurants, bars and shops are happy to be back after Storm Claudia – but there are fears for the future
articles.summary: After Storm Claudia’s floods breached Monmouth’s Monnow and Wye rivers, nearly 120 shops and 200 homes were inundated, devastating independents like Bar 125, which lost equipment, stock and over 1,200 Christmas bookings. Many traders raced to clear debris and reopen—some within days—despite insurance exclusions for flood damage and lost trade. Larger groups such as Loungers could deploy in-house teams, but smaller venues face lost wages, rent and repair bills. Council relief grants and suspended rates offer limited aid. Lingering anxiety over rising premiums and more frequent extreme events underscores the town’s vulnerability.

articles.title: Christmas ads put on a diet as UK ban on TV junk food advertising bites
articles.trailText: Gone are shots of puddings and sweets as advertisers try to market other foods to stay within rules coming into force on 5 January
articles.summary: UK retailers like Tesco, Waitrose, M&S and Asda have trimmed Christmas ads to comply with a January ban on HFSS food advertising before 9pm. New Ofcom rules, voluntarily adopted from October, bar sugary puddings, sweets and many “less healthy” products, prompting brands to pivot to fruit, veg and brand-only storytelling. Complex nutrient profiling and 13 banned categories—with odd exceptions for bacon or pastries—make compliance a creative challenge. Critics warn heavy reformulation and caveats undermine the childhood obesity goal, while food groups shift spend to outdoor and brand-only pre-watershed campaigns.

articles.title: Jim Ratcliffe chemical firms received up to £70m of UK state aid in last four years
articles.trailText: The government is preparing a £50m bailout for Ineos’s Grangemouth plant, after Jim Ratcliffe asked for help in October
articles.summary: Ineos, owned by billionaire Jim Ratcliffe, has received £28m–£70m in UK state aid since August 2022—£16m–£38m in the past year—and secured a £50m government bailout plus a £75m loan guarantee for its Grangemouth ethylene plant. Facing surging energy costs post-Ukraine invasion, Grangemouth is the UK’s last ethylene producer. Ratcliffe, worth $14.5bn, criticized carbon taxes as “idiotic,” arguing they and high energy costs risk deindustrialisation while Ineos invests £30m itself and claims aid matched strict criteria. Previous support included tax breaks tied to energy and emissions reductions.

articles.title: Donald Trump promised a new ‘golden age’ for the US economy. Where is it?
articles.trailText: Most Americans have yet to see this boom – but they’ve certainly heard a lot about it from the president
articles.summary: After ten months of Trump’s second term, his promised “golden age” remains elusive: monthly job gains tumbled to 55,000 vs 168,000 in 2024, unemployment rose to 4.6%, and manufacturing jobs barely budged. Tariffs soared from 2.4% to 16.8%, stoking price pressures as CPI held at 2.7% in November despite claims of fast declines. Recent tariff cuts on food items and $12 billion in farm aid, plus talked stimulus checks, aim to ease pains. Economists foresee only 2% GDP growth in 2025-26, far short of the administration’s lofty boom projections. Trump vows turnaround by early 2026, but advisers and Nobel economists call prospects dim.

articles.title: Retailers hope ‘panic weekend’ will bring Christmas cheer to UK sales
articles.trailText: Experts forecast spending will be more than 12% up on same period in 2024 after lucklustre figures so far
articles.summary: UK retailers are banking on a late surge as households are forecast to spend £3.4bn over the weekend, up 12% year-on-year, with nearly 50m shopping trips. ‘Super Saturday’ (20 December) could see 26.5m shoppers splurging £1.75bn. After a muted run to Christmas—cool budgets, cautious post-Budget sentiment and a mild autumn—consumers have held off, eyeing last-minute bargains from high-street and discounters: toy discounts up to 60%, 5p festive veg and £2.50/kg turkeys for Clubcard members. With cut-off dates squeezing online delivery, the run-up favors in-store shopping amid mixed signals on consumer confidence.

articles.title: Was 2025 the year that business retreated from net zero?
articles.trailText: From retailers to banks, carmakers to councils, the bold pledges for carbon-neutral economies are being watered down or scrapped
articles.summary: By late 2025, the net zero drive is losing ground: Trump’s pro-fossil fuel agenda prompted US, UK and EU regulators to weaken EV mandates, Ford wrote down $19.5 bn and scrapped EV models, while Airbus and Boeing delayed green aviation. BP and Shell shifted back to oil and gas, and major banks including JPMorgan and HSBC exited the UN’s Net-Zero Banking Alliance. Retailers like Morrisons deferred carbon neutrality to 2050, and Reform-led UK councils rescinded local targets. Counterbalancing this retreat, China’s renewables surged past coal, global clean-energy investment hit $2 trn annually, and Labour vows a carbon-free UK grid by 2030.

articles.title: Why is Truth Social owner Trump Media merging with a fusion energy firm?
articles.trailText: What we know about the deal with TAE Technologies so far – from why it is happening to what fusion energy is
articles.summary: Trump Media & Technology Group, owner of Truth Social, is merging with fusion energy firm TAE Technologies in a $6bn deal to build the world’s first utility-scale fusion power plant. The combined entity—co-led by Devin Nunes and TAE CEO Michl Binderbauer—will be split 50/50 between shareholders and governed by a nine-member board including Donald Trump. Trump Media will inject $300m to accelerate TAE’s fusion development amid rising demand for clean power to fuel AI datacenters. The deal marks Trump’s diversification beyond its modest Truth Social user base and mounting losses, leveraging new energy deregulation and national‐security support for fusion. Commercial fusion remains unproven.

articles.title: Independent businesses: have your online sales been affected by the rise of AI?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from independent retailers about how changes to online searches has affected them. We’d also like to find out from customers about how easy it is to track down independent retailers
articles.summary: Independent retailers increasingly rely on online visibility, but AI-driven search changes – from Google’s AI Overview summaries to LLM chatbots like ChatGPT and Gemini – may be reshaping customer discovery. The Guardian invites small-business owners to report recent shifts in organic traffic and online sales: are they seeing new opportunities or facing challenges? What strategies and innovations are they adopting to stand out? The survey also seeks customer insights: has it become harder to find independent shops or relevant products online amid AI-powered search summaries?

articles.title: Former Yodel owner probably forged mother’s signature in takeover bid, judge rules
articles.trailText: ‘Extraordinary’ high court ruling covers Jacob Corlett’s attempt to seize back control of parcel delivery firm
articles.summary: Mr Justice Fancourt ruled that Jacob Corlett, the 31-year-old entrepreneur who acquired the distressed parcel firm Yodel for £1 in January 2024 and sold it to Judge Logistics Ltd in June ahead of its £106m InPost takeover, probably forged his mother Tamara Gregory’s initials on warrant documents to reclaim control. Forensic handwriting experts found multi-pen inconsistencies and signs of forgery. The judge condemned Corlett’s breach of fiduciary duty, misrepresentation and disregard for creditors including HMRC. InPost’s CEO hailed the ruling as vindication and warned of further legal action.

articles.title: WH Smith tries to recover bonuses from ex-bosses as watchdog investigates accounting error
articles.trailText: Retailer targets £7m in bonuses as FCA examines scandal in North American arm
articles.summary: WH Smith will apply malus and clawback to recoup up to £7m in bonuses paid to ex-CEO Carl Cowling (£4m) and ex-FD Robert Moorhead (£3m) after restating 2023–24 profits for a North America supplier-income and stock-provision error that wiped £600m off market value. The FCA has launched a formal probe into listing and disclosure breaches. Interim CEO Andrew Harrison, citing a Deloitte review blaming a target-led culture, is overhauling governance, controls and training, exiting ~40 unprofitable fashion/specialty and up to 25 InMotion stores, and eyeing franchise expansions. FY Aug 2025 pre-tax profit fell to £16m (after £92m one-offs) on £1.5bn sales; FY 26 underlying profit is guided at £100–115m.

articles.title: Rail accident investigators issue warning over sensors on landslide monitors
articles.trailText: Inquiry into recent Avanti West Coast train derailment in Cumbria finds sensors may not work if landslips happen quickly
articles.summary: Accident investigators warn landslide sensors on railways may fail in sudden earth movements and when buried, after an Avanti West Coast derailment near Shap, Cumbria, on Nov 3 derailed by debris at 83 mph. Sensors detected minor shifts hours earlier but remained below alert thresholds; during the main slip, they toppled too fast and wireless signals were lost. The RAIB issued an urgent safety warning requesting Network Rail to assess and mitigate risks, especially in extreme weather. Network Rail pledges to implement advice, investing £100 m over four years in earthwork monitoring and drainage improvements amid rising climate-driven rainfall.

articles.title: Retail sales unexpectedly fall in Great Britain in run-up to Christmas
articles.trailText: Shoppers held back on Black Friday spending in November and budget uncertainty hit consumer confidence
articles.summary: Great Britain’s retail sales fell 0.1% month-on-month in November—against the 0.4% rise economists expected—after weaker-than-usual Black Friday discounts and pre-Budget uncertainty curbed spending, the ONS reports. Online/non-store sales plunged 2.9%, supermarkets declined for a fourth straight month (-0.5%), while non-food stores eked out a 1% gain. This marks two consecutive months of declines in the critical “golden quarter.” Analysts blame tax-hike speculation and poor weather, though a small uptick in December consumer confidence could spur a last-minute Christmas shopping boost. ONS also marginally revised down October and September figures.

articles.title: UK borrowed more than expected in November amid pre-budget pressure
articles.trailText: ONS figures show public sector net borrowing was £11.7bn – £1.9bn less than in same month last year
articles.summary: UK public sector net borrowing hit £11.7bn in November—above the City’s £10bn forecast but £1.9bn below last year, marking its lowest November since 2019. Yet fiscal-year-to-November borrowing rose to £132.3bn, £10bn higher than 2024 and second only to pandemic levels. Higher tax and national insurance receipts helped, though elevated spending—on social benefits, winter fuel payments and Hinkley Point C—and a sixth Bank of England rate cut underscore persistent economic strains. Analysts warn this overshoot may imperil OBR forecasts, heightening fiscal scrutiny despite Chancellor Reeves boosting headroom to £22bn with her autumn budget.

articles.title: MPs to question Vodafone on ‘unjust’ treatment of store franchise owners
articles.trailText: Parliamentary scrutiny follows claims that commercial agreements put the mental health of shopkeepers at risk
articles.summary: MPs will question Vodafone over allegations of “unjust” treatment of its store franchise owners after reports of suicides and mental health crises linked to commission cuts, punitive fines and coerced loans. A group of 62 former franchisees sued in 2024, accusing Vodafone of unjust enrichment and acting in bad faith by slashing fees in 2020. Sir John Hayes, Luke Akehurst and Richard Tice will meet Vodafone on January 21 to demand accountability and explore potential legal reforms to correct power imbalances in franchise agreements. Vodafone says it has offered settlements, apologises for any distress and remains open to further talks.

articles.title: BP opts for culture shock with new CEO appointment, but the timing is odd
articles.trailText: The decision to replace Murray Auchincloss with Woodside’s Meg O’Neill is puzzling on at least two counts
articles.summary: BP’s board has ousted CEO Murray Auchincloss—architect of last February’s oil-and-gas reset—even as shares rose 10% this year, replacing him with Meg O’Neill, Woodside Energy’s American boss and BP’s first external hire. The timing puzzles investors given Auchincloss’s success in meeting activist demands and a Brazilian find. O’Neill’s Woodside tenure delivered hefty dividends but underperformed peers on share price. Tasked with accelerating a “simpler, leaner, more profitable” strategy amid high debt, disposals of Castrol and Lightsource stakes, she joins in April to set tough targets and drive cost cuts.

articles.title: ‘We’ve future-proofed’: how UK’s biggest car factory upgraded for EV revolution
articles.trailText: Nissan builds in capability to go fully electric at Sunderland plant amid scaling back of transition targets across Europe
articles.summary: At its Sunderland plant—Britain’s biggest car factory—Nissan installed a £450m battery "marriage station", robots and modular lines to assemble 3rd-gen Leaf EVs alongside Qashqai and Juke hybrids, enabling 600k-vehicle annual capacity. Yet global EV rollouts have slowed: the EU watered down its 2035 ICE ban, Nissan shelved its 2030 Europe-only EV pledge and won £162m in UK state aid to secure future investment. Adjacent AESC battery plant now runs one of four lines, highlighting demand-capacity mismatch amid strategic flexibility for hybrids, EVs or third-party contract builds.

articles.title: Meg O’Neill: ‘hard-nosed’ outsider who will head BP’s pivot away from green energy
articles.trailText: First female appointment to a major oil company has faced fierce resistance from climate activists as boss of Woodside
articles.summary: Meg O’Neill, 55, from Boulder, Colorado, becomes BP’s third CEO in five years and its first female outsider in that role. She joins from Woodside where in four years she doubled fossil output via the BHP merger and steered the company through the energy crisis. A 23-year ExxonMobil veteran and former adviser to Rex Tillerson, O’Neill earned $7.45m last year. Known as a hard-nosed straight-talker, she plans to cut green investments and ramp up oil and gas production amid activist backlash.

articles.title: What the UK interest rate cut means for you, from mortgage deals to savings rates
articles.trailText: Fourth cut this year is good news for homebuyers and those due to remortgage, but returns on easy-access savings accounts could drop
articles.summary: The Bank of England’s fourth cut of 2025—from 4% to 3.75%—leaves most fixed-rate mortgages (7.2m, 86%) unchanged but reduces costs for 533k tracker borrowers (saving ~£29/month) and, if passed on, 509k SVR customers (saving ~£13.88/month). Easy-access savings yields may dip from a 2.56% average, though top accounts still pay around 4.5% and one-year fixes just over that. New two-year fixed rates have slid to about 4.82% on average and could fall below 3% by spring, aiding buyers and remortgagers, while five-year fixes average 4.9%, with best deals near 3.75%.

articles.title: German prosecutors bring charges against Greensill officials over role in bank’s collapse
articles.trailText: Bremen lawyers say three unnamed people charged with crimes relating to bankruptcy and misrepresentation of bank’s finances
articles.summary: German prosecutors in Bremen have charged three former Greensill Bank officials—two ex-management board members and one supervisory board member—with bankruptcy offenses and misrepresenting finances linked to a €2.2 billion 2019 refinancing of Gupta Family Group steel plants. They allege the trio bypassed banking rules by portraying risky GFG loans as a compliant, low-risk receivables purchase programme, triggering Greensill Bank’s 2021 collapse. Lex Greensill isn’t among the accused. The case deepens legal fallout, following UK Serious Fraud Office probes into related GFG financing and the loss of Sanjeev Gupta’s metals units.

articles.title: Narrow Bank of England vote puts end of interest rate-cutting cycle in sight
articles.trailText: Another reduction expected next year but monetary policy committee is deeply divided over inflation prospects
articles.summary: On December 18 the Bank of England’s nine-member Monetary Policy Committee voted 5–4 to cut its base rate from 4% to 3.75%, marking the sixth reduction since last August. Governor Andrew Bailey said rates remain on a gradual downward path, but the slim majority underscores a split: one side cites slowing inflation (3.2% in November), weak growth and rising unemployment—bolstered by Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s budget measures set to shave 0.5 pp off inflation from Q2 2026—as justification for further cuts; the other fears elevated wage growth (~3.5%) and future fiscal pressures could reignite inflation, hinting this easing cycle’s endpoint may be near.

articles.title: Leeds £2.5bn tram scheme delayed to late 2030s after government review
articles.trailText: Business case must be submitted for mass transit system with lines connecting Leeds and Bradford before work continues
articles.summary: Following a government review by Nista, the £2.5bn West Yorkshire mass transit tram scheme linking Leeds and Bradford will now open in the late 2030s—two to three years later than planned. Mayor Tracy Brabin pledged to “drive this tram” by 2039, citing integrated bus-tram networks and £2.1bn transport funding (2027-32). Rail minister Peter Hendy endorsed a robust business-case-first approach, while Conservatives warned delays risk cancellation. Early funding (£200m) and public consultation on 10 routes underpin efforts to revive light rail since 1959’s tram axe. Previous Supertram (2005) and trolleybus (2016) plans were rejected.

articles.title: US prices continued to rise despite Trump claims they are ‘rapidly’ falling
articles.trailText: Longest federal government shutdown meant data was only collected for second half of November
articles.summary: US consumer prices climbed 2.7% year-on-year in November, short of forecasts and slower than 3% in September, amid data gaps from the record federal shutdown. President Trump’s claim that inflation was “rapidly” falling contrasts with stubborn price growth and rising unemployment, which hit 4.6% in November even as 64,000 jobs were added. Economists blame Trump-era tariffs for higher costs, and polls show waning approval on prices. The Fed, having cut rates thrice, signaled a pause to balance its 2% inflation target with labor-market pressures and will scrutinize shutdown-impacted data.

articles.title: US activist investor urges Whitbread review after budget tax changes
articles.trailText: Corvex says Premier Inn owner should rethink strategy as company braces for business rate changes next year
articles.summary: US hedge fund Corvex, now Whitbread’s second-largest shareholder with a 6.05% stake, has urged the Premier Inn owner to launch a strategic review after Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s autumn budget rateable value reforms, which are set to cost the FTSE 100 group up to £50m next year. Corvex flagged undervalued assets—UK leaseholds, German hotels and developments—and called for a reassessment of Whitbread’s £3.5bn five-year capital plan and a board seat. Whitbread says it remains committed to its long-term strategy while exploring profit and margin-boosting options amid analyst downgrades forecasting pre-tax hits of £30m–£140m over three years.

articles.title: Bank of England cuts interest rates to 3.75% in pre-Christmas boost for struggling economy
articles.trailText: Rate-setters back quarter-point cut after steep fall in inflation and weak economic data but vote remained close
articles.summary: The Bank of England’s Monetary Policy Committee voted 5–4 to cut its base rate by 25bp to 3.75%, the sixth reduction since Labour’s election, citing a fall in inflation to 3.2% and weak economic data. While governor Andrew Bailey and three peers view inflation nearing the 2% target in Q1 2026, four dissenters, led by chief economist Clare Lombardelli, warn of entrenched services-sector price pressures and elevated wage growth. Chancellor Rachel Reeves welcomed the cut, citing budget measures expected to shave 0.5p.p. off inflation in early 2026. TUC’s Paul Nowak urged further cuts amid stagnant GDP, which contracted 0.1% in October and is set to stall late 2025.

articles.title: Waterstones and Barnes & Noble owner looks to list booksellers on stock market
articles.trailText: US hedge fund Elliott thought to prefer IPO in London over New York, which could be welcome boost to UK stock market
articles.summary: Elliott Investment Management, owner of UK’s Waterstones and US’s Barnes & Noble, is preparing an IPO for the combined bookseller group, reportedly favoring London to boost the UK stock market. While adviser talks are in early stages and no final decision is made, a listing is unlikely before late 2025 due to the April fiscal year-end. CEO James Daunt has driven growth—over 300 UK and 600 US stores—resisting Amazon and acquiring rivals. Elliott, which bought Waterstones in 2018 and Barnes & Noble in 2019, is known for activist investments and regards a share sale as ‘inevitable’.

articles.title: BP names Meg O’Neill as new CEO after incumbent ousted
articles.trailText: O’Neill, who has led Woodside Energy since 2021, will be oil and gas company’s first female chief executive
articles.summary: BP has named Meg O’Neill, former ExxonMobil executive and Woodside Energy CEO since 2021, as its new chief executive effective April, ousting Murray Auchincloss less than two years into his tenure. O’Neill is BP’s first female CEO in its 116-year history and the first outsider to lead any of the world’s top five oil majors. Interim CEO Carol Howle will run the firm until April. Backed by new chair Albert Manifold and activist investor Elliott Management, the move signals a pivot from BP’s green agenda back to traditional oil and gas growth after underperformance. Under O’Neill, Woodside merged with BHP’s petroleum arm to become a $40 billion producer and doubled output.

articles.title: UK government plays down reports of plan to bring EV sales target review forward
articles.trailText: Though minister had said ZEV mandate review would be completed ‘quickly as we can’, government confirms it won’t be published until 2027
articles.summary: The UK government has denied rushing a review of its zero-emission vehicle (ZEV) sales targets, stating preparatory work begins next year but the full review will be published in early 2027. Industry minister Chris McDonald had said the review would start “as quickly as we can” amid lobbying from carmakers, who argue current ZEV mandates and fines are unsustainable and have secured flexibilities to earn hybrid credits. The government maintained its ban on new petrol and diesel cars by 2035, even as the EU dilutes its own phaseout to 90% zero-emission production. McDonald visited Nissan’s Sunderland plant, where the new Leaf launch underlines the sector’s EV transition.

articles.title: Ineos chemicals plant is saved – but what is the strategy for the rest of heavy industry? | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Argument for ensuring ethylene production at Grangemouth is strong, yet policymaking on deindustrialisation is disjointed
articles.summary: Prime minister Keir Starmer backed Ineos’s Grangemouth ethylene plant with a £120m rescue amid soaring energy costs and carbon levies, highlighting ad hoc interventions at key UK heavy industry sites. Critics note no clear policy criteria: Exxon's Mossmorran ethylene unit faces closure, Scunthorpe steel was nationalised without a long-term plan, and promised 25% industrial electricity cuts are delayed until 2027. North Sea tax disincentivises investment, while proposed carbon border measures exclude chemicals. With deindustrialisation outpacing policymaking, a cohesive strategy remains elusive.

articles.title: The stats don’t lie. Australia’s tax system is designed to benefit the wealthiest and the rest of us pay for it | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: Many progressives protest that they are not rich, despite being on a very good wicket. They always reel off their CV of working-class roots
articles.summary: ABS data show Australia’s median annual earnings at $74,100 and male full-time average at $111,592. Earning over $156,000 places you in the top 10%. Yet $22bn in annual super tax breaks enriches that group—more than the $12.2bn spent on public schools or $16.9bn on jobseeker. A jobseeker rate of $20,634 sits 40% below the outdated Henderson poverty line. Women’s wages lag men’s after parenthood, and Sydney house prices now cost 16.1× median earnings. Jericho argues these tax settings structurally benefit the wealthy while neglecting genuine hardship.

articles.title: Paddy Power and Betfair to pay £2m settlement after failing to protect users
articles.trailText: Failings included allowing customer to place £20,000 in bets across eight-hour session, Gambling Commission finds
articles.summary: Paddy Power and Betfair, Flutter Entertainment brands, agreed a £2m settlement with the Gambling Commission after a 2024 review exposed social responsibility failings. Automated safeguards missed early harm indicators, letting one customer stake £86,000 over 16 days (losing £6,000) with no manual check, and another place 300 bets worth £20,000 in a 7h46m session before loss thresholds triggered a review. This follows a £490,000 2023 fine for breaching self-exclusion rules. Flutter says new real-time safety tech now prevents such oversights.

articles.title: Warner Bros reportedly poised to reject Paramount’s $108bn hostile takeover bid
articles.trailText: Decision will pave the way for Netflix to proceed with buyout of film and TV group
articles.summary: Warner Bros Discovery is set to recommend shareholders reject Paramount’s $108bn hostile takeover bid, clearing Netflix’s path to acquire the studio for $82.7bn. Paramount Skydance, backed by David Ellison, launched its rival all-cash offer after Netflix won the auction for Warner’s film, TV and streaming assets, excluding cable channels like CNN. WBD’s board cites valuation, financing and terms concerns with Paramount’s proposal, while regulatory scrutiny looms over both deals. Paramount’s bid relies on $24bn from Qatar, Saudi and Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth funds, raising FCC ownership questions, while Netflix’s $5.8bn breakup fee underscores its confidence in regulatory approval.

articles.title: Inflation drop makes Bank of England early Christmas present to Reeves almost a certainty
articles.trailText: Monetary policy committee, cautious in recent months, expected to respond with cut in interest rates
articles.summary: UK inflation plunged to 3.2% in November, down from 3.6% in October, boosting expectations that the Bank of England will cut its 4% base rate by 25bp at its December meeting. Food inflation eased to 4.2% while services inflation fell to 4.4%, and month-on-month prices for sugar, pasta and couscous have declined. Market-implied odds of a rate cut exceeded 95%. Chancellor Rachel Reeves, facing tax rises and a slowing labour market, welcomed the relief and budget measures to curb prices. MPC members wary of high rates amid temporary inflation drivers are now leaning towards early cuts to support growth.

articles.title: UK inflation falls sharply to 3.2% amid slowdown in food price rises
articles.trailText: Drop in November annual rate adds to case for Bank of England cut to interest rates on Thursday
articles.summary: UK CPI slowed to 3.2% in November from 3.6% a month earlier—below the 3.5% consensus—driven by falling food prices (cakes, biscuits, cereals), tobacco and women’s clothing, plus Black Friday discounts. Food and drink inflation eased to 4.2%, while core CPI dipped to 3.2%. Markets now price in over a 90% chance of a quarter-point Bank of England rate cut from 4% on Thursday, weighing on the pound (−0.7% vs. dollar) and government borrowing costs. Chancellor Reeves’s autumn budget relief could shave half a percentage point off next year’s headline inflation, though the rate remains well above the 2% target, stoking cost-of-living and real income concerns.

articles.title: Christmas dinner and festive treats up to 70% more expensive, reports Which?
articles.trailText: Price of turkey jumps as much as £15 compared with 2024, while chocolate has steepest mark-up
articles.summary: Shoppers face steep festive food inflation: Which? finds chocolate treats up 72% year-on-year (Lindt Lindor truffles at Asda +72% to £1.98; Lindt tree decorations at Morrisons +71%), and average chocolate prices +14%. Turkey prices rose up to £14.95 (Tesco Finest turkey crown +27.8% to £68.77), with overall turkey inflation averaging 4.7% due to bird flu, farming costs and cocoa shortages from extreme weather. Traditional turkey demand is waning as major retailers (Waitrose, M&S) drop whole frozen turkeys. Among big chains, Waitrose saw highest Christmas price rise (+6.2%), Asda the lowest (+3%); Sainsbury’s is running festive offers.

articles.title: Rate hikes, rising inflation and difficult decisions: key takeaways from Jim Chalmers’ budget update
articles.trailText: Treasurer says his Myefo, which shows a small improvement in the budget bottom line, is ‘the most responsible’ on record
articles.summary: Jim Chalmers’ 2025 Myefo shows a $36.8bn deficit this year—$5.4bn narrower than pre-election forecasts—and an $8.4bn cumulative improvement across the forward estimates, deferring the $1tn debt milestone by a year despite a $6.3bn disaster-relief cost blow-out. Higher iron ore and gold prices boosted tax revenue, enabling $1.1bn for free mental health services, $233m for CSIRO and $98m to train 6,000 green-energy tradies. Yet inflation is now projected at 3.75% by mid-2026, wages lag and rate hikes loom.

articles.title: EU plans to water down ban on new petrol and diesel cars
articles.trailText: Commission proposes cutting obligation for 100% zero emission vehicles beyond 2035 to 90% after pressure from industry and some EU states
articles.summary: The European Commission has proposed cutting the 2035 zero-emission vehicle mandate from 100% to 90%, allowing manufacturers to produce plug-in hybrids and some combustion models if they offset the remainder with green steel or biofuels. The plan also relaxes van CO₂ targets (50% cut by 2030 down to 40%) and introduces incentives for small EU-made EVs (under 4.2 m, priced €15k–€20k) via toll discounts, charging rebates and super carbon credits. Backed by Germany and Italy to bolster industry competitiveness against China, it faces criticism from green groups and EU parliamentarians as a major retreat in Europe’s electrification drive.

articles.title: Universal Studios UK theme park given planning permission in Bedfordshire
articles.trailText: Attraction part-funded with £500m of public investment will be constructed on site of a former brickworks
articles.summary: MHCLG has approved a special development order for the UK’s first Universal Studios theme park on a former brickworks near Bedford, bypassing local planning procedures. Backed by £500m in rail and road infrastructure funding, plus Luton airport expansion, Comcast aims for a 2031 opening featuring Europe’s tallest rides at 115m, 8m annual visitors and a £50bn boost to the UK economy. The scheme will deliver 20,000 construction jobs and 8,000 operational roles, a new Stewartby East West Rail station and an enlarged Wixams hub. Local MP Mohammad Yasin called it a “landmark moment,” and Universal pledges to share progress and supplier opportunities; a parliamentary review starts 12 Jan.

articles.title: US lost 105,000 jobs in October and added 64,000 in November, according to delayed data
articles.trailText: Data shows the headline unemployment rate continued to climb and hit 4.6%, a four-year high, last month
articles.summary: US labor market shed 105,000 jobs in October and added 64,000 in November, pushing unemployment to 4.6% – a four-year high. August and September’s figures were revised down. Data release delays and quality concerns trace to the 43-day federal shutdown, prompting Fed chair Jerome Powell to view BLS numbers skeptically. Federal payrolls fell by 168,000 across both months, while ADP reported a 32,000 private sector job drop in November. Economists judge the slowdown too gradual to force a Fed rate cut. Meanwhile, the Bureau of Labor Statistics faces leadership and staffing gaps after Trump-era upheaval.

articles.title: Thames Water defers controversial £2.5m in bonuses to bosses
articles.trailText: Heavily indebted utility puts back ‘retention payments’ for 21 executives until new year amid search for rescue deal
articles.summary: Thames Water has postponed £2.5m of retention payments due to 21 senior executives until the New Year amid multibillion-pound rescue talks. Although performance bonuses for top roles are banned under the Water (Special Measures) Act, retention awards fall outside the prohibition; the first £2.5m tranche was paid in April, with identical sums due in December and £10.8m next June. Funded via a £3bn, 9.75% emergency loan from class-A creditors—now poised to inject £5.3bn equity and assume ownership—the utility risks special administration or renationalisation if recapitalisation stalls.

articles.title: Jim Chalmers won’t have good news in Myefo. Instead, he’ll be trying to sell Labor’s good intentions
articles.trailText: The unwelcome return of inflation means Anthony Albanese’s government is desperate not to be seen to be adding to the problem
articles.summary: In its midyear economic and fiscal outlook (Myefo), Treasurer Jim Chalmers reported a $5.4bn budget improvement, but forecast deficits will swell to $36.8bn this year and remain over the next decade. Facing $35bn in spending pressures—from disaster relief to pension and military super costs—the government will scrap energy rebate extensions, cut $6.8bn via consultant and labour-hire savings, and demand 5% departmental spending trims. Additional funding is allocated to the home battery scheme amid a cost blow-out, while higher commodity prices buoy company tax. No major reforms or sustainability blueprint yet; inflation risks constrain fiscal leeway ahead of the 2025 May budget.

articles.title: Roasted! Morrisons loses £17m VAT battle over rotisserie chickens
articles.trailText: High court rules whole cooked cool-down chickens should be subject to standard 20% tax rate for hot food
articles.summary: Morrisons must pay a £17m VAT bill after the High Court ruled its cooled rotisserie chickens fall under the 20% hot-food rate introduced by the 2012 “pasty tax.” The court cited foil-lined bags and two-hour hot-cabinet storage keeping chickens well above ambient temperature, rejecting Morrisons’s claim they were sold cold or “incidentally hot.” A price rise from £4.40 to £5.28 could deter lower-income shoppers, hit suppliers and highlight unclear HMRC guidance.

articles.title: UK unemployment rose to four-year high of 5.1% before budget
articles.trailText: October figure from ONS suggests employers laid off workers, as earnings growth excluding bonuses fell
articles.summary: UK unemployment rose to 5.1% in the three months to October—the highest since early 2016 outside the pandemic—as payrolls shed 38,000 jobs and the claimant count climbed to 1.696m. Wage growth excluding bonuses slowed to 4.6% (private pay 3.9%, public pay 7.6%). GDP unexpectedly fell 0.1% in October. Analysts (ICAEW, Capital Economics) and business groups (BRC, BCC) warn the jobs market is “unravelling,” particularly for under-26s (415,000 added since 2020), boosting calls for a BoE rate cut from 4% to 3.75%.

articles.title: Young people hit hard as UK unemployment marches upwards
articles.trailText: Jobs market slowdown likely to become policy focus and will also have impact on interest rates decision
articles.summary: Labour’s goal of 80% employment looks unlikely as ONS data show a fall to 74.9% in the three months to October and a four-year high unemployment rate of 5.1%. Young adults face the worst squeeze: 546,000 18-24-year-olds out of work, the highest since 2015. Labour plans to equalise youth minimum wage with the adult rate from April, but think tanks question its timing. While economic inactivity has eased, payrolled jobs declined year-on-year from March, and real-time wage growth slowed to 2.7% in October. With wage growth cooling, the Bank of England may cut interest rates before Christmas, but policymakers warn the jobs downturn could dominate 2026.

articles.title: ‘Squeezed from every direction’: pubs voice fury at Reeves’s business rates changes
articles.trailText: Chancellor’s claim to be helping trade met with disbelief in England and Wales amid soaring staff costs, energy bills and other overheads
articles.summary: In the wake of Rachel Reeves’s budget, UK pubs face sharp business‐rates hikes: rateable values are being recalculated in a three‐year cycle, triggering average increases of 76% for pubs (vs 4% for supermarkets). Operators like Three Hills (Cambridgeshire) and Longbow’s George (Peak District) warn bills rocketing to £88k by 2029. UK Hospitality warns of £318m extra in three years, job cuts and closures loom. Landlords decry being ‘squeezed’, some launching ‘No Labour MPs’ sticker campaigns. Government says relief caps next‐year rises to 4% and maintains beer duty cuts.

articles.title: Nissan begins production of new electric car in Sunderland
articles.trailText: Launch of third generation of Leaf follows investment of more than £450m into model, including £300m direct to UK
articles.summary: Nissan has begun production of the third-generation Leaf at its Sunderland plant—Britain’s largest car factory with 6,000 employees and a 600,000-unit capacity. To date, 282,704 Leafs have been built at the site. The new model launch follows a £450 m investment (including £300 m into UK operations), and features a 75 kWh battery delivering up to 386 miles per charge, qualifying for the full £3,750 UK EV grant. Government ministers will visit the factory amid hopes the Leaf rollout secures future EV output—potentially replacing petrol Qashqai and Juke models—and supports the adjacent AESC battery plant. Despite Nissan’s global factory closures and 20,000 job cuts, Sunderland remains protected.

articles.title: UK and South Korea sign new trade deal aimed at cars, salmon and Guinness
articles.trailText: Government says arrangement will bring in extra £400m on top of more than £15bn of existing annual trade with Korea
articles.summary: The UK and South Korea have replaced their 2019 post-Brexit agreement to boost £15bn annual trade by an extra £400m, extending duty-free coverage to 98% of goods. The deal cuts regional value content for cars from 55% to 25%, allowing battery sourcing from China, and broadens tariff-free exports of services, automotive, pharmaceuticals, Scottish salmon and Guinness. It also opens Korean public procurement, legal services, digital trade and e-contract access for UK firms.

articles.title: Morrisons becomes first UK supermarket to delay net zero targets
articles.trailText: Britain’s fifth-biggest grocer postpones goal by 15 years to 2050, saying revised plan will now cover entire supply chain
articles.summary: Morrisons, the UK’s fifth-largest supermarket, has become the first to push its net zero carbon target back 15 years to 2050, extending commitments to its entire supply chain—including agriculture, land use, store operations, logistics and end-of-life emissions. Since its 2019 baseline, the Bradford-based chain says it has cut emissions by 22% through energy efficiency, operational changes and supplier collaboration. Sustainability head Andrew Edlin insists the move, validated by the Science Based Targets initiative, strengthens its long-term strategy. Morrisons, owned by US private equity firm CD&R, holds an 8.3% market share as Lidl closes in at 8.1%.

articles.title: The big quarrels over the workers’ rights bill have barely started | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Many critical details have been deliberately left to be resolved in secondary legislation – including the introduction of guaranteed hours contracts
articles.summary: Major employers urge the Lords to approve the employment rights bill by Christmas, despite dissent over removing the unfair-dismissal compensation cap. They fear further delays could undermine last month’s deal: replacing day-one unfair dismissal protection with a six-month qualifying period. Critical elements—like thresholds and reference periods for guaranteed-hours contracts—are deferred to secondary legislation, as are rules for seasonal workers, industrial action and union procedures. Business secretary Peter Kyle pledges extensive consultation on these details, but warns secondary legislation will fuel new disputes.

articles.title: Brighton’s struggling independent stores: ‘The nation of shopkeepers will go on the dole’
articles.trailText: City’s small shops are reaching tipping point amid higher business rates, staff costs and big chains eager to move in
articles.summary: Brighton’s independent shop owners warn their ‘nation of shopkeepers’ is at a tipping point: higher business rates, staff costs, VAT hikes, Brexit customs fees and rising rents erode margins. Customised expertise is lost, communities rally via WhatsApp and a new council-run Independents Forum tackles crime and rates. Even affluent North Laine, Gen-Z’s top independent destination, faces churn as chains like Mountain Warehouse and Ben & Jerry’s encroach. Traders say rate relief is offset by NICs and minimum-wage rises, risking closures, job losses and political fallout.

articles.title: Roomba maker iRobot bought by Chinese supplier after filing for bankruptcy
articles.trailText: US-listed company, whose profits have been in decline since the pandemic, will be taken over by Picea
articles.summary: iRobot, maker of Roomba vacuums, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in Delaware and agreed to a takeover by Picea Robotics’ subsidiary to restructure after years of declining profits, supply-chain woes and competition from cheaper rivals. The deal, following a collapsed $1.4 bn Amazon bid in 2022 and a $94 m payout, aims to pair iRobot’s R&D and design with Picea’s manufacturing expertise. iRobot will remain a going concern, continue its app and product support, pay creditors in full and manage privacy concerns over Chinese ownership.

articles.title: Young people bearing brunt of UK jobs downturn, thinktank warns
articles.trailText: Resolution Foundation report comes in week when data is expected to show October unemployment rise
articles.summary: Resolution Foundation warns young Britons are hardest hit by the UK’s jobs downturn: a growing “jobs deficit” has pushed graduates and non-graduates into unemployment as public and private sector hiring slows, driving the rate from 5% in September to a projected 5.1% in October and possibly 5.5% next year. With NEET numbers near one million and working-age employment down one point (415,000 jobs) since 2020—entirely due to rising unemployment—policymakers must redouble youth support. Modest inflation relief may prompt a Bank of England rate cut.

articles.title: Green sleeves? Laundry detergent being tweaked owing to gen Z’s love of matcha
articles.trailText: Japanese green tea named stain of the year as survey finds Aperol spritz and bubble tea are also leaving their mark
articles.summary: Unilever’s inaugural Stains Index, based on a survey of 2,000 UK adults, names matcha as 2025’s ‘stain of the year’, with Aperol spritz and bubble tea close behind—reflecting Gen Z’s drink trends. Seventy percent of Gen Z suffer a stain weekly (versus 16% of boomers), reporting matcha (39%), Aperol (38%), bubble tea and hot sauces (35%). While red wine and curry still dominate overall, Unilever’s Port Sunlight labs have reformulated Persil and Surf to tackle these vibrant pigments. The annual index will continue to monitor emerging food and lifestyle marks—from makeup to nail polish—to inform future laundry innovations.

articles.title: Want job security in the age of AI? Get a state license – any state license
articles.trailText: The coming tech boom is about to launch a boom in people who do things with their hands and minds
articles.summary: In an AI-driven job market, state-issued professional licenses—from CPAs to electricians, nurses and beauticians—offer the most durable security. Unlike private certificates, government licenses demand accredited education, exams and ongoing training, validating competence and boosting pay, credibility and entrepreneurship opportunities. Despite regulatory critiques, licensing rates have climbed, trade school enrollment is up over 35%, and private equity is investing heavily in home services. While AI will automate routine tasks, licensed professionals will remain essential for complex judgment, human interaction and equipment operation, ensuring resilience in the coming tech boom.

articles.title: Don’t use ‘boilerplate’ reasons to justify big executive pay rises, UK firms warned
articles.trailText: Investment Association, influential group of shareholders, urges pay committees to avoid ‘benchmarking’
articles.summary: Investment Association tells pay committees at FTSE 350 firms they must avoid generic benchmarking to justify large executive pay hikes, requiring robust, company-specific links between remuneration and performance and clear shareholder-interest rationale. It warns that reliance on peer pay comparisons alone creates a ratchet effect and that disclosures citing competitiveness or talent retention need supporting evidence. This follows median FTSE 100 CEO pay jumping 11% to £6.5m, LSEG chief David Schwimmer’s £7.9m package and broader calls for reform by the IA and thinktanks urging stronger investor oversight.

articles.title: Almost half of people using employment providers threatened with payment suspensions, new data shows
articles.trailText: Government not maintaining ‘effective oversight’, with majority of decisions being overturned, commonwealth ombudsman found
articles.summary: DEWR data shows 618,000 Workforce Australia payment suspension notices from July–Sept 2025, a 23% surge that threatened nearly half of participants, including 52% of First Nations job seekers. Advocates and the commonwealth ombudsman warn the targeted compliance framework operates with inadequate oversight: 964 suspensions were unlawful, half of provider decisions overturned. Only 11.7% secured long-term jobs despite a $750m spend. Critics call for pausing suspensions, an independent quality commission and an end to private firms’ control over vital income-support decisions.

articles.title: How many more times will the Bank of England rescue Rachel Reeves? | Richard Partington
articles.trailText: The City expects a cut in interest rates on Thursday but economic prospects for 2026 complicate the picture
articles.summary: Since Labour’s election, the Bank of England has cut rates five times to alleviate Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s economic challenges, with a likely sixth cut this week as inflation cools after weak growth and a softening jobs market. However, high rates have weighed on GDP and mortgages, and the Monetary Policy Committee remains split on further easing in 2026.
