Reeves’s fiscal measures may bolster arguments for deeper cuts, but sticky services inflation, rising business costs and policy uncertainties could limit future rate reductions.

articles.title: ‘The UK needs some media free of US control’: Comcast’s move for ITV starts to focus minds
articles.trailText: With public service broadcasters starting to look like ‘endangered species’, many want Channel 4 and BBC to work more closely
articles.summary: Comcast is in talks to buy ITV’s £1.6bn broadcasting arm and streaming service, which combined with Sky could control over 70% of UK TV ad spend and stakes in ITN, Sky News and ITV News, sparking plurality and regulatory concerns. Channel 4’s incoming CEO, Priya Dogra, is expected to challenge the deal to protect PSBs. Ofcom warns UK public service broadcasters risk becoming “endangered.” Comcast previously guaranteed Sky News funding until 2028, but future support remains uncertain. Observers urge closer BBC–Channel 4 collaboration, and anticipate CMA scrutiny, licence guarantees and PSB obligations to safeguard national news against US digital giants.

articles.title: Labour is procrastinating over policy as UK’s economy goes backwards | Phillip Inman
articles.trailText: New business rates regime that is poised to hit pubs and hotels is latest example of hasty decision-making
articles.summary: Labour’s hesitation on economic policy coincides with backward-moving growth, rising unemployment and recession fears. Despite acclaimed strategies, Whitehall delays then rushes to impose measures—most recently a new business rates regime raising pub and hotel bills by up to 500%, sparking #taxedout protests from small chains. Proposed inheritance tax levies threaten farms and family firms, risking sales to private equity or foreign buyers. Starmer’s team balances long-term planning with election-driven caution, stalling industrial strategy, local government reform and public investment. Without reviewing these tax hikes and decision-making processes, Britain’s fragile businesses and farming sector face severe long-term harm.

articles.title: Zipcar’s rivals consider London expansion after it reveals UK exit
articles.trailText: Free2Move, Enterprise Car Club and Co Wheels among those eyeing growth, as well as peer-to-peer firm Hiyacar
articles.summary: Zipcar’s planned UK exit at year-end leaves a half-million-user gap in London’s car-sharing market, prompting Stellantis-owned Free2Move to “actively assess” a city launch alongside Enterprise Car Club’s expansion plans and Co Wheels’ talks with boroughs. Peer-to-peer firms Hiyacar and Turo also aim to boost London listings, citing lower capital outlay than fleet operators. While London’s transit-reliant population offers high demand, fragmented borough licensing and parking fees pose barriers. Free2Move highlights London’s readiness for autonomous mobility, but any rollout will require significant investment and regulatory alignment across boroughs.

articles.title: Trump demands Fed listen to him as he lines up new leader: ‘I’m a smart voice’
articles.trailText: Ex-Fed governor Kevin Warsh is at top of his list to succeed Powell as central bank’s chair, president says in interview
articles.summary: President Trump told WSJ he ‘should be listened to’ by the Fed, and is lining up former Fed governor Kevin Warsh as his top choice to succeed Jerome Powell in May. He emphasized Warsh’s alignment with his rate-cut agenda and also considered NEC chair Kevin Hassett among candidates. This marks an unprecedented White House push to influence Fed policy after Powell defied Trump’s demands. Trump plans to nominate soon, arguing the central bank needs a chair who weighs his views on lowering interest rates, following the Fed’s third quarter-point cut this year and officials’ caution on future cuts.

articles.title: ‘Every Leon should be magical’: food chain’s co-founder on what went wrong – and how to fix it
articles.trailText: John Vincent on bouncing back after cutting branches, refreshing the menu, and staff learning from martial arts
articles.summary: John Vincent has bought back Leon for an estimated £30–50m from Asda to revive the fast-food chain he co-founded in 2004. He’s closing unprofitable sites—reducing 68 outlets to around 50 by January—and refocusing on 29 owner-operated London stores while renegotiating leases. Vincent is overhauling the menu (ditching underperformers, reintroducing fish finger wraps, upgrading smoked salmon and halloumi) and training staff in Wing Tsun martial arts to speed service. With plans for 100 UK sites and selective overseas expansion, he aims to restore Leon’s healthy, seasonal ethos and achieve sustainable growth after years of losses and Covid setbacks.

articles.title: Damn dalmatian! Fury erupts after David Jones cancels Christmas window display to promote joy of … its loyalty program
articles.trailText: Department store draws ire of Sydneysiders by abandoning festive tradition to instead promote rewards program with mascot Domino the dalmatian
articles.summary: Two weeks before Christmas, Sydney’s flagship David Jones store cancelled its traditional festive window display, replacing it with animations of Domino the dalmatian to promote its new loyalty program, “A Very Rewarding Christmas.” Featuring Qantas Points baubles and product showcases, the shift sparked public ire and nostalgia-driven backlash on social media. David Jones acknowledged the misstep, citing a retail downturn and a $74m FY2024 loss, and vowed to restore festive magic next year, as rival Myer’s Lego-built windows thronged Melbourne crowds.

articles.title: EU’s 2035 petrol and diesel car ban will be watered down, says senior MEP
articles.trailText: Decision would anger environmental campaigners, who say it would amount to ‘gutting’ of green deal
articles.summary: A senior EPP MEP, supported by German chancellor Friedrich Merz and Italy’s Giorgia Meloni, says the European Commission will dilute its planned 2035 ban on new petrol and diesel cars by scrapping the strict zero-emissions requirement in favour of a 90% CO2 reduction fleet-target, effectively permitting plug-in hybrids with backup combustion engines capable of 600km ranges. Environmentalists warn this "gutting" of the green deal risks prolonging reliance on polluting vehicles. Discussions continue, while Brussels also readies incentives for small, "made-in-Europe" EVs to counter growing Chinese competition. Proponents argue it secures tens of thousands of industrial jobs in Europe’s auto sector.

articles.title: Card Factory issues shock profit warning during peak Christmas period
articles.trailText: Retailer, which also owns Funky Pigeon, says economic pressure has hit shoppers’ confidence
articles.summary: Card Factory, owner of Funky Pigeon, has issued a surprise profit warning in its peak Christmas trading season, cutting its full-year adjusted pre-tax profit forecast to £55m–£60m (from £66m last year) after UK consumer confidence and high-street footfall weakened. Shares plunged 23% on the update. Royal Mail letter volumes have fallen from 20bn to 6.6bn annually and are forecast to drop further, while stamp prices have soared, compounding the shift away from physical cards. Management says its productivity and efficiency programme and the £24m Funky Pigeon integration remain on track, and North America and Irish operations meet expectations. The board remains confident in its long-term strategy.

articles.title: Nationwide fined £44m by watchdog for financial crime control failings
articles.trailText: Ineffective systems culminated in serious case of Covid fraud that cost UK taxpayers £800,000
articles.summary: FCA fined Nationwide £44m for weak anti-financial crime controls from Oct 2016 to Jul 2021, after a customer exploited personal accounts to receive £27.3m in fraudulent Covid furlough payments, leaving taxpayers £800k short. Nationwide lacked business account monitoring, missed red flags like repeated address changes. A forced 2021–24 transformation followed alongside its £2.9bn Virgin Money bid. CEO transitions—from Joe Garner to Debbie Crosbie, whose £7m pay rise drew mutual members’ ire—underscore governance lapses.

articles.title: UK economy shrank unexpectedly before budget, data shows
articles.trailText: GDP fell by 0.1% in October as activity failed to regain momentum after cyber-attack on Jaguar Land Rover
articles.summary: ONS data show UK GDP fell 0.1% in October—the fourth consecutive month without growth—driven by a 0.3% slump in services and a 0.6% drop in construction as consumers and businesses delayed spending ahead of Rachel Reeves’s budget. Production output rose 1.1%, but the rebound from Jaguar Land Rover’s cyber-attack left car manufacturing 21.8% below August levels. Economists now expect the Bank of England to cut rates to 3.75% on Dec 18 and warn of sluggish Q4 growth amid uncertainty.

articles.title: New laws may be considered after ‘harrowing stories’ from ex-Vodafone franchisees
articles.trailText: Concerns about power imbalance in franchise agreements amid claims over firm’s treatment of small-business owners
articles.summary: MPs responded to Guardian-reported suicides and attempts by ex-Vodafone franchisees—triggered by 2020 commission cuts and mounting debts—by calling for a statutory code of practice or national arbitration to rebalance franchise agreements. A high-court claim by 62 former franchisees alleges Vodafone “unjustly enriched” itself; the telecoms giant denies wrongdoing, offers selective financial settlements and commits to discussions. Ministers indicated they may introduce tougher franchising laws, echoing the Post Office scandal.

articles.title: ���Squeaky bum time’ as Great Britain’s new rail timetable goes live this weekend
articles.trailText: More trains, faster journeys and better reliability promised – but spectre of great timetable fiasco of 2018 looms large
articles.summary: On 14 December Great Britain’s rail network will roll out its biggest timetable overhaul since the 2018 fiasco, underpinned by £4bn of east coast mainline upgrades. LNER adds 60,000 weekly seats and trims London–Edinburgh journeys to just over 4 hours and London–Leeds to about 2 hours with six trains per hour. TransPennine Express, East Midlands, Northern, Greater Anglia and Thameslink also ramp up services. Key works include King’s Cross track remodelling, the Werrington dive-under and new platforms at Stevenage and Doncaster. Digitisation to 2030 promises further reliability. Approved by rail minister Peter Hendy, operators cite extensive simulations and control-room prep, though 2018’s legacy stokes performance anxiety.

articles.title: Health and safety rules holding UK infrastructure back, says writer of government report
articles.trailText: Exclusive: John Fingleton says regulators need to change their attitude to risk to end the country’s economic stagnation
articles.summary: Economist John Fingleton, whose nuclear regulation report is shaping Keir Starmer’s growth strategy, argues that Britain’s overcautious health and safety regime—illustrated by park closures in high winds, a £700m fish deterrent at Hinkley Point C saving under one salmon annually, and ultra-low worker radiation limits—is deterring infrastructure investment, inflating costs and merely shifting risk. His recommendations, accepted by Starmer, include clearer ministerial risk tolerances, upfront biodiversity payments and extending the approach to rail, reservoirs and wider industrial policy. Unions and environmentalists warn deregulation could compromise safety.

articles.title: MPs announce inquiry into work of Office for Budget Responsibility
articles.trailText: Treasury committee will examine agency’s forecasting record and discover where it ‘needs to do better’
articles.summary: MPs' all-party Commons Treasury committee has launched a 15-year review of the Office for Budget Responsibility, probing its forecasting accuracy, impartiality and relationship with the Treasury after leaks and a clash with Chancellor Rachel Reeves. The inquiry, chaired by Labour's Meg Hillier, will examine the OBR's role since its 2010 creation, the circumstances behind Richard Hughes’s resignation over premature budget leaks, and whether reforms can bolster economic outcomes. Submissions are due by 30 January, followed by public evidence sessions to shape the new chair’s mandate.

articles.title: Drax plans to convert part of its North Yorkshire power plant into datacentre
articles.trailText: Plans are response to surge in demand for AI capability and come after government signalled it would curb subsidies
articles.summary: Drax, operator of Britain’s largest power station near Selby, plans to apply for permission to convert a former coal-to-biomass unit into a 100MW datacentre by 2027, reusing existing land, cooling systems and transformers. Initially grid-powered, it could later tap the plant’s renewable output. The initiative aims to shore up electricity demand after government subsidy cuts due in 2026, following a trading update forecasting near-top profits backed by £2m+/day biomass subsidies. Ongoing FCA and NGO probes into alleged use of old-growth Canadian wood challenge Drax’s sustainability claims.

articles.title: The UK’s pharma deal was vital – but the GSK boss is right about US dominance | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: It would be absurd to claim the UK has suddenly become a life-sciences leader thanks to the new pricing and tariffs pact
articles.summary: Government agreed a multipronged pharma deal: NHS drug prices will rise, rebate payments capped at 15%, NICE price thresholds up 25%, and UK exports face zero US tariffs for three years. The pact aims to avert threatened Trump-era duties and secure life-science investments after Merck scrapped a £1bn London research centre. GSK CEO Emma Walmsley notes the US remains the dominant market, spending and funding far beyond the UK despite strong domestic research. While NHS costs may increase by £3bn a year, the deal protects future innovation and dovetails with plans to boost R&D to 0.6% of GDP and expand health data infrastructure.

articles.title: Disappointing Oracle results knock $80bn off value amid AI bubble fears
articles.trailText: Weaker-than-forecast quarterly data for Larry Ellison’s tech company shows slowdown in revenue growth and big rise in spending Business live – latest updates
articles.summary: Oracle’s shares plunged 15% after its latest quarter showed revenue up 14% to $16bn—below forecasts—and slower cloud (34%) and infrastructure (68%) growth. The slide wiped about $80bn off its $630bn market cap and dragged Nvidia shares lower, stoking AI bubble concerns. Oracle raised AI-related capex guidance 40% to $50bn, even as long-term debt rose 25% to $99.9bn and debt-insurance costs climbed. Analysts warn heavy AI spending, financed by debt and big-tech deal reliance, may not justify valuations.

articles.title: US is the best place for drug companies to invest, says boss of London-based GSK
articles.trailText: Emma Walmsley’s praise for US pharmaceutical market piles pressure on UK government
articles.summary: GSK CEO Emma Walmsley says the US is the top investment market for pharma, leading global drug and vaccine launches alongside China, and noted GSK derives half its revenues there. Her stance echoes AstraZeneca’s praise of US opportunities. Under pressure, the UK government will cut the NHS clawback on new medicine revenues from 22.5% to 14.5% in 2026, keep 10–35% rates on older branded drugs, raise NICE cost-effectiveness thresholds and give ministers power to set them. New drug spending is forecast to rise by £1 billion over three years, risking staff/equipment budgets. GSK plans $30 billion US investment by 2030.

articles.title: Disney to invest $1bn in OpenAI, allowing characters in Sora video tool
articles.trailText: Agreement comes amid anxiety in Hollywood over impact of AI on the industry, expression and rights of creators
articles.summary: Walt Disney is investing $1bn in OpenAI for a three-year license allowing Sora users to generate short social videos featuring 200+ Disney, Marvel, Pixar and Star Wars characters—excluding talent likenesses and voices. The deal marks OpenAI’s biggest Hollywood tie-up amid industry concerns over AI’s impact on creators, following protests, lawsuits and cease-and-desist actions over unauthorized use. Disney will also integrate OpenAI APIs and ChatGPT internally, stream Sora clips on Disney+, and leverage Sam Altman and Bob Iger’s joint pledge to balance innovation and rights protection.

articles.title: EU watchdogs raid Temu’s Dublin HQ in foreign subsidy investigation
articles.trailText: Chinese online retailer targeted under rules limiting state help to companies
articles.summary: EU regulators carried out an unannounced inspection at Temu’s prestigious Dublin HQ on St Stephen’s Green—alongside the Shelbourne Hotel and Cantor Fitzgerald—under the EU’s foreign subsidies regulation, probing potential Chinese state aid to the fast-growing e-commerce platform. A commission spokesperson confirmed the raid last week. Temu, with 116 million EU users, is already under a Digital Services Act probe into illegal product listings. The action underscores Brussels’ push to level the playing field after last year’s 38 percent tariffs on Chinese automakers, amid widening EU-China trade imbalances—Germany’s first-ever deficit and China’s $1 trillion export surplus—and tighter scrutiny of state-backed foreign firms.

articles.title: No guarantee tobacco tax cut would lure Australian smokers from illegal trade and raise more revenue, report says
articles.trailText: New research points to need for ‘holistic approach to combating illicit tobacco’ including having support of health advocates
articles.summary: Research from the e61 Institute warns cutting Australia’s tobacco excise may fail to draw smokers back to legal products and could deepen a multibillion-dollar budget shortfall. High taxes that once generated $16.3bn in 2019-20 have driven illicit sales to about half the market, halving excise receipts to $7.8bn and evading up to $11.8bn in tax. The analysis finds reinstating 2019 rates could swing annual revenue by –$2.1bn to +$3.2bn. Authors urge a holistic strategy—enhanced enforcement, public education and health-sector backing—to curb illegal tobacco.

articles.title: Fed cuts interest rates by a quarter point amid apparent split over US economy
articles.trailText: Divisive vote to lower rates highlights uncertainty within the Fed as economy absorbs major shakeups, including tariffs
articles.summary: The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark rate by 0.25 percentage points to 3.50–3.75% in a rare 9–3 split, underscoring deep FOMC divisions over rising inflation (3% in September) and climbing unemployment (4.4%) amid tariffs, immigration-related labor shifts and fiscal cuts. Chair Jerome Powell warned that missing price and jobs data from the shutdown will demand extra scrutiny, while officials project hesitancy on further 2026 rate cuts. The move risks fresh tension with President Trump, who is eyeing NEC director Kevin Hassett for Fed chair.

articles.title: Leon to cut jobs and close fast food restaurants
articles.trailText: The 54-outlet chain was recently bought back by its co-founder, who says Leon must downsize as more customers work from home
articles.summary: Leon, the 54-outlet fast-food chain, has appointed Quantuma administrators, planning to close unprofitable sites and cut jobs less than two months after co-founder John Vincent bought it back from Asda. Since October, 10 outlets (including 3 overseas) closed. Sales fell 3.8% to £62.5m in 2024 with an £8.38m pre-tax loss. Vincent cites working-from-home trends, high taxes (36p/£1), and industry losses for the downsizing. He’ll ditch the £25/month Roast Rewards, train staff in "wing tsun" to speed coffee service, and reassign staff to other Leon sites or Pret a Manger. Vincent aims to rebuild profitability and return to growth.

articles.title: No wonder Michele Bullock’s dramatic departure from the interest rate script left markets swinging wildly  | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: Less than two months ago the market was predicting the cash rate would be at 3.35% but that by May next year a further cut to 3.1% was almost certain
articles.summary: Michele Bullock's departure from the usual RBA statement—with a shorter December release and hawkish language on inflation—convinced markets that rate cuts are off the table. After holding the cash rate at 3.6%, Bullock declared ‘I don’t think there are interest rate cuts on the horizon,’ prompting traders to price a climb to 3.85% by May and 4.1% by year-end. Despite slowing private-wage growth and modest job-market shifts, markets now weigh a rate hike risk ahead of February’s RBA meeting.

articles.title: ‘What to buy Dad for Christmas’: is retail ready for the AI shopping shift?
articles.trailText: As shoppers ask ChatGPT for inspiration, brands scramble to ensure their products appeal to the bots calling the shots
articles.summary: This Christmas marks a turning point: around 25% of UK shoppers—and 30% of those aged 25–34—are using AI tools like ChatGPT and Gemini to generate gift ideas, upending keyword-driven marketing. Retailers from Moonpig to John Lewis are racing to optimise product data, reviews and forum mentions for LLM “scraping,” a practice dubbed generative engine optimisation. Success now hinges on authenticity, trust and reliable availability rather than paid search slots. Smaller independents may outpace big brands by responding nimbly with clear branding and customer reviews. Looking ahead, AI agents that negotiate deals, transact purchases and automate returns promise further disruption, raising legal, technical and competitive challenges.

articles.title: Travel firm Tui says it is using AI to create ‘inspirational’ videos
articles.trailText: Boss says German firm also investing in generative engine optimisation to help push it to top of chatbot responses
articles.summary: Europe’s largest travel operator, Tui, is ramping up AI investments—deploying generative engine optimisation (GEO) to boost its visibility on chatbots (ChatGPT, Gemini, TikTok), and using AI to produce “inspirational” videos, multilingual content, and voice/chat customer agents. CEO Sebastian Ebel aims to embed Tui within LLM ecosystems beyond Google. Tui reported €1bn pre-tax profits (+20%) on €24.2bn revenue (+4%), but forecasts slower growth (2–4%) amid macro uncertainties. Plans include €250m cost savings by 2028 without net headcount cuts across its 67,000 workforce. Shares are down 34% in five years; a €0.10/share dividend policy and robust 2026 holiday demand (Greece, Balearics, Turkey) could revive the stock.

articles.title: US senator calls for insider trading inquiry over Trump donors buying $12m worth of shares
articles.trailText: Co-chairs of LNG firm, who bought stock worth almost $12m each after meeting with Trump officials, deny wrongdoing
articles.summary: Senator Jeff Merkley has called for an SEC and Senate probe into potential insider trading by LNG firm Venture Global’s co-chairs Robert Pender and Michael Sabel, who each bought $12m in shares days after meeting Energy Secretary Chris Wright—who then granted a vital export license. They took the company public three days after Trump’s inauguration, donated $1m to his inaugural fund and spent $860k on lobbying in 2024 and $810k so far in 2025. Venture Global insists it complied with SEC rules. Critics allege pay-to-play conflicts amid Trump’s fossil fuel deregulation, campaign contributions and climate rollback policies.

articles.title: William Hill owner Evoke considers sale or breakup after budget tax rises
articles.trailText: Value of heavily indebted company has plummeted more than 90% since it bought chain of 1,400 bookmakers
articles.summary: Evoke, owner of William Hill and 888 online casino, has hired Morgan Stanley and Rothschild to explore sale or break-up after warning of a £135m annual hit from recent budget tax rises on online betting and casinos. Heavily indebted (net £1.82bn), its share value plunged over 90% since the 2021 £2.2bn William Hill acquisition. Analysts warn bondholders might force asset stripping. Regulatory woes—including multi-million-pound anti-money-laundering fines in 2017 and 2022 and a suspended 2023 takeover by Entain veterans now in court—have compounded pressure.

articles.title: Archive, 1975: Iceland opens fire on British vessel
articles.trailText: The two European Nato countries clash in the third cod war over fishing rights in the Atlantic
articles.summary: In October 1975 Iceland unilaterally extended its fishing limit from 50 to 200 miles, triggering the third Cod War. The Icelandic gunboat Thor rammed and tried to arrest the British support trawler Star Aquarius off Seydisfjord in a force 9 gale, collided with the tug Lloydsman, and opened fire on British vessels. The incident coincided with a NATO foreign ministers’ meeting in Brussels, where Reykjavik sought leverage over the Keflavik airbase. Despite proposals in the UK Parliament for German mediation, deadlock persisted until Britain formally recognised the 200-mile zone in June 1976.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves’s test from the bond markets starts now
articles.trailText: UK gilt yields may have dropped a bit relative to other major countries, but it’s not at all clear that the fall with continue
articles.summary: Chancellor Reeves has seen a slight fall in 10-year gilt yields relative to US and eurozone peers, but the UK still pays a hefty premium—70 bp over US Treasuries and 25 bp over EZ bonds—costing up to £7 bn annually if eradicated. IPPR credits improved sentiment since the Labour conference, noting a 20 bp drop, but yields remain near 4.5 %. Skepticism lingers over long-term inflation, backloaded tax rises and communications missteps. OBR growth downgrades and Oxford Economics warn of fiscal credibility risks ahead of next May’s elections. Further gilt relief and BoE rate cuts will be pivotal for Reeves’ “it’s working” narrative.

articles.title: Bank of England expects budget will cut inflation by up to half a percentage point
articles.trailText: In a boost for Rachel Reeves, deputy governor says analysis shows chancellor’s policies will lower annual rate next year
articles.summary: The Bank of England’s early analysis finds Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s Dec 2025 budget—featuring £26bn of tax rises, removal of green energy bill levies, and frozen rail fares and fuel duty—will reduce headline inflation by 0.4–0.5 percentage points from mid-2026, matching the OBR. Deputy Governor Clare Lombardelli said the one-off energy measures are the main driver. The MPC will weigh this against longer-term wage and cost pressures ahead of a likely rate cut to 3.75% next week.

articles.title: Ofgem approves early investment in three UK electricity ‘superhighways’
articles.trailText: Green light intended to limit amount consumers pay for windfarms to turn off during periods of high generation
articles.summary: Ofgem has approved early investment in three high-voltage cables linking Scottish and North Sea windfarms to southern demand centers, advancing two Eastern Green Link subsea lines and the 75-mile Grimsby-Norfolk GWNC project to begin operating by 2033-34. By speeding up these ‘superhighways,’ consumers could save £3-6bn against late-decade delivery via lower curtailment payments (currently nearly £2bn/year), though upfront network charges will rise. National Grid and SSE can start spending on £28bn of grid upgrades. Ofgem stresses planning approvals remain separate, while local opposition over construction and landscape impact may intensify.

articles.title: Moonpig’s use of AI to design and personalise cards drives up sales
articles.trailText: About half of purchases involve shoppers using online retailer’s artificial intelligence-led features
articles.summary: Moonpig reported a 6.7% sales increase to £169m in H1 to Oct 31 and turned to a £26.6m pre-tax profit vs a £33.3m prior-year loss, driven by AI-designed and personalised e-card features. AI now contributes to around half of purchases (from 2% two years ago), generating customized designs—curated by human teams to ensure relevance—and powering a chat tool that resolves a third of enquiries. Customers rate AI chat interactions more highly than human-handled ones. CEO Nickyl Raithatha, stepping down for AutoTrader’s Catherine Faiers, says AI boosts productivity without cutting jobs and festive trading remains strong.

articles.title: Home movers in Great Britain could get just £30 of energy use without account
articles.trailText: Ofgem proposes cutting debt by giving new residents with no supply deal limited credit before they are cut off
articles.summary: Ofgem will require energy meters in GB homes to switch to prepayment when previous occupants leave, granting new movers just £30—about two weeks’ supply—before power is cut if they haven’t opened a supplier account. The move aims to slash record energy debt, now £4.5 bn, by pushing households to set up accounts within two weeks instead of the current 70-day average. Unpaid balances have added £52 to annual bills and burdened suppliers. Ofgem director Charlotte Friel says reforms will stop debt buildup; stakeholders must respond to the regulator’s consultation early next year.

articles.title: Western carmakers ‘in fight for lives’ against Chinese rivals, says Ford boss
articles.trailText: Jim Farley’s comments come as US manufacturer and Renault announce deal to make two smaller electric cars
articles.summary: Ford CEO Jim Farley warns Western automakers are in a “fight for our lives” against Chinese EV rivals as Ford and Renault unveil a partnership to co-develop two small electric cars (and potentially vans) on Renault’s Ampere platform, set for early 2028 production at Douai. Chinese brands like BYD and Chery have gained share with low-cost EVs, exposing Western dependence on larger, pricier battery models. Farley has cut 4,000 European jobs, delayed new EV models and criticized stringent EU carbon mandates alongside a surge of state-subsidized imports. Renault’s François Provost says the alliance will enhance innovation and responsiveness. Separately, BMW chair Oliver Zipse will retire in May, succeeded by Milan Nedeljković.

articles.title: ‘Bring it on!’: growing support in England for four-day week in schools
articles.trailText: Why proposals for a shorter working week are winning over teachers and parents – despite the logistical headaches
articles.summary: Advocates, including the 4 Day Week Foundation, are urging the UK government to pilot a four-day school week in England and Wales to boost teacher wellbeing, recruitment and pupil inclusion. A Guardian callout drew overwhelming support from parents—especially of autistic or exhausted children—and teachers seeking improved mental-health outcomes and work-life balance. Scottish proposals would keep campuses open five days by dedicating one day to planning and training. Skeptics warn of childcare shortages, budget strains, curriculum compression and disruption for special-needs students, pointing to mixed experiences from France. Proponents stress that careful planning and sustainable funding are crucial to success.

articles.title: UK fraud prevention ‘still lacking’ after Covid-related scams and errors cost £11bn
articles.trailText: Most of losses from bounceback loan, furlough pay and eat out to help out fraud not recovered, report finds
articles.summary: Tom Hayhoe’s independent Covid counter-fraud report finds UK taxpayer losses of £10.9bn from pandemic schemes—bounceback loans, small business grants, furlough and eat-out-to-help-out—ran without early safeguards. Failures in accountability, data quality, contracting and uneven departmental capabilities fuelled fraud risks. Though losses of £1.8bn have been recovered and the new Public Sector Fraud Authority is established, fraud prevention remains insufficiently embedded. Hayhoe urges the Treasury and PSFA to develop pre-tested, fraud-proof crisis stimuli and robust cross-departmental controls. The government says it will fully consider the findings and respond early next year.

articles.title: Britons face higher chocolate prices but average cost of Christmas dinner falls
articles.trailText: Supermarkets investing heavily in promotional deals to pull in customers, Worldpanel finds
articles.summary: In November, chocolate prices in Great Britain jumped 18.4% year-on-year amid cocoa shortages, driving manufacturers to shrink bars and cut cocoa content. Yet promotional deals helped average Christmas dinner for four fall marginally to £32.46, with frozen turkey down 3.6% to £13.52, while potatoes (+1.1% to £1.67), cranberry sauce (+10% to £0.86) and stuffing (+6.9% to £0.96) rose. Grocery prices rose 4.7%, beef mince surged 37.1%, prompting shifts to chicken, pork and fish. Tesco led with 28.3% market share; Asda slid to 11.5%. Online grocer sales rose 8%, but stores remain dominant.

articles.title: Australia is facing its shortest rate cut cycle in 30 years as the RBA hints it may have to start hiking
articles.trailText: It’s sure to leave many mortgage holders feeling short-changed given the RBA’s equally historic 13 rate hikes through 2022 and 2023
articles.summary: RBA Governor Michele Bullock held the cash rate at 3.6%, ruling out further cuts and warning that persistent inflation could force a hike in 2026. After three cuts this year—the shortest easing cycle in 30 years—and 13 hikes in 2022–23, 3.3 million mortgage holders face frustration. Underlying inflation rose to 3.8% in October, above the 2–3% target. Fiscal pressures ahead of the mid-year budget intensify strain on Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The RBA meets next in February, with rates on hold or rising possible.

articles.title: UK households cut spending at fastest pace in almost five years, says Barclays
articles.trailText: Bank reports 1.1% drop in card spending despite Black Friday boost for retailers
articles.summary: Barclays reports UK card spending fell 1.1% in November—the steepest decline since February 2021—as households delay festive shopping amid pre-budget jitters. Black Friday saw transactions 62.5% above 2025’s daily average but failed to offset muted growth: food sales rose 3% (below 3.6% inflation) and non-food was flat at 0.1%. Pub spending dropped 1.5%, while travel agents (+10.7%) and streaming services (+3.5%) gained. Subdued consumer confidence, rising unemployment and economic slowdown point to a likely Bank of England rate cut to 3.75%, prompting calls to ease business rates for retailers.

articles.title: Great British Railways flies the flag as logo goes back to the future
articles.trailText: Livery for renationalised railway features red, white and blue alongside familiar double arrow symbol
articles.summary: Ministers unveiled the Great British Railways (GBR) livery and logo at London Bridge, featuring red, white and blue with the double-arrow motif as a heritage nod. Designed in-house by the Department for Transport, the branding accompanies landmark legislation to unify track and train operations under a renationalised system headquartered in Derby. Seven private operators are already repatriated, with full takeover by 2027. A new GBR ticketing app, station clocks and model/virtual liveries in Hornby and Train Sim World 6 support the relaunch. Transport Secretary Heidi Alexander lauded the reforms and 2026 fare freeze.

articles.title: Why has Paramount Skydance launched a hostile bid for Warner Bros Discovery – and what happens now?
articles.trailText: The future of some of the world’s most prominent media and entertainment businesses hangs in the balance
articles.summary: Paramount Skydance has launched a $108.4bn hostile bid for Warner Bros Discovery (WBD), outbidding Netflix’s $82.7bn offer for its studio and HBO assets. Netflix’s deal, endorsed by WBD’s board, would spin off cable networks like CNN and Discovery, paying shareholders $23.25 cash plus $4.50 in stock per share. Paramount’s all-cash proposal covers WBD in full at $30 per share, directly appealing to shareholders and claiming higher regulatory approval odds. WBD will advise investors on Paramount’s approach by January 8. Both bids face antitrust scrutiny amid political pressure.

articles.title: Paramount launches $108.4bn hostile bid for Warner Bros Discovery
articles.trailText: Paramount’s bid for the entire company counters $82.7bn Netflix deal for WBD’s studio and streaming operation
articles.summary: Paramount Skydance, backed by David and Larry Ellison plus Affinity Partners, Saudi PIF and Qatar’s QIA, launched a $108.4bn all-cash hostile tender offer for Warner Bros Discovery, eclipsing Netflix’s $82.7bn bid for WBD’s studio and HBO assets. Paramount argues its superior premium, full-company scope and regulatory viability deliver better value for shareholders. WBD will review the proposal within two weeks. Netflix, confident in its deal, downplays the rival offer. WBD’s board faces pressure over fairness, while political ties to the Trump administration add weight to the Ellison-backed bid.

articles.title: Anglo American’s merger bonus was a pay wheeze too far | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Miner will have to do things by the book after ditching plan to pay bosses millions in bonuses after Teck deal
articles.summary: Anglo American proposed a back-door pay rise for CEO Duncan Wanblad via ‘resolution 2’ of its $50bn Teck merger, amending 2024–25 long-term incentive plans to guarantee a 62.5% payout (~£8.5m) on deal completion. Major investors, including Legal & General IM, objected that hijacking LTIPs undermines five-year performance measures. Faced with shareholder revolt, Anglo withdrew the plan and will publish an updated directors’ remuneration policy next year. Wanblad still stands to benefit if share prices rise post-merger, but governance norms remain intact.

articles.title: Bank of England cutting jobs as part of overhaul after critical Bernanke review
articles.trailText: Bank under budget pressure as it responds to former Fed chair’s report into slow response to surging inflation
articles.summary: The Bank of England, under budget pressure after Ben Bernanke’s critique of its forecasting failures, has opened a voluntary departure scheme—running until mid-January with March exits—as part of a multiyear efficiency and transformation drive. Staff choosing to leave will receive standard redundancy terms: 10% of salary per year of service, capped at £150,000 or two years’ pay. This overhaul accompanies updates to forecasting models and rate-communications and follows a rise in headcount to 5,731. The BoE is also expanding its Leeds office to 500 staff by 2027 and is expected to cut interest rates next week to 3.75%.

articles.title: Divided Fed ponders US interest-rate cut at end of tumultuous year
articles.trailText: Markets expect final rate cut amid pressure from Trump as Jay Powell urges central bank to proceed with caution
articles.summary: With rates at 3.75–4%, a divided Fed meets for its final 2025 decision amid scarce post–shutdown data. Officials are split on a third cut after September and October half-point reductions, balancing rising inflation (2.3%→3%) against growing unemployment (4%→4.4%). Chair Jay Powell urges caution—“driving in the fog”—as markets price in another cut Wednesday. Data gaps from the six-week shutdown leave analysts guessing. Meanwhile, Trump is eyeing NEC director Kevin Hassett as Powell’s potential successor, favoring deeper cuts to spur growth without stoking prices.

articles.title: Anglo American drops plan to pay bosses millions in bonuses after $50bn Teck merger backlash
articles.trailText: FTSE 100 miner’s U-turn follows investor opposition to payouts when deal completes, including estimated £8.5m to CEO
articles.summary: Anglo American has abandoned a proposal to grant multimillion-pound bonuses—£8.5m to CEO Duncan Wanblad and enhanced long-term incentive awards guaranteeing at least 62.5% of share awards for senior executives—contingent on its planned $50bn merger with Canadian rival Teck Resources, after investors and ISS objected that linking payouts to deal completion contravened best practice and diluted performance metrics. The FTSE 100 miner will now re-engage on director pay ahead of its AGM, just one day before the pivotal shareholder vote on forming a leading global copper producer.

articles.title: ‘We’ll never be able to rebuild’: despair of ex-Vodafone franchisees and pressures on their mental health
articles.trailText: Experiences raise questions about how telecoms firm treated small business owners, whose commission it cut
articles.summary: In August 2018 former Vodafone retail manager Adrian Howe took his own life days before opening two franchise stores under personal guarantees. His family and 62 ex-franchisees now suing Vodafone for £78m–£85m allege the telecoms giant unjustly enriched itself by slashing sales commissions by over 40% in 2020, forcing them to run loss-making outlets and triggering severe anxiety, depression and suicidal thoughts. A 2020 survey found 78 of 119 respondents blamed Vodafone for mental-health crises. Vodafone rejects undue pressure, labels the dispute commercial, and says it has paid at least £21m in contractual or “goodwill” payments.

articles.title: Extracting hangovers from beer: inside Budweiser owner’s ‘nolo’ brewery in south Wales
articles.trailText: AB InBev unveils its ‘de-alcoholisation’ annex at Magor site as demand for once ‘lousy’ low- or no-alcohol beer rises
articles.summary: AB InBev has opened a £3.9m de-alcoholisation annex at its Magor, South Wales brewery - one of the world's largest - using vacuum distillation to strip alcohol while preserving flavour in Budweiser, Corona and Stella Artois variants. The move targets surging UK demand for low- and no-alcohol nolo beer - now 2% of the £13.5bn market - fuelled by health-conscious zebra stripers and weekday drinkers. With 29 0.0 brands, including Corona Cero and Budweiser Zero, AB InBev cites a 27% revenue lift and predicts UK volume share could hit 4% by 2029. Government relief on business rates and local job protection underscore the strategic push amid industry cost pressures.

articles.title: ‘Zombie’ electricity projects in Britain face axe to ease quicker grid connections
articles.trailText: Backlog delaying ‘shovel-ready’ ventures will be cleared with aim of building virtually zero-carbon power system by 2030
articles.summary: Britain’s grid operator (Neso) will ax over half of the 700GW backlog of “zombie” electricity generation and storage projects to clear the queue for £40bn of shovel-ready schemes crucial for a near-zero carbon power system by 2030. A new delivery pipeline totalling 283GW will fast-track projects for connection by 2030 with the remainder by 2035. Nearly half the 2030 capacity is solar and batteries, a third wind, and only 3% gas. Energy secretary Ed Miliband and taskforce head Chris Stark say the reforms unlock clean power growth. The overhaul coincides with the UK marking 25 years of offshore wind.

articles.title: Keir Starmer to make Iceland boss Richard Walker a Labour peer
articles.trailText: Appointment marks a rapid political transformation for a former Tory donor and potential candidate for MP
articles.summary: Richard Walker, the former Tory donor and Iceland supermarket boss, is to be elevated to the House of Lords as a Labour peer by Keir Starmer in December’s 25-peer appointment. Named a prospective Tory MP candidate just over three years ago and having donated £10,000 to Boris Johnson’s government, Walker has since criticized the Conservatives for drifting from core economic principles and backed Labour in early 2024. As a peer, he aims to champion inclusive growth, closer EU ties and a positive economic message, adding a rare business voice amid debates over national insurance and business rates.

articles.title: Bill Kingdom obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Leader of water supply and sanitation projects for the World Bank
articles.summary: Bill Kingdom, who died aged 69, was a global leader in water supply and sanitation with the World Bank from 1999 to 2019. He pioneered innovative financial and governance frameworks across south and east Asia, southern Africa and the Middle East, extending clean, affordable water to impoverished communities. Earlier at Mott MacDonald and the UK’s Water Research Centre he led major projects in Indonesia and Oman. After retirement he consulted and taught at Oxford. Stoic through a final brain tumour, he is survived by his wife, three children and two grandchildren.

articles.title: Let it be: Paul McCartney urges EU to drop ban on veggie ‘burgers’ and ‘sausages’
articles.trailText: Former Beatle argues use of terms for meat-free products ‘encourages attitudes essential to our health’
articles.summary: Paul McCartney and eight British MPs have written to the European Commission urging it to overturn a European Parliament-approved ban on using “burger,” “sausage,” “steak” and “escalope” for plant-based products, arguing the restrictions address no real problem, undermine climate goals and will yield unappetizing labels like “discs” or “tubes.” McCartney, a longtime vegetarian advocate and co-founder of Linda McCartney Foods and the Meat Free Monday campaign, says “plant-based,” “vegetarian” or “vegan” qualifiers suffice. Opponents, including meat industry lobbies, fear job loss, while the EU’s 355–247 vote contrasts with broader geographical indication protections. MPs signatories include Jeremy Corbyn, Carla Denyer and Adrian Ramsay.

articles.title: Forcing UK banks to support credit unions would help keep loan sharks at bay | Heather Stewart
articles.trailText: High street banks dodged a windfall tax – now they should invest in growth of local lenders
articles.summary: Nikhil Rathi, FCA chief, visited Rochdale to launch a report supporting a pledge to double the UK’s mutuals sector, including 350 credit unions holding £4.9bn in assets. The FCA and Treasury propose easing legal “common bonds” and a £30m IT modernisation fund to help low-income consumers avoid loan sharks. Despite this, Fair4All Finance found 1.9m Britons still use illegal lenders. Campaigners and experts urge a new “Fair Banking Act” modelled on the US Community Reinvestment Act to force high-street banks to invest in credit unions and CDFIs, potentially boosting annual lending to £3bn.

articles.title: The K-shaped Christmas: wealthy few drive holiday spending splurge while many struggle to get by
articles.trailText: A soaring stock market rewards the already well-off but Trump’s handling of the economy has caused his approval ratings to plunge
articles.summary: Amid a K-shaped recovery, surging stock markets have enriched the top 10%—the S&P 500 is up 86% over five years—fueling lavish holiday spending at stores like Printemps, while half of Americans own barely 1% of stocks and struggle with rising grocery, healthcare and housing costs. Inflation edges up, Trump’s tariffs add $1,700 annual costs, anti-poverty cuts worsen poverty, and his inflation approval dropped to -35%, as Republicans brace for tough midterms. CEOs cite premium sales growth alongside budget consumer strain.

articles.title: Ministers urged to close £2bn tax loophole in car finance scandal
articles.trailText: Banks and specialist lenders will not pay tax on compensation payouts, sidestepping 2015 rule
articles.summary: MPs led by Lib Dem Bobby Dean demand ministers close a loophole letting banks’ non-bank motor finance arms and specialist lenders (e.g. Barclays, Santander UK, Lloyds’ Black Horse, Honda, Ford) deduct up to £11bn in redress payouts from profits before corporation tax, sidestepping a 2015 ban and cutting Treasury revenue by £2bn over 2025–27 (OBR). The FCA’s consultation on its car finance compensation scheme closes imminently amid lender and FLA lobbying. Treasury pledges orderly resolution but declines comment on tax relief.

articles.title: BP to scrap paid rest breaks and most bank holiday bonuses for forecourt staff
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Plans to offset increase in minimum ‘fair pay’ set by Living Wage Foundation will affect 5,400 employees
articles.summary: BP will eliminate paid 20-30min rest breaks and reduce bank holiday premium pay for 5,400 staff at its 310 company-owned UK forecourts from February to offset a mandated living wage rise from £12.60 to £13.45 (6.7%). Workers warn this stealth move cuts take-home pay by about 6.25%, nullifying almost all of the hourly increase. The changes—framed as benefit restructuring—apply only to company-run sites; 850 partner-operated forecourts use separate pay deals. BP says it’s benchmarking industry standards and will implement the wage hike two months early, while the TUC decries it as an unfair pay reduction.

articles.title: Financial markets now certain the RBA will hike interest rates in 2026
articles.trailText: The changed outlook is a result of unwelcome inflation data, but could slow down the hot property market
articles.summary: Financial markets now fully price an RBA rate hike in 2026, reversing from expectations of cuts after October CPI rose to 3.8%, above the 2–3% target. Traders see no further cuts and start pricing in rises from February. Higher repayments loom for 85,000 first-home buyers who benefited from three cuts in 2025. Fixed rates under 5% are dwindling. Westpac projects 8% national home price growth in 2025, trimmed to 6% for 2026 on this outlook. The RBA is forecast to hold at 3.6% next week, though markets may test its resolve.

articles.title: UK first-time buyers in best position to snap up property in a decade, data shows
articles.trailText: Halifax says average price of house was a record £299,892 in November but that affordability is at its strongest since 2015
articles.summary: Halifax reports UK first-time buyers are in their strongest position since 2015, even as average house prices hit a record £299,892 in November. Affordability—price-to-income ratios—improved thanks to easing lender criteria and a 4.85% average two-year fixed rate, bringing mortgage costs to a three-year low as a share of incomes. Annual price growth slowed to 0.7%. Halifax expects gradual growth into 2026 amid looming rate cuts, noting a north-south divide: London and the south-east fell while Scotland, the north-west and Northern Ireland (up 9%) led gains. Nationwide adds prices proved resilient pre-budget and that a new “mansion tax” will have limited market impact.

articles.title: Skipton in Yorkshire named happiest place to live in Great Britain
articles.trailText: Access to nature and essential services and friendliness of the people led ‘gateway to the Dales’ to top Rightmove index
articles.summary: Skipton, a Yorkshire market town nicknamed the ‘gateway to the Dales’ and home to a medieval castle, is Britain’s happiest place to live, topping Rightmove’s 14th annual ‘Happy at Home’ index. Residents cited access to nature and green spaces, a friendly community, essential services and affordability—average asking price £326,093 below the £364,833 national average. First-time top finisher (after second in 2020 and sixth last year), Skipton beat Richmond upon Thames and Camden. Local leaders praised strong community ties, transport links to Leeds, Bradford and Harrogate, and outdoor pursuits along the Leeds & Liverpool canal, moors and Pennine Way.

articles.title: ‘Tough market conditions’ hit UK half-year retail sales at Frasers Group
articles.trailText: Owner of Sports Direct chain says consumer confidence ‘very subdued’ with sales at sports division down 5.8%
articles.summary: Frasers Group, owner of Sports Direct, Flannels and House of Fraser, reported a 5.8% decline in UK sports division sales to £1.3 bn in H1 to Oct 26, citing heavy rival discounting and ‘very subdued’ consumer confidence. Despite a 5% rise in group sales to £2.6 bn and operating profits up 18% to £219.8 m, pre-tax profits nearly doubled to £412 m thanks to an increased Hugo Boss stake. Premium division revenues fell 3.7% amid store closures. CEO Michael Murray warned of tough market conditions and excess inventory, remaining cautious on FY26 while targeting up to £600 m in full-year profits.

articles.title: Dryrobe wins trademark case against rival waterproof changing coat D-Robe
articles.trailText: Favourite with cold water swimmers wins court case in London forcing brand to stop selling infringing items
articles.summary: Dryrobe has won a High Court ruling forcing rival D-Robe to cease selling infringing waterproof changing coats within a week. Judge Melissa Clarke found D-Robe had intentionally passed off its towel-lined changing robes as Dryrobe products, citing a high degree of visual similarity likely to mislead consumers. Founded in 2010 by Gideon Bright, Dryrobe’s sales surged from £1.3m in 2017 to £20.3m in 2021 before easing to £18m last year amid rising competition. The brand, credited with popularising outdoor swimming apparel during Covid lockdowns, defends against genericide and plans overseas expansion as D-Robe rebrands to Delta Roam.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves will not be investigated over pre-budget briefing, FCA says
articles.trailText: Regulator leaves door open for follow-up as it rejects calls for formal inquiry into claims against Treasury officials
articles.summary: FCA chief executive Nikhil Rathi told Treasury committee chair Meg Hillier the regulator has not commenced an enforcement investigation into potential market abuse around pre-budget briefings by Rachel Reeves and Treasury officials, rejecting calls from MPs including shadow chancellor Mel Stride for a formal probe. The FCA will review the Treasury’s own inquiry into leaks and requested details of the security process review led by permanent secretary James Bowler. It also plans to consider the OBR’s internal report on the early release of its Economic and Fiscal Outlook following chair Richard Hughes’s resignation over the breach.

articles.title: What has gone wrong at Zipcar – and is UK car-sharing market dead?
articles.trailText: Vehicle hire firms have struggled to succeed in London but other European countries offer examples to follow
articles.summary: Zipcar will exit the UK on Jan 1, abandoning over 500,000 London members and disrupting services like Rotherhithe Community Kitchen’s food deliveries. Parent Avis Budget flagged a £11.7 m UK loss in 2024 as trips fell under cost-of-living pressures. London’s fragmented borough parking fees and new e-car congestion charges contrast with Europe’s national car-share frameworks—Germany mandates 5.4 shared cars per 10,000 people. Operators from fleet models (Co-Wheels, GreenMobility) to peer-to-peer apps (Hiyacar, Turo) eye the gap, urging unified permits and integration with public transport.

articles.title: UK’s small brewers call for chancellor to think again on business rates
articles.trailText: Trade group tells Rachel Reeves her property tax changes threaten the survival of community pubs
articles.summary: UK’s Society of Independent Brewers (about 700 members) urged Chancellor Rachel Reeves to rethink business rates reforms, warning upcoming property revaluations and phased relief will push community pubs toward closure. They say although Reeves cut small hospitality rates funded by higher levies on major firms, pubs face 76% rate hikes by 2029 versus 16% for online giants, stifling investment and hiring amid rising costs and weak trade. They urge delayed revaluations or steeper discounts to protect local breweries, warning closures hit record highs with 100+ lost last year.

articles.title: Fossil-fuel billionaires bought up millions of shares after meeting with top Trump officials
articles.trailText: Co-founders’ acquisition of Venture Global shares before key permit granted draws scrutiny as pair deny wrongdoing
articles.summary: Two fossil-fuel billionaires and Venture Global co-chairs, Robert Pender and Michael Sabel, bought nearly 1.2m company shares each in mid-March—days after energy secretary Chris Wright issued a key permit for the firm’s Plaquemines-parish LNG terminal. The purchases follow an April 2024 Mar-a-Lago meeting with top Trump officials, Trump’s rollback of LNG permits and Venture Global’s March IPO. Ethics experts demand probes over potential conflicts; the company and White House deny wrongdoing as shares trade 67% below IPO.

articles.title: Refinancing is delayed at Thames Water. If Ofwat is playing hard, it should keep going | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Discussions are ‘taking longer than expected’, which may mean regulator is tearing chunks out of creditors’ proposal
articles.summary: Thames Water’s refinancing has stalled as Ofwat prolongs talks over creditors’ debt write-down and equity recapitalisation plan. Investors proposed a £4bn (25%) haircut on Class A debt and £3.15bn equity injection, but Ofwat is pushing for larger write-downs, clearer £20bn capital spending priorities, and robust performance-linked fines. Ministers favour a market-led rescue to avoid special administration, yet US hedge funds like Elliott Management may dominate. Nils Pratley argues the regulator should maintain leverage, enforcing tougher terms and not concede leniency, to safeguard customers and ensure a resilient turnaround.

articles.title: Advertising giant WPP relegated from FTSE 100 after nearly 30 years
articles.trailText: Market value of ad group that was once world’s largest plummets from about £24bn in 2017 to £3.1bn
articles.summary: Advertising group WPP, a FTSE 100 mainstay since 1998, has been dropped after its market value fell from £24 bn in 2017 to £3.1 bn and shares plunged two-thirds this year. Struggling to retain clients and lagging rivals in AI and data, it issued two profit warnings as new CEO Cindy Rose launched a strategic review. British Land, valued at over £4 bn, replaces WPP in the blue-chip index. Analysts warn Rose has about a year to restore growth or face break-up or takeover, marking the end of an era for Britain’s global ad leader.

articles.title: Post Office avoids fine over leak of wrongfully convicted operators��� names
articles.trailText: ICO reprimands company over accidental publishing of data about people caught up in Horizon IT scandal
articles.summary: The Post Office was reprimanded by the Information Commissioner’s Office after its press team accidentally published an unredacted June 2024 settlement document, exposing names, addresses and operator status of 502 of 555 claimants in the Horizon IT scandal. The ICO found that inadequate technical and organisational measures—no documented publication policies, QA or staff training—made the breach entirely preventable. Though initially considering a £1.09m fine, the ICO deemed it non-egregious. The Open Rights Group condemned the lack of legal force. Postmasters had previously settled for £57.75m (2019) and were exonerated by parliament in May 2025.

articles.title: EU looks at legally forcing industries to reduce purchases from China
articles.trailText: Commission unveils €3bn strategy to de-risk and diversify supply chains for critical rare earth metals and elements
articles.summary: EU industry commissioner Stéphane Séjourné unveiled a €3bn ReSourceEU programme to de-risk and diversify supply chains for critical raw materials by funding 25–30 projects including Greenland molybdenum and German lithium mines, restricting scrap metals exports, recycling battery magnets and creating a €2bn/yr EIB fund. Firms will be urged—and ultimately may be legally obliged—to cut Chinese imports of rare earths and permanent magnets (now 85–90% China-sourced). A raw-materials platform and joint stockpiles aim to cushion future market shocks after Beijing’s export curbs.

articles.title: Historic Smithfield and Billingsgate markets find new home in Docklands
articles.trailText: City of London corporation names Albert Island near City airport in Docklands for meat and fish markets
articles.summary: After nearly eight centuries in central London, Smithfield meat market and Billingsgate fish market will move to Albert Island, a 10ha brownfield site in Newham’s Royal Docks, under a City of London Corporation proposal. The new “New Smithfield” and “New Billingsgate” estates alongside a shipyard, marina and food school are set to create 2,200 jobs, generate £750m local spend and retain apprenticeship programmes. Traders can remain at current sites until 2028 while planning permissions and a developer are secured. Governed by acts of parliament, the markets require a private bill to close, and this plan ensures continuity of 10% of London’s meat and fish trade.

articles.title: HSBC has a new chair but the succession process should have been slicker
articles.trailText: This is the UK’s second-largest listed company, and the European bank most exposed to declining US-China relations
articles.summary: HSBC appointed 76-year-old Brendan Nelson as chair, succeeding Sir Mark Tucker, but the board’s messy succession plan has raised eyebrows. Interim chair Nelson, a former KPMG partner and non-executive director, lacks major banking or FTSE 100 chair experience and has an uncertain tenure. CEO Georges Elhedery’s comments suggesting Nelson declined a full six-to-nine-year term fueled doubts. Other candidates like George Osborne and Kevin Sneader were considered. With half its revenues from China/Hong Kong and US-China tensions mounting, HSBC needs a smoother, geopolitically savvy process for selecting chairs.

articles.title: UK using more wood to make electricity than ever, Drax figures show
articles.trailText: Giant biomass plant reveals burning of wood pellets made 9% of UK’s electricity in July, its largest ever monthly share
articles.summary: Britain’s biomass generation hit a record 9% of electricity in July and peaked at 17% one morning in September, according to Drax data. Under a new subsidy deal, Drax will earn over £1m daily but face reduced operating hours—just over 25%, down from nearly 65%. Subsidies originally due to end in 2026 now extend to 2031 at £458.6m annually. Environmental groups and Stand.earth report burning of 250-year-old Canadian trees, despite Drax’s claim of sustainable sourcing. Analysts warn of reliance on polluting fuels, urging faster wind and solar growth. Government says support is halved, saving households about £6 per year.

articles.title: Design boss behind new Jaguar leaves JLR weeks after change of CEO
articles.trailText: Gerry McGovern reportedly removed from role of chief creative officer after 20 years with business
articles.summary: Gerry McGovern, Jaguar Land Rover���s design chief for 20 years, has been removed as chief creative officer just four months after Tata-owned JLR appointed PB Balaji as CEO. McGovern, responsible for the Range Rover Evoque, flagship Range Rover and the polarising pink Type 00 electric Jaguar that drew criticism from Donald Trump and Elon Musk, leaves amid a recent cyber-attack that halted JLR production. Observers call his abrupt exit a symbolic end to his era and a sign Tata Motors may tighten control. His departure casts doubt on the future styling of JLR’s forthcoming electric Jaguar and Range Rover models.

articles.title: HSBC appoints interim chair Brendan Nelson to permanent role
articles.trailText: Questions raised about permanency of 76-year-old’s appointment and ‘leadership stability at critical juncture for bank’
articles.summary: HSBC has named former KPMG partner Brendan Nelson, 76, as its permanent chair after a protracted search for Mark Tucker’s successor that saw external candidates like George Osborne and Kevin Sneader courted. Nelson, interim chair since October, brings deep financial services experience but has signalled he won’t serve the full six‐to‐nine‐year term, prompting investor concerns over leadership stability and succession planning. His appointment ends a governance gap but raises questions about when the bank might restart its search. HSBC shares dipped 1% on the news.

articles.title: Thames Water faces collapse as crisis talks take ‘longer than expected’
articles.trailText: Debt-ridden utility company warns of ‘material uncertainty’ despite seeing profits rise to more than £400m
articles.summary: Despite swinging to a £414m half-year profit thanks to a 31% bill hike and 40% revenue rise, Thames Water warns of “material uncertainty” over its future as crisis talks with its £17.6bn net debt holders drag into 2026. Lenders, led by Elliott and Silver Point, seek leniency on environmental fines, arguing potential penalties hamper a turnaround. The company has cut sewage spills by 20% and boosted investment by 22%, but faces risk of a special administration regime takeover if refinancing terms aren’t agreed, while government resists pollution-fine waivers.

articles.title: There are two big drivers of Australia’s economic growth – but shape matters as much as size | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: Income from rooftop solar panels and investment in data centres are helping to power the economy, which leads us to the question: is all growth good?
articles.summary: Australia’s economy grew 2.1% over the past year, driven largely by household income gains from rooftop solar and superannuation re-measurements, alongside private investment in datacentres. Including solar income boosted living standards around 3% above 2020 levels, helped by lower mortgage rates, while higher household spending has skewed towards essentials—electricity, gas and health. Yet data-centre expansion, underpinned by AI and cloud demand, is powering machinery and equipment investment but risks increasing electricity demand and emissions, potentially undermining climate targets. These contrasting drivers highlight why the 'shape' of growth—in its composition and environmental impact—matters as much as its size.

articles.title: UK temporary workers: tell us have you received less holiday pay than you are due?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from temporary workers in the UK who have not received their correct holiday pay by their agency
articles.summary: Harrods warehouse staff were underpaid thousands of pounds after their temporary staffing agency neglected correct holiday pay entitlements. The Guardian is now appealing for UK temporary workers supplied to any prominent business to share experiences of withheld holiday pay. If you suspect your agency has shortchanged your statutory leave pay, submit details via the designated form. Journalists may follow up your submission for an in-depth investigation. Your insights will contribute to a broader series examining pay practices across the UK temporary work sector. For assistance with the form, refer to the help link; review terms of service and privacy policy before responding.

articles.title: Airbus cuts plane delivery target amid A320 fuselage problem
articles.trailText: Output reduction to ‘around 790’ planes comes after French firm issued recall over software glitch affecting 6,000 jets
articles.summary: Airbus has trimmed its 2025 delivery guidance from 820 to around 790 jets after discovering fuselage panel defects on its A320 family. Supplier Sofitec Aero produced metal skins behind the cockpit doors at incorrect thickness, prompting inspections of 628 aircraft—168 in service, 245 on production lines and 215 in subassembly. This follows a recent software glitch recall affecting 6,000 A320s but poses no safety risk. Despite the setback, Airbus maintains its €7bn operating profit target. Shares rose over 2%, and November delivery figures are due Friday.

articles.title: Chop and change: pork is ‘new beef’ for money-saving Britons, report finds
articles.trailText: As beef price inflation soars to 27%, customers are turning to cheaper pork alternatives, Waitrose says
articles.summary: Waitrose’s annual food & drink report finds UK shoppers swapping expensive beef (27–37% inflation) for premium pork cuts—fillets, ribs, T-bones and rib-eyes—as pork mince sales climb 16%, lasagne with pork mince searches double and pulled pork nachos searches rise 45%. Pork fillet costs £20/kg versus £80/kg for beef. AHDB data show pork mince volumes up 36.6% and chicken mince up 65.6%, reflecting budget-driven shifts.

articles.title: Australian economy crawls back into growth mode thanks to datacentre boom and household spending uptick
articles.trailText: Analysts say national accounts figures show how far the economy has come, with annual GDP growth hitting 2.1% compared to 0.8% this time last year
articles.summary: Australia’s annual GDP growth accelerated to 2.1% in the year to September (from 0.8% a year earlier), led by a 2.9% surge in private investment—chiefly major data-centre projects in NSW and Victoria—and a rise in household spending on essentials (electricity, rent, food, health). Quarterly GDP climbed just 0.4% (below forecasts) and per-capita output was flat, while inflation at 3.8% and capacity pressures leave the RBA weighing future rate hikes. Productivity remains weak at 0.8%, savings rose to 6.4%, discretionary outlays eased.

articles.title: Production of French-German fighter jet threatened by rivalries, chief executive says
articles.trailText: Relations between French company Dassault and the German unit of Airbus are reportedly ‘very strained’
articles.summary: Safran CEO Olivier Andriès warned that bitter rivalries between France’s Dassault and Germany’s Airbus unit threaten the Future Combat Air System (Scaf), a next-generation 6th-gen fighter jet project. Despite “very strained” ties over leadership, presidents Macron and Merz still back a political solution. Safran and Germany’s MTU Engines report smooth collaboration on turbines. Concurrently, Safran lobbied UK ministers for investment in Buckinghamshire electric-motor facilities to develop rare-earth-free magnets amid China’s export controls. The group is also preparing for new civil engine programmes with both open-fan and conventional ducted designs via CFM International ahead of Airbus and Boeing’s single-aisle jet plans.

articles.title: Tunbridge Wells water cut likely to last after treatment problem reoccurs
articles.trailText: Thousands of homes, schools and businesses expected to be without supply for at least another day
articles.summary: South East Water’s accidental use of a faulty coagulant at its Pembury treatment plant since Saturday has cut off tap supplies for about 18,000 homes, schools and businesses in Tunbridge Wells, forcing closures and prompting reliance on bottled-water stations and rainwater. Elderly residents report delivery failures, and local MP Mike Martin has urged CEO David Hinton to resign over poor communication. The Drinking Water Inspectorate and DEFRA are investigating. The plant has reopened but recurring quality issues delay full restoration amid warnings of discoloured water during network recharge.

articles.title: Fiscal headroom is a matter of guesswork | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Economic obsession | Two-child benefit divide | Paddington stare | No Place | Word of the year
articles.summary: Prof Costas Milas warns that five-year fiscal headroom forecasts are guesswork, likening economics to Russell’s quip on mathematical uncertainty. Readers also clash over the timing and removal of the two-child benefit cap; puzzle fans blame a new Paddington-stare cat for harder crosswords; villagers debate blank signage for No Place; and OUP’s naming of “rage bait” as word of the year prompts spelling objections.

articles.title: OBR chief’s exit may ease pressure on Rachel Reeves but the battle isn’t over
articles.trailText: With the row deepening over budget leaks, who is most likely to replace Richard Hughes in the increasingly thankless role of chair?
articles.summary: Richard Hughes resigned as OBR chair after accidental leaks of Rachel Reeves’s budget forecasts strained relations with the Treasury. Leaks of pre-budget productivity reviews and government briefings misrepresented OBR forecasts, prompting Hughes’s departure and concerns over the watchdog’s independence. His exit, criticized by Jonathan Portes and Andrew Bailey, heightens scrutiny of fiscal governance. Potential successors include Clare Lombardelli, Carl Emmerson, Conrad Smewing or Nick Joicey. The new chair must secure assurances of autonomy amid political pressures over policy scoring and fiscal credibility, as bond investors watch for evidence of robust, independent oversight.

articles.title: BoE governor says it has not forgotten lessons of financial crisis, as it eases capital rules
articles.trailText: Bank of England’s move risks stoking concerns about weakening protections against UK bank failures
articles.summary: Bank of England to lower bank capital requirements by 1pp to about 13% from 2027—the first cut since the 2008 crisis—to boost lending. Governor Andrew Bailey insists the move reflects banking health and retains crisis lessons amid Chancellor Reeves’ push for growth-friendly rules. New stress tests show seven major UK banks can weather a severe downturn, but the FPC flags rising stability risks from AI valuation bubbles and private credit exposures. Deputy Governor Breeden warns against further reductions.

articles.title: Bid by Gina Rinehart’s company to build helipad set to be blocked by City of Perth
articles.trailText: Hancock says facility is ‘modern necessity’ but opponents argue the noise would disrupt local businesses
articles.summary: Hancock Iron Ore, owned by Gina Rinehart, seeks approval to install a rooftop helipad atop its new West Perth headquarters at 53 Ord Street. City of Perth planning officers recommended blocking the proposal citing potential noise, vibration, asbestos risks, lack of public benefit and flight-path constraints on surrounding developments. Hancock argues the pad—limited to 12 daylight flights annually—meets global business needs, offers emergency back-up and aligns with modern urban connectivity. The application faces 29 objections, a pending council vote and possible state-government appeal.

articles.title: OBR complained to Treasury before budget about leaks spreading ‘misconceptions’
articles.trailText: Official tells MPs there was lots of information appearing in the press that ‘wasn’t particularly helpful’
articles.summary: In evidence to the Treasury select committee, OBR’s David Miles revealed the watchdog had warned Treasury officials before the budget about a spate of leaks misrepresenting its forecasts, including alleged last-minute swings and shifted bond‐yield assessment periods. He disputed claims that these leaks signalled improved fiscal headroom or misled Chancellor Rachel Reeves. The controversy led to OBR chair Richard Hughes’ resignation after premature document release and an explanatory letter outlining forecast evolution. Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey and former chair Robert Chote defended the OBR’s independence and urged less politicized leaks.

articles.title: OECD warns Reeves higher taxes and spending restraint will limit consumer expenditure
articles.trailText: UK economy will grow faster than France, Germany and Italy but slower than US next year, report predicts
articles.summary: The OECD warns that UK chancellor Rachel Reeves's fiscal consolidation—£26bn of tax rises including freezing income tax thresholds and spending restraint—will curb household disposable income, slowing consumption despite upgrading UK growth to 1.2% in 2025 (outpacing France, Germany and Italy but below 1.7% in the US). It predicts inflation will return to 2% by mid-2027, prompting two Bank of England rate cuts to 3.5% by Q2 2026. Meanwhile, OBR chair Richard Hughes resigned amid a protocol breach over budget information and a dispute with Reeves. Globally, growth will ease to 3.2% in 2025 and 2.9% in 2026.

articles.title: ‘The Chinese will not pause’: Volvo and Polestar bosses urge EU to stick to 2035 petrol car ban
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Swedish carmakers push to retain target as Germany lobbies to help its own industry by softening cutoff date
articles.summary: German chancellor Friedrich Merz has asked EU president Ursula von der Leyen to allow new hybrids post-2035, arguing consumer hesitance to buy EVs, but Green MEPs warn this would fatally weaken climate legislation. In response, Polestar CEO Michael Lohscheller and Volvo’s Håkan Samuelsson call upholding the 2035 ban essential to accelerate EV adoption, meet consumer concerns on range, charging and cost, and to prevent China from dominating future markets. They liken any delay to rolling back mandatory seatbelts, urging Brussels to stay its course, prioritize innovation, and align with the EU’s 2050 carbon neutrality goal.

articles.title: Report detailing risks to UK gas security was not one to bury on budget day | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Facts in Neso’s stark assessment have been ignored for years – yet running out could be government-toppling event
articles.summary: Neso's 50-page Budget-day release warns an 'emerging' risk that UK gas supply will fall short across five demand pathways in 2030-31 if the single largest asset—namely the 725-mile Langeled pipeline—fails. Under such a scenario, priority cuts would hit factories and power stations, with households potentially left winter cold. Expanding North Sea output, Norwegian imports, LNG terminals, interconnectors and storage (e.g. Rough) are costly, slow and underfunded. Government pledges 'whatever it takes' but decisive investment and planning are needed to avert a crisis.

articles.title: People living along polluted Thames file legal complaint to force water firm to act
articles.trailText: Residents claim raw sewage and poorly treated effluent as result of Thames Water’s failings are threat to health
articles.summary: Residents in 13 south-east England areas, including Hackney, Oxford and Henley, have filed coordinated statutory nuisance complaints under the Environmental Protection Act against Thames Water, accusing it of failing to upgrade 98 treatment plants and discharging raw sewage and poorly treated effluent—pollution hours at Newbury plant rose 240% (482h to 1,630h 2019–24). After Ofwat refused to pass £1.18bn upgrade costs fully onto customers, allowing only £793m, locals demand urgent action and abatement notices. E. coli sickness cases among rowers, kayakers and children highlight health risks. Thames, fined £104m, plans £9.5bn investment over five years.

articles.title: Zipcar, world’s biggest car-sharing company, to close UK operation
articles.trailText: Move by firm, owned by US group Avis Budget, will remove access to shared fleet across London at end of year
articles.summary: Zipcar, owned by Avis Budget, will close its UK operation and suspend new bookings after 31 December 2025, affecting 71 staff and nearly 3,000 vehicles across London. The shutdown, driven by an £11.7 m loss, rising costs—including a congestion-charge hike adding £1 m annually—and declining revenues, undermines sustainable car-sharing. CoMoUK warns policy gaps as the UK lags behind Europe (0.7 shared cars per 10,000 vs 2.2 in Germany). Zipcar will honour existing bookings and refund subscribers for 2026.

articles.title: OBR chair quits after inquiry into early release of budget document
articles.trailText: Richard Hughes takes ‘full responsibility’ for watchdog error as Starmer attempts to secure chancellor’s position
