articles.summary: OBR chair Richard Hughes resigned after an internal inquiry branded the early online leak of Rachel Reeves’s budget document “the worst failure” in the watchdog’s 15-year history. An add-on glitch made a draft EFO live, accessed 43 times from 32 devices, echoing an unaddressed March breach. Opposition figures demanded Reeves’s exit, but Keir Starmer defended her, citing the budget’s cost-of-living measures, fiscal priorities, closer EU ties and welfare reform. Labour insiders hope Hughes’s departure draws a line under tensions, while critics allege the chancellor misled on fiscal shortfalls that underpinned proposed tax rises.

articles.title: NHS to pay 25% more for innovative drugs after UK–US zero-tariff deal
articles.trailText: Agreement could cost NHS an extra £3bn a year, industry sources estimate
articles.summary: Under a new UK–US drug pricing deal, the NHS will pay 25% more for innovative medicines—adding up to £3 billion annually by 2035—and double its GDP share on new therapies from 0.3% to 0.6%. Tariffs on £6.6 billion of UK-made medicines exported to the US are suspended for three years. NICE will lift its cost-per-QALY threshold from £20k–£30k to £25k–£35k, potentially approving 3–5 extra drugs yearly. Ministers and NHS leaders hail patient access gains and industry boosts, while critics warn of budgetary strain on core services. A new rebate cap will cut manufacturer refunds from up to 35.6% to 15%.

articles.title: How the standoff between Rachel Reeves and the OBR unfolded
articles.trailText: Treasury’s independent economic forecaster says outlook for economy rosier than chancellor led everyone to believe
articles.summary: Rachel Reeves faced scrutiny for allegedly overstating fiscal damage after the OBR’s forecasts proved rosier than she signalled. Between June and November, OBR’s productivity downgrades and later revisions—from a £20bn hole to a £4.2bn surplus—shaped pre-budget debates. Reeves hinted at, then dropped, income tax rises; froze thresholds to raise £7.5bn; and announced £26bn of tax hikes on 26 November. Leaks of OBR forecasts and a delayed disclosure of improved figures fuelled calls for clarity. OBR chair Richard Hughes, “mortified” by the early leak, resigned on 1 December after an inquiry blamed leadership lapses.

articles.title: Manchester-London 7am ‘ghost train’ to carry passengers after outcry over regulator’s decision
articles.trailText: Avanti service was to have been axed from mid-December but would have still run because of needs out of Euston
articles.summary: After backlash, ORR reversed its ruling to operate Avanti’s 7am Manchester-London service as an empty ‘ghost train’ from mid-December. Under pressure from ministers and northern leaders, the regulator will now allow passengers on the only sub-two-hour link, warning of potential West Coast mainline performance impacts but pledging mitigation with Network Rail and Avanti. Running since 2008, the 1h59m express is prized by business travellers and carers. Transport secretary Heidi Alexander cited the need to simplify fragmented rail governance ahead of a new rail bill.

articles.title: OBR says inadvertent budget leak is ‘worst failure’ in its 15-year history
articles.trailText: Investigation finds organisation’s leadership over many years was to blame for error, and similar breach happened earlier this year
articles.summary: After Rachel Reeves’s budget speech on Nov 2025, the OBR reported its Economic and Fiscal Outlook document was mistakenly published online nearly an hour early – its “worst failure” in 15 years. A probe led by Laura Gardiner and Ciaran Martin found long-standing leadership failings and misconfigured pre-publication procedures caused this and a similar March breach. The OBR will audit and bolster security, while also faulting Treasury and Cabinet Office IT. Chief Richard Hughes apologised and may resign if confidence is lost. Reeves denies misleading the public on tax rises.

articles.title: Swiss prosecutors file charges against Credit Suisse and UBS over ‘tuna bonds’ scandal
articles.trailText: Banks accused of ‘organisational deficiencies’ relating to scam that crashed Mozambique economy nearly a decade ago
articles.summary: Swiss federal prosecutors have charged Credit Suisse and its acquirer UBS with organisational deficiencies in anti–money-laundering controls linked to the 2013–16 “tuna bonds” scandal in Mozambique. An unnamed Credit Suisse employee faces money-laundering charges, while both banks are accused of failing to flag $2 bn in government loans—of which $137 m in kickbacks, including $50 m to bankers, went missing—until 2019. The scheme prompted IMF aid suspension and battered Mozambique’s economy. Credit Suisse paid $275 m to US and £147 m to UK regulators in 2021; UBS settled with Mozambique in 2023. UBS rejects the AG’s findings and will defend itself.

articles.title: Airbus finds problem with fuselage panels after fixing software glitch
articles.trailText: Shares in French manufacturer tumble as second problem comes to light after weekend of flight disruption
articles.summary: Airbus has fixed software on the vast majority of 6,000 A320-family jets grounded by a solar-radiation–induced flight-control glitch, leaving fewer than 100 aircraft awaiting an update and up to 15% requiring hardware upgrades, especially on about 900 older planes. Airlines including Delta, United, American, easyJet, Wizz Air and JetBlue completed most updates over Thanksgiving weekend with minimal cancellations. Shares tumbled as much as 6% when Airbus identified a separate quality issue in a limited number of A320 fuselage panels, triggering inspections; new panels now meet requirements and the source has been contained.

articles.title: UK pulls $1.15bn support for Mozambique gas project after climate and terror concerns
articles.trailText: TotalEnergies scheme became lightning rod for terror in region and was accused of violating human rights
articles.summary: UK government has withdrawn a $1.15bn (£870m) export finance package for TotalEnergies’ Mozambique LNG scheme, citing increased climate, human rights and security risks after a jihadist insurgency killed 800 locals in 2021. Business secretary Peter Kyle said Ukef’s comprehensive reassessment showed the project no longer served UK taxpayers. Initially pitched in 2020 to back 2,000 British jobs and supply Centrica with gas, it faced judicial-review bids from Friends of the Earth and Reclaim Finance over community relocations and emissions. NGOs warn international banks to exit and urge renewable investments for Mozambique.

articles.title: Mall-going but budget-constrained: gen-z shoppers shape the future of retail
articles.trailText: Malls are popular with zoomers, but they show less brand loyalty and are happy to settle for ‘dupes’ over the real thing
articles.summary: Gen Z shoppers, squeezed by credit card debt, inflation and student loans, will cut holiday spending by 23% despite a projected $12 trn by 2030. They prize value over brand loyalty—82% hunt for cheaper “dupes” and only 59% stick with established brands—while 58% view malls as social hubs. They demand curated experiences, membership perks and emotional connection rather than hard sells, obsessively researching price, quality and reviews. Gift giving veers toward DIY crafts or experiences, forcing retailers to shift from transactions to authenticity and community.

articles.title: Accenture dubs 800,000 staff ‘reinventors’ amid shift to AI
articles.trailText: Consultancy’s move to embrace artificial intelligence follows Disney’s use of the term ‘imagineers’
articles.summary: Accenture has rebranded its 800,000 employees as “reinventors” after merging its strategy, consulting, creative, tech and operations divisions into “Reinvention Services.” CEO Julie Sweet pushes the label to signal its AI focus—training staff in generative AI and exiting those who can’t adapt. The move echoes past jargon experiments, from Accenture Song to Disney’s “imagineers,” and draws criticism that a universal title risks confusing roles amid 11,000 layoffs, slowing US federal spending and a 7% revenue rise to $69.7bn that still coincides with a share-price slump.

articles.title: From star jumps to job cuts: how Ovo Energy fell from grace
articles.trailText: One-time wunderkind of UK energy market faces battle for new investment – but it continues to pay out millions to its founder’s company
articles.summary: Ovo Energy’s fall began with its “star jumps” gaffe in 2022. Its SSE acquisition propelled founder Stephen Fitzpatrick to billionaire status but the supplier now warns of financial doubts, plans 200 job cuts to meet Ofgem resilience rules and has replaced CEO David Buttress and CFO James Davies with loyal insiders. It’s failing to raise £300m, Mayfair Equity is selling its 30% stake, Verdane and Permira pulled out, Iberdrola talks stalled. Meanwhile, Ovo has paid £122m in brand royalties to Fitzpatrick’s Imagination Industries, drawing scrutiny amid low margins and strict capital requirements from Ofgem.

articles.title: UK refrains from hitting high street on Black Friday as fears grow over economy
articles.trailText: Data comes as KPMG highlights soft consumer spending as one factor likely to hold back growth in 2026
articles.summary: Data from MRI shows UK high street footfall fell 2% on Black Friday and 7.2% year-on-year, with online deals also mixed as cost-of-living pressures curb spending. KPMG’s forecast sees unemployment rising to 5.2%, subdued GDP growth (1% in 2026, 1.4% in 2027) despite green energy and potential housing reforms. CBI’s services survey recorded a three-year low in business optimism, while the IoD’s confidence index languished near record lows (-72). Hospitality firms warn business-rates hikes threaten investment and jobs, as transitional relief merely delays the pain.

articles.title: England’s water industry issued £10.5bn in ‘green bonds’ despite pollution record
articles.trailText: River Action says use of issuance tied to environmental benefits is ‘corporate greenwash on steroids’
articles.summary: Since 2017, English water companies have issued £10.5 bn in "green bonds"—a fifth of UK corporate green bond issuance—tied to environmental projects while facing persistent sewage pollution. Anglian Water and Thames Water issued £3.5bn and £3.1bn respectively. Critics, including River Action, accuse this of “greenwash on steroids” as infrastructure failures continue harming rivers. Thames has missed two years of impact reports, and seeks up to 15-year environmental exemptions in its rescue deal. Industry defenders cite investment in sustainable water management and carbon reductions. Water firms accounted for 19% of all corporate green bond issuance (22% including Thames Tideway’s ‘super sewer’).

articles.title: Expect a tale of two holiday seasons as the well-off spend and the rest pull back | Gene Marks
articles.trailText: Parts of the US economy are doing just fine but many are struggling to make rent, let alone splurging on gifts
articles.summary: In the 2025 holiday season, affluent consumers—supported by 4.5–6.7% salary gains, a 13% stock market rise year-to-date and average household incomes above $125k in hubs like New York, Boston and San Francisco—are still splurging on high-end dining, luxury hotels and premium retail. By contrast, lower-income households face sub-3% wage growth, mounting credit-card debt and rent pressures, prompting significant cutbacks. S&P Global sees nominal holiday sales up 4% but flat in real terms, while Deloitte projects 2.9–3.4% growth—underscoring a bifurcated season where wealthy-area merchants prosper and those in less affluent markets struggle.

articles.title: Bakery chain Gail’s plans to open 40 more outlets as sales soar
articles.trailText: Sales rose to £278m in last finanical year but profit margins were hit by increasing staff and energy costs
articles.summary: Upmarket bakery chain Gail’s, now at 185 sites, plans 40 more after a 20% sales rise to £278m in the year to February; pre-tax losses widened to £7.8m as staff and energy costs surged and £51m was spent on pre-opening fees. Retail arm grew 23% versus slower wholesale supply to Waitrose, Ocado and Amazon. Co-founder Tom Molnar calls expansion “still early”; backed by Bain Capital (£500m valuation) with Goldman Sachs advising, Gail’s credits demand for nutrient-dense food and community support. Founded by Yael Mejia in the 1990s, its rapid growth has prompted local protests and even political use as a bellwether.

articles.title: Is gen Z’s love of fried chicken pushing Britain to ‘peak pizza’?
articles.trailText: Competition intensifies as former chief of Domino’s says days of ‘massive growth’ are over
articles.summary: Domino’s UK chief Andrew Rennie’s sudden exit follows his warning that the pizza market in Britain is nearing saturation: chain outlets fell from 5 000 in 2015 to 3 750 today. Fried chicken shops, boosted by Gen Z usage (52 % vs pizza’s 56 %), are rapidly expanding—Popeyes grew from 32 to 80 sites and KFC’s adding 50+ outlets. Asian-inspired chains and supermarket pizzas also chip in. Yet pizza sales climbed from £1.3 bn to £2.3 bn since 2015, driven by takeaway growth, delivery apps and premium operators.

articles.title: Net migration is plummeting. Why can’t Labour say so? | Heather Stewart
articles.trailText: An honest debate is needed on this polarising topic as sectors such as social care struggle with recruitment
articles.summary: Official figures show net migration plunged 69% from 649,000 to 204,000 in the year to June. Starmer called it “a step in the right direction,” avoiding a frank debate. Migration spikes after Brexit/Covid were “accidents” driven by Homes for Ukraine/Hong Kong schemes (200k), student visas (200k→650k) and extended healthcare visas. Bell warns surges mask policy failures—e.g. social care understaffing, where higher pay could reduce visa reliance. Labour’s £500m fair pay deal by April 2028 falls short, ministers tightened work visas, so net migration must be openly acknowledged and targeted.

articles.title: Harrods warehouse staff underpaid by thousands of pounds after agency error
articles.trailText: Pay mistake is latest setback to image of exclusive Qatar-owned London retailer after a series of crises
articles.summary: Harrods warehouse staff supplied via The Best Connection were underpaid thousands due to a clerical holiday-pay miscalculation, potentially creating a six-figure liability affecting up to 1,000 lower-paid workers. The Qatar-owned retailer, already beset by abuse-compensation and IT breach scandals, discovered after two years of warnings that the agency’s low-ball tender may have relied on under-calculating holiday accruals. The Best Connection attributes it to human error and is repaying impacted staff; legal and sector-wide implications persist.

articles.title: Airbus issues major A320 recall after mid-air incident grounds planes, disrupting global travel
articles.trailText: Immediate software change on ‘significant number’ of jets to result in disruption to half the worldwide fleet
articles.summary: Airbus ordered immediate software and hardware fixes on 6,000 A320-family jets (over half of the 11,300-strong fleet) after EASA and FAA issued emergency directives following a JetBlue October flight-control glitch that injured 15 passengers. The recall mainly reverts to earlier ELAC flight-control software; a smaller subset requires time-intensive hardware modifications. US carriers (American 209 aircraft, Delta <50, United 6), Japan’s ANA (65 flights), Jetstar (90 cancellations), Avianca (>70% of fleet) and others including easyJet, Lufthansa and IndiGo paused or delayed flights, exposing maintenance backlogs and highlighting solar radiation-induced data corruption risks.

articles.title: US small businesses sound alarm over Trump’s tariffs amid crucial holiday season
articles.trailText: Some small business owners doubt that even strong holiday sales will ease impact of tough year plagued by uncertainty
articles.summary: Small business owners warn that President Trump’s tariffs have driven many firms—including toy retailer Queen’s Treasures and holiday-light specialist Village Lighting—to the brink by adding up to $1m in extra costs, eroding margins and wiping out retirement savings. Game Kastle in Maryland reports supply-chain strain and studio closures. A survey of 1,048 small firms found 71% expect reduced holiday spending, 44% have raised prices, and 74% doubt survival over the next year. Owners fear 2026 will be worse without tariff relief, citing complex offshore supply chains. The White House insists tariffs fund trade deals, tax cuts and US investment.

articles.title: Soon-to-be-axed 7am Manchester-London train will still run – but without passengers
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Rail regulator pulls Avanti service from timetable from mid-December but it is needed for staff travel
articles.summary: From mid-December the 07:00 Avanti West Coast Manchester Piccadilly–London Euston service, the only sub-2 hour link and a major peak-time revenue generator (tickets £193–£290), will be removed for passengers yet still run empty on weekdays to reposition crew under the new May-2026 roster. The Office of Rail and Road cites timetable reliability and firebreak path needs to accommodate new Lumo Stirling open-access trains, booking it as empty coaching stock for flexibility. Business travellers now must catch 06:29 departures with 2h15min journeys. Northern leaders warn taxpayers will fund over 100 empty runs, blaming the ORR's competition focus.

articles.title: Jetstar cancels 90 domestic flights across Australia after global Airbus A320 recall
articles.trailText: Immediate software update ordered by Airbus after US mid-air incident causes airport disruption across Australia and New Zealand
articles.summary: Jetstar grounded 34 of its 85 A320s and cancelled 90 flights on Saturday after Airbus mandated a precautionary software reversal and update on thousands of A320s following a mid-air incident on a JetBlue flight. Each 2-3h fix will return 20 aircraft by Saturday evening, with remaining updates overnight. Disruptions may spill into Sunday as Jetstar alerts customers via SMS and email. Qantas A320s are unaffected; Virgin’s Boeing 737s covered its routes. Air New Zealand cancelled 12 services, expecting about 20 total cancellations before schedules normalize on Monday. Airbus cited solar radiation-corrupted flight-control data in its global recall.

articles.title: Asda hits out at government for ‘killing confidence’ among consumers
articles.trailText: But supermarket blames ‘self-inflicted’ IT problems that left gaps on shelves for 3.7% drop in sales
articles.summary: Asda’s sales fell 3.8% to £5.1bn in the three months to September, with like-for-like sales down 2.8%, after ‘self-inflicted’ IT failures during its separation from Walmart left shelf gaps and a flawed new app. Chair Allan Leighton, back at the helm to revive the business, said the issues set turnaround plans back six months but are now resolved. He also blamed the government for ‘killing consumer confidence’ through stagnant growth and investment, as Asda presses ahead with aggressive price cuts, claiming it is 4–7% cheaper than rivals.

articles.title: OBR challenges claims Reeves dropped income tax rise due to rosier forecasts
articles.trailText: Official forecaster’s chair says chancellor knew about revised predictions well before her budget change of heart
articles.summary: OBR chair Richard Hughes has challenged claims that Chancellor Rachel Reeves abandoned a planned income tax rise because of improved forecasts, revealing in a letter to the Treasury select committee that updated OBR forecasts sent on 31 October showed she already had £4.2bn headroom against her fiscal rule. Earlier forecasts on 3 October had predicted a £2.5bn breach. No substantial forecast changes followed after 31 October. Treasury sources insist final decisions awaited forecasts incorporating policy measures, while shadow chancellor Mel Stride accuses Reeves of misleading the public. Tensions between No.11 and the watchdog over timing and assumptions predated the U-turn.

articles.title: Germany to urge EU to soften 2035 ban on sale of new petrol and diesel cars
articles.trailText: Friedrich Merz to ask for series of exemptions in attempt to protect crisis-hit automotive industry
articles.summary: Chancellor Friedrich Merz will press the EU to soften its 2035 ban on new petrol and diesel cars by allowing plug-in hybrids, battery hybrids and range-extended EVs with efficient combustion engines. Backed by SPD finance minister Lars Klingbeil, Berlin argues that technology neutrality and job protection are vital as Germany’s auto sector faces heavy investment costs and Chinese competition. The government also plans a €5,000 subsidy for electric and hybrid models with mainly German components. The European Commission says it is open to “flexibility,” though all-electric makers like Polestar oppose any delay.

articles.title: Ryanair closes frequent flyers club after members take advantage of discounts
articles.trailText: Airline says 55,000 people signed up to Prime, making €4.4m, but passengers benefited by more than €6m
articles.summary: Ryanair is shutting its Prime frequent-flyer club after eight months, citing that 55,000 members generated €4.4m in fees but claimed over €6m in perks (flight discounts, free seat reservations on up to 12 flights and travel insurance). Launched at €79/£79 per year in February, Prime saved heavy flyers €54–€456 annually but proved loss-making. No new sign-ups after 28 November; existing subscribers retain benefits until their 12-month term ends in October 2026 as Ryanair reverts to open discounts for all customers.

articles.title: JP Morgan boss gave go-ahead for new £3bn tower in London after UK assurances
articles.trailText: Decision by US bank’s CEO Jamie Dimon followed trip to New York by top adviser to Keir Starmer
articles.summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon approved a £3bn, 3m sq ft Canary Wharf tower for its UK HQ after senior Starmer envoy Varun Chandra flew to New York to secure reassurances on the government’s pro-business stance. The decision came hours after the autumn budget spared banks a levy rise and followed intense sector lobbying. The development will house over half of JPMorgan’s 23,000 UK staff and, alongside Goldman Sachs’s expansion plans, could deliver £9.9bn to the UK economy over six years.

articles.title: Pub chain Mitchells & Butlers faces £130m hit from rising wage and food costs
articles.trailText: Group, which also owns restaurant brands including Toby Carvery, feels impact of increase in employer NICs
articles.summary: Mitchells & Butlers, owner of All Bar One, Toby Carvery and other restaurant chains, warns of a £130m cost spike next year driven by April’s rise in the national living wage (to £12.71 for over-21s and £10.85 for 18-20s), higher employer NICs and soaring food prices, especially meat. CEO Phil Urban flags ongoing sector cost pressures but remains confident of mitigation. Despite this, M&B shares jumped over 10% on full-year revenues of £2.7bn (+3.5%), pre-tax profit up 20% to £238m and food & drink sales +4.3%. Separately, Whitbread shares fell 5% after Bernstein downgraded the Premier Inn owner, citing potential business-rates hits of up to £140m by year three.

articles.title: Amid ‘instability and fear’ in Trump’s economy, Americans are cutting holiday spending
articles.trailText: In addition to rising prices and tariffs, readers cite growing unemployment as a reason not to exchange gifts this year
articles.summary: US consumers report shrinking holiday budgets as inflation, tariffs and rising unemployment under Trump dent spending. Guardian readers like Grace Brown (Charlotte) and Jeffrey Larimore (Idaho) say higher grocery, insurance and tariff‐driven costs force them to skip gifts, dining out and travel. Consumer confidence fell to April lows, unemployment hit 4.4%, and Deloitte/NRF forecast holiday retail sales down 4%/1.3%. Amid calls to “vote with dollars,” some opt for homemade, thrifted gifts or local artisans while bracing for continued “instability and fear.”

articles.title: US regulators ‘taking seriously’ allegations of bankers’ support for Epstein
articles.trailText: Exclusive: It follows calls from US senator Elizabeth Warren to investigate bank executives including ex-Barclays boss Jes Staley
articles.summary: After Senator Elizabeth Warren’s letter—she is lead Democrat on the Senate banking committee—the OCC and FDIC said they are reviewing allegations that JPMorgan Chase and former Barclays CEO Jes Staley facilitated Jeffrey Epstein’s criminal operations. Comptroller Jonathan Gould and FDIC acting chair Travis Hill pledged to examine potential safety, soundness or legal breaches, risking fines or banking bans. Warren demands formal inquiries and testimony from executives like Jamie Dimon as JPMorgan denies aiding Epstein. Scrutiny heightens with an imminent Justice Department release of unclassified Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell records.

articles.title: ‘A step-change’: tech firms battle for undersea dominance with submarine drones
articles.trailText: As navies seek to counter submarines and protect cables, startups and big defence companies fight to lead market
articles.summary: Navies including the UK, US and Australia are investing billions in autonomous underwater vehicles (UUVs) to hunt submarines and safeguard undersea cables and pipelines. Australia’s $1.7 bn Ghost Shark programme and multiple US Navy UUV projects—some launched from nuclear submarines—underscore a “step-change” in undersea warfare. The Royal Navy’s Project Cabot aims to field contractor-owned UUV fleets in the GIUK gap as “anti-submarine warfare as a service.” BAE Systems, General Dynamics and Boeing face off against startups such as Anduril and Helsing, leveraging passive sonar, seabed sensors and low-power acoustics for scalable, cost-effective patrols in grey-zone conflicts.

articles.title: ‘Mortified’ OBR chair hopes inquiry into budget leak will report next week
articles.trailText: Reuters news agency says it obtained document after visiting URL it predicted file would be uploaded to
articles.summary: OBR chair Richard Hughes apologized after Reuters accessed the office’s budget forecasts via a predictable unprotected URL 45 minutes before Chancellor Reeves’s speech. Mortified by the “publication error,” Hughes launched an expedited inquiry, overseen by independent board members Sarah Hogg and Dame Susan Rice, with cybersecurity input from former NCSC chief Ciaran Martin. Reeves backed Hughes despite the breach; he said he’d step down if confidence waned. Opposition figures urged OBR reform and called for Hughes’s resignation after details of £26bn tax rises and benefit changes leaked early.

articles.title: UK retailers urge faster end to tax break on low-value imported goods
articles.trailText: Primark, Currys and Boohoo criticise government for waiting until 2029 to phase out exemption on customs duty
articles.summary: Major British retailers including Primark, Currys and Boohoo, represented by the British Retail Consortium, have urged Chancellor Sunak to accelerate the end of the “de minimis” exemption—currently allowing under-£135 imports duty-free—now set for 2029. They warn 1.6m low-value parcels arrive daily, enabling platforms such as Shein and Temu to undercut UK firms and threaten high street viability. With the US and EU phasing out similar breaks, Helen Dickinson, George Weston, Dan Finley and Alex Baldock argue a faster repeal would level trading conditions, safeguard standards, and deliver £500m in annual revenue with only modest consumer price impact.

articles.title: Energy minister says UK must ‘do whatever it takes’ to avoid gas supply crisis
articles.trailText: Official advisers urge government to address situation that could mean homes and businesses going without on coldest days
articles.summary: Energy minister Michael Shanks vows to ‘do whatever it takes’ to avert a UK gas supply crisis flagged by the National Energy System Operator (Neso), warning of possible shortages by 2030 on the coldest days. Despite an overall decline in gas demand, Neso’s gas supply assessment signals risk if ageing North Sea production and infrastructure falter, prompting emergency measures like industrial cut-offs—and potentially household outages—in extreme scenarios. Shanks pledges to boost decarbonisation, expand storage, imports and network resilience. Ofgem, National Gas and Neso emphasize collaboration and investment to secure supply for peak winter demand as domestic output falls to 50-year lows.

articles.title: Daily Mail’s parent company on ‘credit watch’ over Telegraph takeover
articles.trailText: S&P Global Ratings warns Lord Rothermere’s RCHL could face credit downgrade as it seeks funding for £500m deal
articles.summary: US ratings agency S&P Global has placed Rothermere Continuation Holdings Ltd (RCHL)—owner of Daily Mail, Mail on Sunday, Metro and i Paper—on credit watch amid plans for a £500m Telegraph Media Group takeover. Analysts warn RCHL’s BB- rating has limited headroom for additional debt given its modest scale and TMG’s structurally challenged markets, risking a downgrade if leverage rises beyond thresholds. With exclusivity agreed with RedBird IMI, RCHL seeks funding without foreign state capital. DMGT’s reorganisation into RCHL yielded £1.1bn revenue and £78m profits for year to Sept. 2024.

articles.title: Debenhams boss could receive almost £150m if he turns around struggling retailer
articles.trailText: Incentive scheme for CEO of fashion group, which also includes Boohoo, comes as sales slump 23%
articles.summary: Debenhams Group CEO Dan Finley could earn £148.1m in shares under a new £200m incentive plan if he boosts the share price to £3 over 30 days within three years and sustains it for two more, valuing the company at £4.2bn. The scheme replaces a contested bonus plan as half-year sales slump 23% to £297m—youth brands down 41%, Karen Millen down 31%, though the Debenhams marketplace rose 20%. Pre-tax losses narrowed to £2.5m after £160m of cost cuts and 2,500 job losses, with another £60m of savings planned. FD Phil Ellis could receive £14.8m; Pretty Little Thing is up for sale amid Frasers Group opposition.

articles.title: Soup firm Campbell’s dismisses executive over alleged ‘poor people’ comments
articles.trailText: Senior figure allegedly referred to customers buying ‘highly processed food’ and denigrated Indian employees
articles.summary: Campbell’s has fired Martin Bally, its VP of information technology, after a recording captured him disparaging the company’s soups as "shit for fucking poor people" and making racist remarks about Indian employees. The recording, made by former security analyst Robert Garza—who is now suing for wrongful termination—also alleges Bally admitted drug use at work and criticized Campbell’s products as unhealthy and "bioengineered." Campbell’s apologized, condemned the comments as "vulgar, offensive and false," reaffirmed its quality standards and said it will not tolerate such language. Bally has not responded to requests for comment.

articles.title: ‘The customers are still there’: Welsh mussel farmers hope post-Brexit reset can revive business
articles.trailText: Shellfish exports to the EU from the Menai Strait have all but collapsed, but fishers are looking to the future
articles.summary: Welsh mussel farmers in the Menai Strait saw production tumble after Brexit—from 10,000 t to just 5 t annually—when EU sanitary checks and no local depuration facilities ended exports. With only one dredger left, Myti Mussels’ Valente, firms now sell domestically. A newly fitted purification plant by an Irish investor near Port Penrhyn and the UK-EU “reset” SPS deal, expected to remove border controls, offer hope for revival. Fishers warn rebuilding seed beds and awaiting a likely 2027 implementation create uncertainty, while industry chiefs and government forecast billions in growth if red tape is cut and live bivalves flow again.

articles.title: US banks announce UK expansion projects hours after budget
articles.trailText: JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs reveal plans for London and Birmingham as sector is spared tax rises
articles.summary: Hours after Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s autumn budget spared banks from higher levies, JP Morgan unveiled plans for a £3bn, 3m sq ft Canary Wharf tower to house more than half of its 23,000 UK staff as its new headquarters, while Goldman Sachs announced a Birmingham office expansion and 500 hires, over doubling its local workforce. JP Morgan forecasts a £10bn economic injection over six years; both lenders cite Britain’s growth-focused policies, planning deeper tech, AI and infrastructure investments.

articles.title: New rules crack down on high risk loans as Australian property market heats up
articles.trailText: Regulator announces 20% cap on share of new lending banks can do on mortgages worth more than six times borrower’s income
articles.summary: Australia’s Prudential Regulation Authority will impose a 20% cap on new mortgages with debt-to-income ratios above 6:1 from February, marking its first lending speed limits in a decade. The measure targets an overheated property market amid record-low affordability—households now spend nearly half of pre-tax income on mortgages—while investor loans, which rose 18% in Q3 and account for 40% of new lending, drive concern. Officials and analysts label it a stability guardrail, not a demand brake, unlikely to curb prices in the short term. Greens and housing advocates deem it insufficient, urging stricter investor limits and broader fiscal reforms to ease the housing crisis.

articles.title: Gopichand Hinduja obituary
articles.trailText: Billionaire businessman who as head of his family’s vast conglomerate topped the UK rich lists
articles.summary: Gopichand Parmanand Hinduja, who died aged 85, was Britain’s richest man and co-chair of the family’s £35bn Hinduja Group. Alongside brothers Ashok, Prakash and Srichand, he transformed their father’s Indo-Iranian trading firm into a global conglomerate spanning auto manufacturing, banking and Bollywood. Known for opulent London residences and the £1.25bn Raffles hotel in Whitehall, he also funded charity and Hindu temples. His career featured controversies over alleged arms sales to Iran, the Bofors affair and a 1999 Millennium Dome donation linked to Peter Mandelson. A pious yet acquisitive figure, he was survived by wife Sunita, children Dheeraj, Sanjay and Rita, and his brothers.

articles.title: Relief for retailers as business rate changes in budget not as bad as feared
articles.trailText: Sainsbury’s chief executive says ‘industry concerns have been heard’, although others outside retail industry are left frustrated by changes
articles.summary: Retailers relieved as budget’s business rates changes less severe than feared; chancellor Reeves permanently reduces rates for retail, hospitality and leisure properties, though discounts are lower than pandemic levels. About 750,000 sites will have bills below standard rates, with deeper cuts for small operators. A surcharge on properties over £500,000 is set at just a quarter of expected levels, backed by transitional relief. Analysts at Ryan warn 3,480 high-value shops face £112m extra from April 2026, though offset by deflation and lower multipliers. Sainsbury’s CEO welcomes the concession, while the BRC deems the package a mixed bag and hospitality and CBI leaders express frustration. The City hails a three-year IPO stamp duty holiday to spur equity market investment.

articles.title: Labour is still in a muddle on North Sea oil and gas | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Maintaining existing drilling sites for longer is sensible but doesn’t square with plans to keep the energy profits levy
articles.summary: Labour’s manifesto pledged no new North Sea licences but to manage existing fields ‘for their lifespan’, creating ‘transitional energy certificates’ for tie-backs on or near current sites. While this could extend use of rigs and pipelines, the Treasury’s decision to maintain a 78% energy profits levy until 2030 threatens to stifle investment and jobs. The result is a policy tug-of-war with no clear production targets or joined-up goals. Meanwhile, the budget missed a chance to cut stamp duty on all share trades—opting only for a three-year holiday on new listings—undermining efforts to revive London’s capital markets.

articles.title: Ed Miliband confirms crackdown on North Sea exploration – but new drilling will continue
articles.trailText: Strategy paper released with budget allows new oil and gas projects to move ahead if they are linked to existing fields
articles.summary: Labour energy secretary Ed Miliband confirmed a ban on new North Sea oil and gas licences for new fields, while permitting limited ‘tie-back’ drilling linked to existing infrastructure. The budget maintains the windfall tax and current rates, aiming to balance thousands of North Sea jobs with climate commitments. Environmentalists praised ending fresh exploration but faulted a £20m workers’ fund, calling for a just energy transition, while industry groups warn the tax will deter investment, accelerate job losses and slash Treasury revenues. A decision on the Rosebank field, already licensed, is due early next year.

articles.title: North Sea plan allows drilling while enabling Labour to keep ‘no new licences’ pledge
articles.trailText: ‘Tiebacks’ will permit small amount of new fossil fuel extraction, but campaigners want bolder strategy
articles.summary: Energy secretary Ed Miliband, fresh from COP30, reaffirmed the UK’s no new oil and gas licences pledge but unveiled a North Sea strategy allowing “tiebacks”—transitional energy certificates for drilling near existing fields, adding just 25m barrels of oil and 20m boe of gas versus Rosebank’s 500m boe. Environmentalists urge a complete halt to new fields and a just transition for workers. Meanwhile, Chancellor Rachel Reeves froze fuel duty, shifted green levies to general taxation, introduced a 3p/mile EV tax, scrapped the ECO scheme and retained the windfall tax until 2030, drawing criticism for mixed climate signals and underfunding home upgrades.

articles.title: Computer maker HP to cut up to 6,000 jobs by 2028 as it turns to AI
articles.trailText: US firm says plan to speed up product development and improve customer satisfaction would save $1bn a year
articles.summary: HP will cut 4,000–6,000 jobs globally by October 2028—up to 10% of its 56,000-strong workforce—as CEO Enrique Lores embeds AI across product development, internal operations and customer support to drive innovation and save $1 bn a year (with $650 m in severance costs). The move follows 1,000–2,000 layoffs in February and accompanies a 2025 EPS forecast of $2.90–3.20 versus $3.33 consensus. Q4 revenue topped $14.6 bn, AI-enabled PCs exceeded 30% of shipments, and shares fell 6%. This shift mirrors broader automation warnings from McKinsey and the UK’s NFER.

articles.title: Ministers approve £750m Marlow Film Studios development after review
articles.trailText: Planning permission granted for Buckinghamshire project seen as test of Labour’s drive for economic growth
articles.summary: Ministers approved planning for a £750m Marlow Film Studios near London after Labour’s growth-first review overturned Buckinghamshire council’s rejection. Endorsed by Sam Mendes, James Cameron and Paul Greengrass, the project will regenerate a former landfill into 18 sound stages, a creative campus and skills academy, creating 4,000 jobs. Steve Reed’s decision conceded potential green-belt harm but prioritised global investment, echoing Rachel Reeves’s budget growth agenda. Local campaign Save Marlow’s Greenbelt, warning of lasting environmental and landscape damage, has opted against a high court challenge.

articles.title: The latest inflation figures offer no joy – except to the gas producers whose windfall profits remain largely untouched | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: The boom in world gas prices due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine has led to energy companies making out like bandits
articles.summary: Australia’s CPI jumped to 3.8% from 3.6% with the switch to monthly data. Annual inflation is skewed by electricity price swings tied to unwinding then partial re-extension of federal and state rebates introduced after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Gas prices, linked to global markets via the Gladstone LNG terminal, have driven electricity costs and delivered massive windfall profits to producers. Yet revenues from the petroleum resource rent tax have fallen, leaving these gains largely untaxed.

articles.title: Warner Music signs deal with AI song generator Suno after settling lawsuit
articles.trailText: Music company representing Coldplay and Ed Sheeran had sued tech platform alleging mass copyright infringement Business live – latest updates
articles.summary: Warner Music Group, home to Coldplay and Ed Sheeran, has become the first major label to license its repertoire to AI song generator Suno, resolving last year’s copyright suit. The pact lets users generate tracks using voices and likenesses of opt-in Warner artists via text prompts and mandates paid-tier subscribers, download fees and caps to curb mass streaming uploads. Suno will roll out advanced licensed models next year, phasing out unlicensed versions, and has acquired concert platform Songkick. The deal follows Warner’s Udio settlement and comes amid UK IP reforms advocating artist opt-in licensing.

articles.title: Pets at Home boss says ‘urgent and necessary’ action needed as profits dive
articles.trailText: Interim chair of group, which is still looking for a CEO, says chain must ‘return to our retailing roots’
articles.summary: Interim chair Ian Burke warns urgent action is needed after Pets at Home’s half-year pre-tax profit fell 33.5% to £36.2m, driven by an 84% collapse in retail profit (£3.5m) and a 2.3% revenue drop to £679.9m. Veterinary arm Vets for Pets grew revenues 6.7% to £376m and profits 8.3% to £45m. Burke, in place since CEO Lyssa McGowan’s September exit, plans a £20m cost-cutting drive to refocus on core retail, tackle overexposure to traditional pet food versus premium direct brands and revive lagging accessories sales. Full-year profit is forecast at £90m–£100m, with vets contributing over £80m. Meanwhile, UK regulators propose capping vet prescription costs after a 63% price rise since 2016.

articles.title: Reserve Bank could raise interest rates as early as May after inflation climbs to 3.8%
articles.trailText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says government deciding on energy rebate extension in ‘next few weeks’ as cost of living continues to bite
articles.summary: Australia's annual CPI inflation rose to 3.8% in October (from 3.6%), driven by a 37% spike in power bills after state subsidies lapsed, raising concerns the Reserve Bank may hike rates as early as May. Underlying inflation climbed to 3.3%, with childcare costs up 11%, medical services +5.1% and accessories +12%. ABS head David Gruen expects power cost peaks soon, but economists at Barrenjoey and UBS forecast further CPI resilience and possible RBA rate increases in May, August and beyond. Treasurer Jim Chalmers weighs extending $150 energy rebates in December's mid-year budget update amid cost-of-living pressures.

articles.title: Joan Templeman, wife of billionaire Richard Branson, dies aged 80
articles.trailText: The British billionaire founder of Virgin Atlantic said he was ‘heartbroken’ by loss of wife and partner for 50 years
articles.summary: Joan Templeman, who died aged 80, was the wife and partner of British billionaire Richard Branson for 50 years. They met in 1976 at The Manor studio—where she worked in an antique shop—and married in 1989. The couple had three children: Holly, Sam and Sarah Clare, who died in infancy, and several grandchildren. Branson described her as his “rock, guiding light and best friend,” praising her private, supportive nature. Their son Sam called her the “kindest, most loving and generously warm” mother, and Branson said he was “heartbroken” by her passing.

articles.title: B&Q owner holds firm – but others might struggle if a ‘softening’ retail market turns soggy
articles.trailText: Kingfisher may be thriving, but its numbers mask a retail landscape that looks increasingly fragile as budget looms
articles.summary: Kingfisher, owner of B&Q and Screwfix, raised its FY profit forecast from £480–540m to £540–570m, driven by 3% UK like-for-like sales growth, market share gains after Homebase’s collapse, stronger trade and e-commerce operations, and Screwfix’s leading position. However, it warns of “softening market conditions” amid inflation, pre-budget uncertainty and a cooling labour market. Its French arm is under restructuring to offset weak local demand. Lower mortgage costs from recent rate cuts provide some cushion, but fragile consumer sentiment means further downturns could see softening conditions turn “soggy” for weaker retailers.

articles.title: UK to extend sugar tax to cover bottled milkshakes and pre-packaged lattes
articles.trailText: Levy will also apply to more fizzy drinks as health secretary says government ‘will not look away as children get unhealthier’
articles.summary: The UK government will extend its Soft Drinks Industry Levy (SDIL) to bottled milkshakes, flavoured milks and pre-packaged lattes by lowering the sugar threshold from 5g to 4.5g per 100ml and scrapping the milk-drink exemption. Announced by health secretary Wes Streeting, the change—backed by dentists including FDS dean Charlotte Eckhardt—takes effect 1 January 2028 after a further consultation, giving manufacturers two years to reformulate. Drinks served in cafes remain exempt. Industry body BSDA director Gavin Partington warned of extra costs, while ministers project up to £45m extra annual revenue for obesity and oral health measures.

articles.title: Peak pizza? Domino’s boss who launched shift towards chicken ousted
articles.trailText: Firm says Andrew Rennie departs ‘by mutual agreement’ but it is thought he faced tensions with the board
articles.summary: Andrew Rennie has left Domino’s Pizza Group after two years as CEO following tension with its board over his strategy to diversify into fried chicken, declaring the UK pizza market at “peak pizza.” He spearheaded the Chick ’N’ Dip trial in 210 outlets, positioning chicken as complementary to its core pizza business. Nicola Frampton, COO since 2021, will serve as interim CEO while the group searches for a permanent leader. Domino’s reported a 1.5% Q3 sales dip and a 15% fall in half-year profits amid weak consumer confidence and rising costs, and has paused acquisitions until new leadership is in place.

articles.title: EasyJet profits climb as package holidays sell well despite price rises
articles.trailText: Travel firm says most popular package destinations are Majorca, Tenerife, Costa Blanca, Dalaman and Lanzarote
articles.summary: EasyJet’s annual pre-tax profit rose 9% to £665 m, driven by a 27% surge in its holidays arm, which generated £1.4 bn revenue and £250 m profit by selling 3.1 m package trips (prices up 5% to £698). Popular resorts included Mallorca, Tenerife, Costa Blanca, Dalaman and Lanzarote, with top city breaks in Amsterdam, Paris and Barcelona. Airline revenue climbed 6% to £8.7 bn on a 4% capacity increase. CEO Kenton Jarvis highlighted 80% customer satisfaction, new bases in Milan, Rome, Newcastle and Marrakech, and set a £450 m holidays profit target by 2030.

articles.title: FCA makes inquiries into WH Smith accounting error that wiped almost £600m off value
articles.trailText: Regulator assessing whether firm breached UK disclosure rules for listed companies, but is yet to launch formal investigation
articles.summary: Following WH Smith’s accounting misstatement at its North America division—which overstated profits by up to £50 m and wiped about £600 m off its market value overnight—the FCA has opened inquiries to assess potential breaches of UK listing disclosure rules, though no formal investigation has been launched. The error, uncovered during year-end preparations and probed by Deloitte, prompted CEO Carl Cowling’s departure, interim replacement Andrew Harrison, and revised full-year profit guidance of £100–110 m (down 55%). Shares remain 45% lower as the group focuses on travel-hub outlets.

articles.title: UK bank shares rise after reports of budget tax reprieve
articles.trailText: NatWest, Lloyds and Barclays stock up amid expectation Rachel Reeves will spare lenders from further levy
articles.summary: UK bank shares jumped as investors bet Chancellor Rachel Reeves will spare lenders from new levies in her budget. Lloyds rose 3.8%, NatWest 3.7% and Barclays 2.3% after reports the Treasury sought supportive statements from the sector. Speculation over a revived bank tax, revived by IPPR proposals, has prompted intense lobbying, with banks citing a 45.8% total tax rate versus 38.6% in Frankfurt and warning a levy could curb lending and undermine Leeds growth reforms. Campaigners including Positive Money have collected nearly 69,000 signatures for a 38% windfall tax, which they say could raise over £14bn to bolster public services, backed by Labour MP Simon Opher.

articles.title: Australia is bringing in ‘world first’ minimum pay for food delivery drivers – here’s how it will work
articles.trailText: Deal between companies and union, which includes an hourly wage and accident insurance, still requires approval from the industrial umpire, but this is what we know so far
articles.summary: Food delivery firms DoorDash and Uber Eats and the Transport Workers’ Union have struck a “world-first” deal to set enforceable minimum standards for Australian gig drivers, including a safety-net hourly rate of A$31.30 from July 2026 (rising in January 2027), with slight vehicle-based adjustments, plus personal accident insurance, dispute-resolution processes, representation and feedback rights. The application to the Fair Work Commission, under recent Albanese government reforms, still awaits approval; it excludes penalty rates and pay for waiting time. Platforms are likely to pass costs to consumers. If ratified, it may reshape gig-economy standards and define driver employment status.

articles.title: ‘Replacing the old, stuffy department store’: John Lewis boss on its revamp
articles.trailText: Peter Ruis discusses the chain’s £800m reboot, bringing ‘radical relevance’ – and that dance-driven Christmas ad
articles.summary: John Lewis managing director Peter Ruis, who returned last year to revive the 161-year-old retailer, is directing an £800m redesign of its 36 stores by 2029 to deliver “radical relevance.” He’s replacing traditional departments with experiential lifestyle zones—consolidated gifting, cafes, beauty bars and a gin station at Bluewater—to encourage serendipitous browsing. After a £10m annual profit countering a £53m half-year loss, the employee-owned chain plans no closures and is eyeing expansion. A viral dance-driven Christmas ad taps teens and parents, supported by youth-friendly brands (Topshop, Carhartt, Charlotte Tilbury, Apple). Trials with 45-minute Uber Eats delivery, womenswear partnerships and a £1bn cash reserve aim to secure its lead as peers close.

articles.title: Black Friday discounts fail to offer cheapest prices, Which? research finds
articles.trailText: Products sold by retailers including John Lewis and Very among those cheaper outside of November discount period
articles.summary: Which? tracked prices of 175 home, tech and health appliances across eight retailers from May 2024 to May 2025 and found that no Black Friday 2024 deals hit their lowest 12-month prices. At John Lewis 94% of offers were cheaper or the same outside November, and at Very 93%, exemplified by a Samsung Jet Bot vacuum at £350 on Black Friday versus £299 for 29 days earlier. Despite this, UK consumers are forecast to spend £9.52 billion over the four-day weekend (up 4.2%), including £3.38 billion on Cyber Monday. Clothing and footwear could total £2 billion, electronics £1.7 billion (averaging £213 per person), and cosmetics £840 million. Meanwhile, 77% of small businesses are boycotting Black Friday, promoting alternatives like Bright Friday and Small Business Saturday on 6 December.

articles.title: Motability scheme to drop BMW and Mercedes as it aims to buy UK-made cars
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves says changes to subsidised scheme for disabled drivers will help support thousands of jobs
articles.summary: Motability will remove BMW and Mercedes-Benz from its subsidised car-leasing scheme for disabled drivers, focusing instead on vehicles that ‘meet disabled people’s needs and represent value and purpose’. Chancellor Rachel Reeves says this aims to support thousands of skilled UK jobs ahead of the budget. Motability targets sourcing 50% of its 300,000 annual leases from British factories by 2035 – rising from 22,000 last year to 150,000 – boosting Sunderland-built Nissan, Burnaston-made Toyota and Oxford’s Mini assembly lines. Premium brands accounted for just 5% (40,000) of an 800,000-vehicle pool. The move could inject over 100,000 extra domestic orders into UK carmakers.

articles.title: End the tax break that makes flying cheaper than trains | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Airlines benefit from a tax system that helps them keep fares low, writes Anna Hughes
articles.summary: Anna Hughes, director of Flight Free UK, argues that the UK’s no-tax policy on aviation fuel skews travel costs, making short-haul flights often cheaper than train journeys. She highlights public shock at the fuel tax exemption and calls it an obvious target for reform to both raise revenue and curb aviation’s environmental impact. While acknowledging that fuel taxation alone won’t solve carbon emissions, Hughes says it’s a logical first step, especially as the government, under Rachel Reeves, considers new levies on electric vehicles. She urges policymakers to seize this “easy win” for both climate goals and public coffers.

articles.title: More than 650 jobs at risk as scrap metals giant files for liquidation
articles.trailText: Unimetals, which operates at 27 UK locations, files winding–up petition after failing to find a buyer
articles.summary: Unimetals Recycling (UK), founded in 2023 by Jamie Afnaim and Alec Sellem and operating 27 sites—including four metal shredders, three port facilities and a hydromet plant in Abu Dhabi—has filed a winding-up petition after failing to find a buyer or new financing, jeopardising over 650 jobs. Acquired from Sims in October 2024 for £195m, the group suffered from oversupply and price falls, posting a £22m loss to June 2023. Alvarez & Marsal is overseeing urgent stakeholder talks on the liquidation process.

articles.title: Reeves expected to reveal cut in growth forecasts for next five years in budget
articles.trailText: OBR has reportedly downgraded predictions after review that blames lack of investment under Tories
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves will reveal in her upcoming budget that the Office for Budget Responsibility has downgraded UK growth forecasts annually through 2030-31, citing underinvestment under successive Tory governments. Despite her £120 bn extra infrastructure allocation, these cuts risk shaving £10 bn–£20 bn off annual tax receipts, undermining Labour’s 2029 election prospects. To shore up revenues, Reeves may levy properties over £2 m (raising £400 m–£450 m), extend the income-tax threshold freeze to 2030, introduce an EV pay-per-mile charge, curb salary-sacrifice perks, and lift the two-child universal credit cap. Rail fares and prescription fees will remain frozen to ease cost-of-living pressures.

articles.title: Labour will listen to bosses’ concerns on workers’ rights, says business secretary
articles.trailText: Peter Kyle tells CBI conference he will ensure firms do not lose as a result of overhaul
articles.summary: At the CBI conference in London, business secretary Peter Kyle pledged 26 post-legislation consultations to ensure Labour’s employment rights overhaul—banning zero-hour contracts and granting day-one unfair-dismissal protection—won’t harm firms. Facing boardroom fears of £0.9–5 billion compliance costs and Tory and Lib Dem Lords amendments, Kyle vowed to tweak secondary legislation but keep manifesto promises. Union leaders warn watering down betrays workers, while Tory figures like Kemi Badenoch condemn the bill as anti-business.

articles.title: Novo Nordisk shares slide after Ozempic pill fails in Alzheimer’s trials
articles.trailText: Report dashes hopes for new use for blockbuster weight-loss drug
articles.summary: Novo Nordisk’s semaglutide pill failed to slow Alzheimer’s progression in two large trials of nearly 4,000 patients, sending shares down over 10% intraday and 5.8% at close. Despite improvements in disease markers, no cognitive benefit materialized, quashing hopes to repurpose Ozempic beyond diabetes and obesity. CEO Mike Doustdar, fresh off workforce cuts and multiple sales-forecast downgrades, faces heightened pressure amid fierce competition from Eli Lilly’s tirzepatide. The result underscores the difficulty of dementia drug development despite early signals from smaller GLP-1 studies.

articles.title: ‘Friends end up blocking you’: Northwestern Mutual sold college grads a dream job. They left in ruin and debt
articles.trailText: Expecting to be financial advisers at the Fortune 500 firm, some hires say they were ‘gaslit’ into peddling ‘terrible’ life insurance to all their contacts
articles.summary: Northwestern Mutual, a 168-year-old Fortune 500 insurer and touted top employer for new grads, recruits college seniors at swanky campus events with promises of entrepreneurship and uncapped earnings as “financial advisers.” Interns upload 200+ personal contacts, make 40 daily calls and book five meetings weekly using scripts that invariably push costly whole-life insurance—despite minimal financial training. Many reps earn below minimum wage, go into debt buying policies to hit targets, and drop out amid “cultlike” gaslighting and public shaming. Critics say the firm exploits naïve recruits for lead generation, leaving clients misadvised and advisers burned out.

articles.title: Trump touts cheap groceries ahead of Thanksgiving. The reality is a mixed plate
articles.trailText: President looks to Walmart���s promotion as proof he lowered cost of living. But holiday prices are volatile, economists say
articles.summary: Trump has cited Walmart’s October deal—under-$4-per-person “curated” basket for a 10-person Thanksgiving feast—as evidence of lower food costs under his leadership. Economists caution prices remain volatile: Wells Fargo finds store-branded menus 2-3% cheaper year-on-year if shoppers use promotions, while Groundwork Collaborative sees overall costs up nearly 10% for branded items. Loss-leader turkeys mask higher wholesale and packaging costs—canned cranberry sauce and aluminum foil soared over 20–40%—and Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs plus climate-driven supply shocks leave further price relief uncertain.

articles.title: Mining giant BHP drops latest bid to buy rival Anglo American
articles.trailText: FTSE 100-listed miner forces Australian company to walk away from takeover after rebuffing second approach
articles.summary: BHP has abandoned its latest takeover bid for FTSE 100-listed Anglo American after being rebuffed, ending its second approach within a year following a failed £39bn attempt in 2024. With shareholders due to vote on Anglo’s $53bn merger with Teck Resources on December 9, BHP will focus on its own organic growth strategy. Under UK takeover rules it cannot re-bid for six months absent major changes. Anglo’s copper reserves—vital for low-carbon tech—have driven its shares up ~70% since early 2024. The Anglo-Teck deal still needs regulatory approval in China, the US and Canada.

articles.title: Minister indicates sympathy for artists in debate over AI and copyright
articles.trailText: People rightly want to get get paid for their work, says Liz Kendall, in apparent change of tack to predecessor
articles.summary: The UK technology secretary Liz Kendall has signaled a shift in policy on AI and copyright, expressing “sympathy” for artists who demand payment and transparency when their works are used to train large language models. Replacing Peter Kyle, Kendall said she and culture secretary Lisa Nandy will “reset” the debate by consulting with creative and AI sectors on a new IP framework. High-profile protests—from Paul McCartney’s silent track to Elton John’s criticism—highlight artists’ push for opt-in agreements and clear reporting. An initial government report is due end of 2025, with fuller proposals by March 2026.

articles.title: Americans are feeling the pain of the affordability crisis: ‘There’s not any wiggle room’
articles.trailText: The costs of groceries, housing, childcare, education and healthcare have become intolerable to many
articles.summary: Americans like Cat Hill face skyrocketing basic costs—groceries up 4.5% for meats, 2.8% beverages, 1.3% produce, plus housing, childcare, healthcare and education. The Fed blames Trump’s tariffs for inflation rising from 2.3% to 3% year-over-year. Consumer sentiment plunged to a near-record low of 51 in November. After midterm losses over affordability, Trump partly rolled back levies, floated 50-year mortgages and a $2,000 tariff-funded rebate. Polls show 72% disapprove of his cost-of-living record, including a third of Republicans.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves, please, let’s make budgets boring again | Heather Stewart
articles.trailText: Budgets need to be reassuringly dull with no repeat of this year’s long, drawn-out and chaotic buildup
articles.summary: Facing a protracted, chaotic budget buildup caused by volatile bond markets and a mere £10bn fiscal buffer, Chancellor Rachel Reeves is urged to: expand headroom to about £20bn to calm markets and enable BoE rate cuts; reduce the OBR spring forecast’s binding status to avoid biannual fiscal drama; and frame a cohesive, progressive tax-and-spend narrative tied to Labour’s NHS, cost-of-living and debt priorities. Done decisively, this can reset investor confidence and deliver the 'reassuringly dull' budgets Reeves and markets crave.

articles.title: Bad season of bird flu in UK hits supply of Christmas turkeys
articles.trailText: Availability of chickens and ducks also expected to be tight, with 5% of the seasonal flock culled so far
articles.summary: UK poultry farmers face a severe bird flu season with around 5% of the Christmas flock (300,000 turkeys, ducks and chickens) culled so far and cases exceeding last winter’s levels. Organic and free-range producers—such as Capestone Organic, which lost 48,000 turkeys—are hardest hit, prompting earlier processing of heavy birds to curb infection risk. Major supermarkets have secured advance orders at higher margins, but smaller retailers may face shortages or pass on price hikes. Since October, 50 outbreaks have triggered housing orders and a national avian influenza prevention zone, with the coming weeks crucial for festive supply.

articles.title: EU and US to restart trade talks as sticking points on July tariff deal remain
articles.trailText: US officials to hold high-level talks in Brussels amid unhappiness in Washington at slow action on July deal
articles.summary: US and EU trade envoys will resume negotiations in Brussels after a two-month hiatus to resolve delays in implementing July’s non-binding 15% levy deal that replaced Trump’s 50% tariff threat. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer will meet EU commissioners, ministers and industry bosses to tackle unresolved issues: ongoing 50% steel and aluminium duties, extra levies on steel-embedded goods, wine and spirits taxes affecting France and Ireland, food and drink duties, plus chip-supply security. Talks will explore coordinated anti-dumping measures to protect US and EU steel from cheap Chinese imports.

articles.title: Labour must back delivery drivers sacked by DPD, former cabinet minister says
articles.trailText: Louise Haigh criticises delivery company over treatment of workers who spoke out against pay cuts
articles.summary: Former transport secretary Louise Haigh urged the Labour government to support self-employed DPD delivery drivers dismissed after protesting a unilateral cut of up to £8,000 a year in delivery rates. DPD, which posted £200m pre-tax profit and boosted its top director’s pay to £1.5m, partially reversed the cuts temporarily but reinstated them for the New Year and sacked spokespeople like Dean Hawkins. Haigh warns existing employment rights bill won’t shield drivers and calls for legal safeguards against dismissal for collective action, pressing ministers to honour promises on workers’ rights.

articles.title: Hospitals and clinics are shutting down due to Trump’s healthcare cuts. Here’s where
articles.trailText: From Georgia to Oregon, clinics and wards are closing as Trump’s health law triggers steep Medicaid cuts and rising costs
articles.summary: Since Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act cut Medicaid eligibility and ACA costs, slashing hundreds of billions in federal health funding, providers have closed hundreds of rural hospitals, obstetric wards and clinics across nine states. Over 300 rural hospitals risk closure, and nearly 100 counties lose sole obstetric care. Georgia’s St Mary’s Sacred Heart shut its maternity ward; Maine Family Planning ceased primary care; Kansas, Nebraska and New Hampshire sites aborted openings or closed clinics; NY, OR, VA and WA also announced layoffs and service cuts, disproportionately affecting low-income, Native American and white women.

articles.title: US data agency cancels October inflation report as Fed considers whether to cut rates
articles.trailText: Bureau of Labor Statistics canceled release of October’s consumer price index, citing the government shutdown
articles.summary: The Bureau of Labor Statistics canceled publication of October’s consumer price index, citing the recent government shutdown and inability to retroactively collect data, leaving the Fed without key inflation metrics as officials—including Chair Jerome Powell, who likened policy choices to “driving in the fog”—weigh possible rate cuts. Price growth remains elevated. NY Fed’s John Williams signaled space for further near-term easing. The September jobs report, delayed and revised downward, showed 119,000 jobs added and unemployment rising to its highest since 2021. October employment figures will merge with November’s data after the next Fed meeting.

articles.title: Drax, the forestry industry and the guise of ‘green’ energy | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters:
articles.summary: Drax’s chief sustainability officer says 81% of its Canadian biomass comes from sawmill residues and 19% from low-grade forest leftovers, all harvested under strict BC rules mandating reforestation, and argues using this waste for power cuts wildfire risk versus on-site burning—none from protected old-growth areas. NRDC senior advocate Matt Williams counters that UK subsidies for burning imported wood pellets, including centuries-old trees, are hypocritical, merely shift emissions overseas and calls on Britain to stop financing forest loss and instead restore and protect woodlands.

articles.title: Europe’s economy is geared towards a disappearing world, says ECB’s Lagarde
articles.trailText: Central bank chief warns that the bloc’s dependence on third countries for trade and security has left it vulnerable
articles.summary: ECB chief Christine Lagarde warned that Europe’s economy is geared to a disappearing global trade order and overdependent on third countries for security and critical raw materials—citing US protectionism under Trump and China’s rare-earth and power-chip dominance—and static internal markets in digital, AI and capital. She argued each new shock quietly erodes growth and that savers’ tilt to US stocks hinders EU productivity. Praising resilient labor, digital and defense investment, Lagarde urged cutting internal trade barriers (100% on services, 65% on goods), matching the Netherlands’ openness to offset US tariffs, and adopting mutual recognition of regulated firms plus qualified majority voting on taxes to harmonize VAT across the bloc.

articles.title: UK government borrows more than expected in setback before budget
articles.trailText: October figures represent final snapshot of public finances before Rachel Reeves’s tax and spending statement
articles.summary: ONS data show UK government borrowed £17.4bn in October—third-highest October deficit on record—bringing year-to-date borrowing to £116.8bn, £9.9bn above OBR forecasts. With borrowing now tracking close to 5% of GDP and interest payments of £8.4bn in October, chancellor Rachel Reeves faces pressure to rebuild fiscal headroom in next week’s budget. Bond markets will test her ability to unlock roughly £20bn buffer without unsettling sentiment. Cost pressures from inflation-linked benefits and public sector pay, a retail sales dip, and political disputes over tax rises add to the challenge.

articles.title: Wetherspoons to open first pub in Spain – offering garlic prawns and beer from 6am
articles.trailText: Opening in Alicante airport is the chain’s first move into mainland Europe, and will offer outdoor drinking
articles.summary: Wetherspoons will open its first mainland Europe pub in January at Alicante–Elche Miguel Hernández airport, serving alcohol from 6 am daily and offering a terrace. Named Castell de Santa Bàrbera after a local fortress, the 93 m² venue seats holidaymakers in the departure lounge and serves its usual fry-ups, burgers and pizzas alongside local dishes like garlic prawns and Spanish omelette. Founder Tim Martin, who backed Brexit, plans further European expansions. The 800-unit chain saw 3.7 % sales growth in its latest financial period.

articles.title: Asos turns to AI stylists to win back shoppers after sales slide 12%
articles.trailText: Online fashion retailer says action to cut discounts and deter ‘serial returners’ contributed to fall in sales
articles.summary: Asos, facing a 12% sales drop to 31 Aug and pre-tax losses narrowed to £282m, is trialling “Styled for You” AI stylists on its app. Using a 100,000–outfit database and shopper history/trending data, the tool suggests complementary items (jackets, heels or casual sweaters, trainers). Separately AI accelerates design mockups. Amid high returns, new fees and bans on serial returners cut return rates by 1.5pp. CEO José Antonio Ramos Calamonte aims to rebuild Asos as a style “destination”. Post-pandemic slumps, unwanted stock and fast-fashion rivals (Shein, Next) leave Asos bracing for further sales declines; shares fell 10%.

articles.title: UK retail sales drop unexpectedly as shoppers await Black Friday and budget
articles.trailText: Supermarkets, clothing stores and online mail order firms suffer sales declines as consumers delay purchases
articles.summary: Retail sales in the UK unexpectedly fell 1.1% in October—the first decline since May—as consumers held off for Black Friday deals and awaited next week’s budget from Chancellor Rachel Reeves. Clothing, footwear and textiles plunged 3.3%, supermarkets dropped 1.1%, online retail was down 1.7% and fuel sales fell 2.4%. Pre-budget uncertainty dented consumer sentiment, with the S&P Global services PMI easing to 50.5 and GfK's consumer confidence index slipping to -19.

articles.title: AI bubble fears return as Wall Street falls back from short-lived rally
articles.trailText: Leading US stock markets tumble less than 24 hours after strong results from chipmaker Nvidia sparked gains
articles.summary: After Nvidia’s Q3 results sparked a brief global rally—FTSE 100 +0.2%, DAX +0.5%, Nikkei +2.65%—bubble fears returned as U.S. stocks slumped: S&P 500 -1.6%, Dow Jones -0.8% and tech-heavy Nasdaq -2.2%. Despite Nvidia reassuring investors on robust datacenter chip demand and a valuation of $4.4 trillion, heavy AI infrastructure spending by hyper-scale cloud firms ignited bubble concerns. Nvidia shares fell 3.2%, the VIX index rose 8%, and a mixed U.S. jobs report cemented expectations the Fed will hold rates in December.

articles.title: Serious Fraud Office arrests two men over suspected £20m crypto fraud
articles.trailText: Law enforcement agency raids two sites in West Yorkshire and London as it appeals for information
articles.summary: The Serious Fraud Office arrested two men in their 30s and 40s in West Yorkshire and London over an alleged £20m cryptocurrency fraud linked to Basis Markets. The scheme raised £21.4m via two fundraisers in late 2021 promising to build a crypto hedge fund, then blamed US regulations in June 2022 for halting the project. The SFO, bolstered by an extra £8m for crypto asset recovery, is now probing what happened to investors’ money. Director Nick Ephgrave urged anyone with information to come forward.

articles.title: Industry can’t wait any longer for a fix to its energy crisis. Ministers should get a move on | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Make UK’s call for the government to recognise that the energy crisis for industry is happening now is spot-on
articles.summary: Make UK urges the government to expand its British industrial competitiveness scheme (BICS) from 7,000 to 115,000 manufacturers and backdate savings to April this year, instead of waiting until April 2027. Chancellor Rachel Reeves is resistant—backdating is rare, broadening costs more and defies the eight ‘priority’ sectors focus. With UK industrial energy prices among the highest in developed economies, firms face closures and looming network-charge hikes next April. Although the top 500 energy-intensive users receive a bigger ‘supercharger’ discount, many hefty users are exposed. Make UK calls for BICS to launch by April to curb rising bills and stem deindustrialisation.

articles.title: ‘No contract, no coffee’: what to know about the Starbucks workers’ strike in 65 US cities
articles.trailText: More than 2,000 Starbucks employees are on the picket line as politicians like Zohran Mamdani back striking workers
articles.summary: Since Nov 13, over 2,000 unionized Starbucks baristas in 65 US cities have launched an unfair labor practice strike, demanding a first-ever national contract after talks with Starbucks Workers United stalled over wages and benefits. The union, representing 11,000 baristas at 550 stores, has filed NLRB charges as it threatens to scale the 'no contract, no coffee' campaign during the holiday season. Starbucks, citing 99% of outlets open, blames the union for stalled talks and notes only 4% membership. Politicians including NYC's Zohran Mamdani and Seattle's mayor-elect back the strikers, while the chain faces soft sales, rising costs and CEO turnover.

articles.title: UK is worst-performing market for JD Sports as youth unemployment hits sales
articles.trailText: Lack of spare cash among under-25s feeds slide in sales with annual profits to be at lower end of expectations
articles.summary: JD Sports warns UK is its worst-performing market as rising youth unemployment erodes spending among under-25s, with NEET levels near a decade high at 946,000 (1 in 8). Established store sales fell 3.3% in the quarter to 1 Nov, while US and EU sales dropped 1.7% and 1.1%. Reliance on Nike, sparse product launches and weaker consumer sentiment prompted a full-year profit downgrade to ~£853m from ~£1bn. Higher employer taxes and wage costs add pressure. Separately, Dr Martens reports consumer caution across Europe and the US, raising some US prices to offset Trump’s import tariffs.

articles.title: Asda to raise £568m in store sell-off as sales continue to fall
articles.trailText: Supermarket still losing market share despite effort under Allan Leighton to win over customers with price cuts
articles.summary: Asda sells 24 stores and a distribution centre to DTZ Investors and Blue Owl, raising £568m via sale-and-leaseback to service debt after its 2020 £6.8bn leveraged buyout by the Issa brothers and TDR Capital. Despite price cuts under chair Allan Leighton, Q3 sales fell 3.9% and market share slid 1pp, contributing to a near £600m parent loss. The GMB union warns that rising lease liabilities and low morale signal weakness, while analysts say higher rents will boost interest costs, limit capex and won’t cut core debt, as funds are earmarked to repay Walmart.

articles.title: US added 119,000 jobs in September in report delayed by federal shutdown
articles.trailText: Unemployment rate hits 4.4%, its highest level since 2021, and government has said no October report will be issued
articles.summary: A six-week delayed BLS report shows the US added 119,000 jobs in September versus 51,000 forecast, while unemployment rose to 4.4%—its highest since 2021. July and August gains were revised down to +72,000 and −4,000. The government shutdown also voided the October jobs report, now due mid-December. ADP data flagged a 29,000 private-sector loss in September. Wall Street initially rallied—S&P500 +1.7%, Nasdaq +2.1%—then reversed into declines of 0.7% and 0.9% as Nvidia fell 0.9%. With Fed policymakers eyeing a December rate hold, political fallout included Trump’s firing of the BLS commissioner and Warren’s criticism of data withholding.

articles.title: People in the US: how has the Trump administration affected your healthcare?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear how the One Big Beautiful Bill Act is impacting your local healthcare provision
articles.summary: Four months after Trump signed the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, providers have shuttered clinics and hospital wards nationwide. The tax-and-spending law, projected to strip coverage from 10 million people and cut federal healthcare funding by hundreds of billions, is blamed for these closures alongside existing financial woes. Local facilities report service reductions, reduced hours and layoffs. We want to know how your area has been affected: closures, service cuts or staff layoffs since the law’s enactment.

articles.title: Ban on veggie ‘burgers’: plant-based products may lose meaty names in UK under EU law
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Trade agreement means UK is subject to some food labelling rules, with vote on vegetarian food terms this week
articles.summary: Under the UK–EU SPS deal, British plant-based producers face EU food-labelling rules that could bar terms like “veggie burger” or “sausage” if an EU legislature vote—backed by livestock lobbies—is finalised this week. Once adopted, the ban on “meaty” descriptors for vegetarian foods would automatically apply in the UK until renegotiated. Critics including Aldi, Lidl, Burger King, WePlanet and Ivy Farm warn it would confuse consumers and hamper industry growth, while proponents like MEP Céline Imart and German Chancellor Friedrich Merz argue it ensures transparency and protects farmers. The UK government says alignment preserves trade benefits without lowering standards.

articles.title: Victoria to force agents to publish property reserve prices in crackdown on underquoting
