Industry critics cite timing and enforcement issues, but delays risk unsustainable Treasury deficits. After IFS warnings since 2019, this blunt pay-per-mile is deemed vital to preserve motoring tax revenues.

articles.title: Bank of England opens door to December rate cut as it signals inflation has peaked
articles.trailText: Policymakers keep borrowing costs at 4% before crucial budget while also warning of persistent weak growth
articles.summary: The Bank of England held its key rate at 4% in a narrow 5–4 vote, warning that while inflation has likely peaked at 3.8%, it must see further disinflation before cutting rates. Governor Andrew Bailey, casting the deciding vote, said the MPC will assess the impact of Rachel Reeves’s 26 November budget, which is expected to raise taxes and curb living-cost pressures. Markets now put a nearly 60% chance on a quarter-point cut in December. The Bank forecasts inflation falling to 2.5% next year and back to target by 2027, GDP growth slowing to 1.2% in 2026, and unemployment peaking above 5%.

articles.title: Sainsbury’s says shoppers are delaying spending in run-up to budget
articles.trailText: Boss of supermarket urges Rachel Reeves not to fuel inflation with tax rises on retailers and suppliers
articles.summary: Sainsbury’s CEO Simon Roberts warns finance minister Rachel Reeves against retailer and supplier tax hikes, arguing they would stoke inflation and deter cautious shoppers already delaying discretionary spending ahead of her budget. He highlights rising costs—£140m more in employers’ national insurance and tens of millions in new packaging rules—and notes early Black Friday deals at Argos to spark demand. Despite cost pressures, Sainsbury’s raised half-year sales by 4.8%, upgraded annual profits to over £1bn, plans one new store monthly for 18 months, and will pay a £250m special dividend plus £150m in share buybacks.

articles.title: Bank of England’s decision to keep interest rates at 4% is not all doom and gloom
articles.trailText: Close-run vote raises hopes of rates cut in December, with inflation said to have peaked at 3.8%
articles.summary: Bank of England held rates at 4% in a narrow 5–4 MPC vote, with Governor Andrew Bailey casting the deciding vote. Inflation, which peaked at 3.8%, is projected to fall to the 2% target by 2027, while GDP growth edges up from 1.5% this year to 1.8% by 2028. The MPC signalled rates could drop to about 3% by 2028, with the next potential cut in December. Bailey cited the need to assess the impact of Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s upcoming budget and safeguard the Bank’s anti-inflation credibility amid political pressures. Growth dips to 1.2% in 2026 before recovering, improving fiscal headroom.

articles.title: NHS won’t get cutting-edge drugs unless it pays more, says AstraZeneca boss
articles.trailText: Pascal Soriot calls for cost-effectiveness thresholds to undergo ‘substantial adjustment based on inflation’
articles.summary: AstraZeneca CEO Pascal Soriot warns that without significant NHS spending increases and inflation-adjusted NICE thresholds, the UK risks affording only generic drugs and deterring R&D—highlighting ~£2bn of paused investments. He calls to double medicine spend to 0.6% of GDP, raise cost-effectiveness thresholds to £40k-£50k per QALY, and cut the 25% revenue clawback under the voluntary scheme. AZ shares climbed 3% as the firm said US price cuts won’t dent profits, announced a NYSE listing, $50bn US investment plan and a $4.5bn Virginia plant.

articles.title: Banks poised to escape tax rises in Rachel Reeves’s budget
articles.trailText: UK bank shares rise after reports, with chancellor wanting sector to remain competitive to help economic growth
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has ruled out further taxes on UK banks in her November budget to keep the sector competitive, sending NatWest and Lloyds shares up about 2%. Banks pay a 28% corporation tax rate including a 3% surcharge. Despite IPPR calls for a new £8bn “windfall” tax to recoup quantitative easing gains, and discussions of bank levies, Reeves opted for stability amid public finance shortfalls. UK Finance notes banks’ total tax burden exceeds peers, contributing £43.3bn (4.3% of receipts). NatWest’s CEO and analysts argue banks must boost lending and growth in return.

articles.title: Illegal tobacco burns $3.3bn hole in Australia’s tax revenue, crime agency says
articles.trailText: ACIC report says total impact of illicit trade on economy amounted to $4bn in a year amid debate over cigarette excise
articles.summary: Australia’s illicit tobacco trade now represents one in five sales, leaving a $3.3bn excise gap in 2023-24 and driving a $4bn economic drag including $700m in healthcare costs and productivity losses. The $30-per-pack excise – up from $4.65 in 2006 – has spurred NSW premier calls for a review, while criminals profit from ~$13 black-market packs vs $50 legal, fueling turf wars with at least three murders and 200+ firebombings. ATO forecasts excise revenue to fall from $16.3bn to $7.1bn next year and cut by $6.9bn over four years, highlighting policy stalemate.

articles.title: Pollution from Ineos’s Antwerp plastic plant ‘could cause more deaths than jobs created’
articles.trailText: Lawyers challenge €4bn Project One development, saying emissions and health impacts vastly underestimated
articles.summary: Lawyers have launched a court challenge in Belgium to halt Ineos’s €4bn Project One petrochemical plant in Antwerp, arguing its pollution will cause 410 deaths while creating only 300 permanent jobs. The facility would convert US shale gas ethane into ethylene, emitting particulate matter and unleashing 3.8m tonnes of CO2e annually when full lifecycle emissions are counted—five times Ineos’s estimate of 655,000 tonnes. Campaigners say this case, the first to press scope-3 emissions and plastics in court, could reshape Europe’s environmental impact assessments.

articles.title: The RBA predicts inflation will rise faster than wages. Let’s hope it’s wrong | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: If the Reserve Bank is right, then by the end of 2027 the average wage will only have the same purchasing power as it did at the end of 2011
articles.summary: Reserve Bank of Australia held rates on November 6, with Governor Michele Bullock emphasizing inflation control over unemployment. The RBA projects unemployment stabilizing at 4.4% to 2027, while inflation will outpace wage growth through 2026–27. Real wages by end-2027 will have purchasing power equal to 2011 levels. Meanwhile, household spending softened, rising just 0.5% in Q3 excluding alcohol/tobacco, below pre-COVID trend and suggesting no excess demand. Markets now await December meeting alongside new wage, inflation and GDP data.

articles.title: Marks & Spencer’s cyber-trauma is bad, but clearly manageable
articles.trailText: Chief executive criticises chancellor before budget that could prove bigger threat to business than ‘the incident’
articles.summary: M&S CEO Stuart Machin downplays April’s six-week cyber-attack that forced manual stock control, cut clothing & home sales by 16.4% and wiped £324m of profits (£100m insured), noting food sales jumped 7.8%. He lambasts Chancellor Reeves’ pre-budget fanfare for sapping consumer confidence. Management expects full recovery by early 2026, a return to pre-attack growth with food sales set to double long-term, store estate rationalisation under way, and 2026-27 profits back on track, a path the market still views as intact despite budget risks to spending power.

articles.title: ‘A lifeline’: how fashion designers came to love the high street collab
articles.trailText: Since the 1990s, high fashion has sprinkled stardust on the high street – now collabs also help struggling designers
articles.summary: Since the 1990s’s Designers at Debenhams initiative, high street chains have tapped fashion talent—from H&M’s Karl Lagerfeld and Topshop’s Kate Moss to recent M&S/16Arlington and H&M/Glenn Martens tie-ups. John Lewis and Debenhams have similarly partnered with Labrum, Rejina Pyo and Ashish Gupta. These collabs offer independent labels vital funding, brand exposure and operational know-how—allowing them to skip costly fashion weeks—while designer Aaron Esh has joined All Saints for stability. Retailers benefit from injected creativity, elevated credibility and fresh consumer reach, driving sales and innovation across price tiers.

articles.title: Drax power plant to go on earning ‘over £1m a day’ from burning wood pellets
articles.trailText: Analysts say Britain’s biggest power plant in line to earn £458.6m a year under new government subsidy contract
articles.summary: Under a new UK subsidy deal (2027–31) Drax will earn £458.6m/year—over £1m/day—by burning biomass ~28% of the time at a guaranteed £157.50/MWh (up from £142.24), despite halving its current support. It must raise sustainable woody pellet use from 70% to 100% or face penalties. Ember warns Drax remains Britain’s largest emitting power station and still garners hefty subsidies; Drax counters that Baringa analysis shows £3.1bn in consumer savings and enhanced grid security. The FCA is investigating its past pellet‐sourcing disclosures.

articles.title: Ozempic maker struggles as it loses ground to rivals in weight-loss market
articles.trailText: Novo Nordisk cuts sales and profit forecasts as it continues to lose ground to Mounjaro firm Eli Lilly
articles.summary: Novo Nordisk, maker of Ozempic and Wegovy, cut its 2025 full-year sales growth forecast to up to 11% and operating profit growth to a maximum of 7%—down from 16%—citing intensifying GLP-1 competition after Q3 sales rose 5% to DKK 75bn, below analyst estimates. CEO Mike Doustdar pointed to slowed profit expansion and market share loss to Eli Lilly’s more effective Mounjaro and Zepbound. The Danish firm, whose share price has halved and forecasts have been trimmed four times, is also locked in a $9bn takeover race with Pfizer for obesity biotech Metsera.

articles.title: M&S boss says Reeves made customers more worried with pre-budget speech
articles.trailText: Stuart Machin says shoppers are concerned about rising costs after chancellor failed to rule out manifesto-breaking tax rises
articles.summary: M&S CEO Stuart Machin warned shoppers grew more anxious after Chancellor Reeves’s pre-budget speech failed to rule out tax rises ahead of Christmas. He reported H1 underlying profit fell to £184.1m from £413.1m after a cyber-attack halted online clothing and homeware orders for six weeks, inflicting a £324m trading hit. Total sales dipped 0.6% to £6.5bn—fashion/home down 16.4%, food up 7.8%. Insurance recouped £100m; a £50m packaging levy and £102m one-off cyber costs weighed on results, with £34m more expected. M&S plans £600m of savings, no job losses, opened six stores with 12 more due, and forecasts H2 profit at least flat.

articles.title: Global stock markets fall sharply over AI bubble fears
articles.trailText: Drop in US, Asia and Europe follows warning from bank bosses that market correction could lie ahead
articles.summary: Global stock markets plunged as AI valuations wane after record highs: US Nasdaq fell 2% and S&P 500 dropped over 1% driven by declines in the “Magnificent Seven” AI giants (Nvidia, Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, Tesla, Alphabet, Meta). Palantir slumped nearly 8% amid Michael Burry’s short bets, prompting CEO Alex Karp’s backlash. Asian markets tumbled over 5%; European bourses edged down. Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan chiefs warned of an imminent equity correction. Bitcoin dipped below $100k as risk assets sold off.

articles.title: Bosses at six water firms had £4m in bonuses blocked under new rules, Ofwat says
articles.trailText: Regulator also considers forcing companies to report pay received from parent firms after Guardian investigation
articles.summary: Ofwat barred £4m in executive bonuses at six English and Welsh water companies—Anglian, Southern, Thames, United Utilities, Wessex and Yorkshire—under new rules targeting environmental and performance failures. The regulator is consulting on stronger pay-reporting requirements after The Guardian revealed Yorkshire Water’s CEO Nicola Shaw received £1.3m via an offshore parent. Despite the ban, average CEO pay rose 5% to £1.1m, with Southern’s boss seeing an 80% rise to £1.4m through a pre-existing long-term incentive plan. Thames and other firms still awarded non-CEO bonuses, prompting calls for more transparency. Anglian Water was also flagged for financial resilience concerns.

articles.title: Fixing Britain’s worklessness crisis will cost employers £6bn a year, report says
articles.trailText: The Keep Britain Working review, created to tackle the rising tide of ill health pushing millions out of work, reported its findings ahead of this month’s budget
articles.summary: The Keep Britain Working review, led by Charlie Mayfield, warns that Britain’s health-related worklessness—3m on long-term sickness, over 9m economically inactive—costs the economy £85bn annually. It calls for employers to fund occupational health at £5–15 per employee per month (≈£6bn a year) to reduce sickness absence, boost return-to-work rates and disability employment. If adopted economy-wide, measures could yield £18bn benefits. A vanguard of 60 employers, incl. British Airways and Tesco, will trial government-certified workplace health schemes integrated with the NHS app. The report also suggests tax cuts and rebates to incentivize investment.

articles.title: Telecoms companies to improve security to stop UK phone number ‘spoofing’
articles.trailText: Six of biggest providers to roll out new technology over next 12 months in effort to prevent fraud by foreign call centres
articles.summary: Six leading UK phone providers—BT/EE, Virgin Media O2, Vodafone, Three, Tesco Mobile, TalkTalk and Sky—will sign the second telecoms fraud charter with Comms Council UK and the government to deploy new call-authentication and tracing technology within 12 months. The system will authenticate caller ID, improve traceability and block foreign call centres spoofing UK landline numbers, in line with Ofcom’s mandate. Home Office research shows 75% of consumers ignore unknown overseas calls; Virgin Media O2 flags 50m scam calls monthly. The upgrade aims to eliminate spoofing, disrupt organised fraud gangs and bolster consumer confidence in phone security.

articles.title: Ashford’s ghost terminal could be brought back to life by Richard Branson | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Helena Dollimore MP says the entrepreneur could burnish his legacy by bringing international trains back to the Kent station
articles.summary: Helena Dollimore MP argues that after Britain ended Eurostar’s cross-Channel rail monopoly and granted Virgin Trains access to key depots, entrepreneur Richard Branson could revive the mothballed Ashford International terminal, closed since 2020 despite its £80m build cost. Reactivating it, she says, would generate up to £2.7bn for the local economy and counter decades of inward-looking policy by reconnecting Kent with European partners, cementing Branson’s legacy as Britain’s top disruptor and boosting businesses and tourism on the south coast.

articles.title: China accuses Dutch of prolonging chip war that threatens to halt car factories
articles.trailText: Beijing tells Netherlands to ‘stop interfering’ after seizure of chipmaker Nexperia as export bans disrupt supply chain
articles.summary: China has demanded that the Netherlands ‘stop interfering’ after The Hague seized chipmaker Nexperia from China’s Wingtech Technology over US security concerns. In retaliation, Beijing halted exports of Nexperia semiconductors—used in airbags, locks and rare-earth magnets—triggering warnings from EU, UK and Japanese automakers of imminent production stoppages. The EU is in urgent Brussels talks with China to lift chip and rare-earth bans, contrasting with a fragile US-China truce promising restored exports. The Dutch, invoking a Cold War-era law, face pressure to resolve the dispute or risk widespread job and supply-chain losses.

articles.title: Gopichand Hinduja, head of Britain’s richest family, dies aged 85
articles.trailText: Billionaire businessman’s family owns Hinduja Group, which has interests across oil, banking and real estate
articles.summary: Gopichand Hinduja, 85, head of Britain’s richest family and co-chair of the £35.3bn Hinduja Group, died in London after a long illness. Alongside brother Srichand (d.2023), he built the conglomerate’s interests in banking, oil, real estate and entertainment, employing 150,000 globally. Key acquisitions include Ashok Leyland (1987) and Gulf Oil. He courted controversy in 2001 over lobbying for a UK passport with minister Peter Mandelson, and his family’s London portfolio—Carlton House Terrace mansion and luxury Old War Office conversion—bypassed affordable housing. Survived by wife Sunita and children Sanjay, Dheeraj and Rita.

articles.title: Primark owner’s boss urges Reeves not to hit shoppers with budget tax rises
articles.trailText: George Weston tells chancellor to ‘tax rich folks instead’ as ABF says it could split fashion chain from food arm
articles.summary: ABF chief George Weston has urged Chancellor Rachel Reeves to avoid VAT or income-tax hikes that dent consumer confidence after last year’s budget reversed Primark’s growth, suggesting instead targeting the wealthy. Warning that late-November fiscal measures could impact Christmas trading, Weston also endorsed a strategic review—advised by Rothschild & Co and backed by the Weston family—of splitting budget retailer Primark from ABF’s food division. ABF reported a 26% slump in pre-tax profit to £1.4bn as sugar and agriculture costs rose, while Primark sales edged up 1%.

articles.title: BP signals more cost cuts on way after fall in profits
articles.trailText: Oil and gas company says it will review its portfolio and push to sell off assets faster
articles.summary: BP Q3 profit fell to $2.2 bn from $2.4 bn, though it beat forecasts. CEO Murray Auchincloss, under pressure from activist Elliott Management, plans to sell $20 bn of assets by 2027 and expects $5 bn by year-end. A portfolio review will simplify operations and cut costs. Recent disposals include US onshore wind, Dutch forecourts, EV charging hubs and a $1.5 bn Permian shale stake. BP also announced thousands of job and contractor cuts, using AI to boost efficiency.

articles.title: City watchdog ‘nakedly’ siding with lenders on car finance redress, MPs say
articles.trailText: Cross-party group says Financial Conduct Authority had been ‘patently influenced’ by concerns over profits
articles.summary: Cross-party All-Party Parliamentary Group on Fair Banking accuses the Financial Conduct Authority of 'nakedly' siding with car lenders in its planned compensation scheme for borrowers overcharged under dealer commission arrangements. Based on 2019 estimates, the FCA’s draft scheme forecasts redress of £8.2–£9.7bn (c. £700 per claim) versus the APPG’s £15.6bn projection, far below the £1,500 court average. MPs warn lenders, who also act as ‘judge and jury’, influenced the regulator by highlighting profit impacts, risking complex calculations open to exploitation. They deem the scheme unfit for purpose; the FCA defends its balanced, efficient approach.

articles.title: Outrage in Paris as Shein prepares to open its first permanent store
articles.trailText: Fast-fashion retailer faces political anger, fury from workers and warnings it will damage city’s progressive image
articles.summary: Shein will open its first permanent brick-and-mortar shop on the sixth floor of Paris’s BHV department store, igniting political outrage, staff protests and boycotts by independent French brands over fast-fashion’s labor and environmental record. City hall, the small-business minister and Communist officials warn the move undermines Paris’s sustainable image; Disneyland and a state bank have withdrawn partnerships. Meanwhile, Shein has paid €191m in 2025 fines for cookies, false advertising and microfibres, removed illicit “sex dolls” under threat of a ban, and plans further permanent outlets in Dijon, Reims, Grenoble, Angers and Limoges.

articles.title: We need clarity on big pharma’s tax breaks | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Pharmaceutical giants like GSK should be more transparent about the generous tax breaks they get from the UK government, says Mike Lewis
articles.summary: A Guardian letter urges transparency on Big Pharma’s UK tax breaks after revealing GSK has benefited from £3.4bn in patent-box relief (including £486m in 2024), surpassing the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council’s budget. Despite these subsidies, GSK’s outgoing CEO wants the NHS to pay more for drugs to drive ‘patient access to innovation.’ Critics note relief was even granted on a lupus drug unavailable to some UK patients at £769.50 per dose. With NHS budgets squeezed and tax hikes looming, they call on government to demand tangible public benefits and honesty from drug firms.

articles.title: Time for Reeves to recognise reality: AstraZeneca has killed stamp duty on shares | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Shareholder-backed plans to upgrade US listing have exposed multiple flaws in tax that should be abolished or at least cut
articles.summary: AstraZeneca won 99% backing to dual-list on NYSE while keeping London and Stockholm quotes, letting US investors bypass ADRs. The change will cost HM Treasury ~£200m/year by dodging the 0.5% stamp duty via depositary interests. Nils Pratley warns Chancellor Reeves that the levy’s high rate, partial reach (hitting only UK retail and pensions) and easy workarounds expose its obsolescence (no equivalent in US, China or Germany; only Ireland’s 1% rate is higher). He urges bold action—abolish or halve stamp duty, rather than limited relief—to safeguard revenue and competitiveness.

articles.title: Safety of train users and staff is paramount | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Problem with driver-only trains | A-level history | Unusual girl names | Theft in narrow daylight
articles.summary: Letters: Milton Keynes reader Jessica Holroyd criticises government and rail firms’ insistence on driver-only trains—which has delayed the new Oxford–Milton Keynes service—and warns against single-manning in light of a recent mass stabbing on a Cambridgeshire train. James Turtle celebrates the lost A-level history personal study for fostering original research. Linda Weir, ex-teacher, laments the use of 'Bidet' as a girl’s name. Dr Neil Denby jokes about 'narrow daylight' in response to the Louvre theft. The Guardian invites more letters.

articles.title: UK economy ‘doomed’ under Labour, says Ryanair chief
articles.trailText: Michael O’Leary says Rachel Reeves needs tax cuts to create growth, as airline’s profits jump 42% in first half
articles.summary: Ryanair CEO Michael O’Leary warns the UK economy is ‘doomed’ under Labour, accusing chancellor Rachel Reeves of stifling growth by taxing wealth and air travel before the budget. He urges selective tax cuts, warns rising air passenger duty could drive carriers from small UK airports to lower-tax markets, and claims new wealth levies are pushing wealthy residents from London. Ryanair’s H1 profits jumped 42% to €2.5bn, carrying 119m passengers (+3%), with average fares up 13% to €58. O’Leary predicts modest fare hikes through 2027-28 and accuses the EU’s two-bag cabin rule. Treasury counters APD hikes add only £2 per family flight.

articles.title: Kimberly-Clark to buy Tylenol maker Kenvue in landmark $40bn merger
articles.trailText: Kleenex maker’s deal for troubled Johnson & Johnson spinoff comes amid lawsuits and regulatory scrutiny
articles.summary: Kimberly-Clark will acquire consumer-health spinoff Kenvue for $40bn, combining Kleenex, Huggies, Tylenol, Neutrogena and Listerine. The deal follows Kenvue’s turbulent post-J&J IPO, CEO ouster, stock slump, lawsuits over baby powder and contested claims linking acetaminophen to autism by Trump and RFK Jr. KC expects $2.1bn in annual synergies and to close by late 2026, funded partly by proceeds from selling its tissue business to Suzano, amid broader cost pressures in fast-moving consumer goods. It reported a 3.5% drop in last-quarter net sales and warned of further low-single-digit declines this year.

articles.title: Nearly 90% of jobseekers unable to get long-term work despite millions spent on private job agencies
articles.trailText: Employment department’s annual report shows just 11.7% of jobseekers ended up with jobs lasting at least 26 weeks last year
articles.summary: Private employment services are failing to secure long-term jobs; only 11.7% of participants reached the 26-week threshold last year, well below the 15% government target. Since Workforce Australia’s 2022 launch, providers consistently underperform despite rising public spending (A$3,575 per outcome, 590,965 jobseekers served). A dedicated complaints line recorded 8,320 grievances, often citing providers’ coercive payslip demands to claim outcome payments. Critics argue the system punishes claimants—especially those facing skills mismatches, homelessness and cultural barriers—and call for abolishing mutual obligations, ending payment suspensions and boosting voluntary support programs.

articles.title: Jaguar Land Rover restart helps UK factories return to growth
articles.trailText: S&P Global purchasing managers’ index rises to one-year high amid pick-up in consumer spending
articles.summary: UK manufacturing rebounded in October as Jaguar Land Rover’s restarted facilities – closed since a cyber-attack costing an estimated £1.9 bn – drove output growth and consumer car spending. The S&P Global PMI rose to 49.7 from 46.2, with the output sub-index at 51.6 vs 45.7. Economists cite rising real wages, green and battery incentives, sterling’s depreciation and lower energy network charges as tailwinds. However, firms warn the jump may be temporary, with business optimism still below average ahead of a critical government budget.

articles.title: Tax rises and drop in investment predicted to limit UK growth
articles.trailText: EY Item Club downgrades forecast for next year, with Office for Budget Responsibility expected to follow suit
articles.summary: EY Item Club forecasts UK GDP growth under 1% (0.9%) in 2026, citing looming tax hikes, global trade disruption and high rates, after upgrading 2025 to 1.5%. The OBR is set to cut potential growth via a 0.3 pp productivity downgrade—slashing £21 bn of revenues. Business investment’s 3.7% boost this year is forecast to slump to 0.8%, while unemployment peaks at 5% and pay growth slows to 3.5% by end-2025 and 3% mid-2026. An IoD survey shows confidence at –73, with firms delaying hiring and spending amid tax and policy uncertainty. EY urges Reeves’s budget to balance deficit and growth.

articles.title: Australia’s richest person Gina Rinehart spotted at Donald Trump’s Halloween party
articles.trailText: The 1920s, Great Gatsby-themed bash also reportedly attracted the likes of One Nation leader, Pauline Hanson, though her office did not confirm
articles.summary: Australia’s mining billionaire and richest person, Gina Rinehart, was photographed whispering to Donald Trump at his 1920s Great Gatsby–themed Halloween gala at Mar-a-Lago, an event also attended by Jeanine Pirro and Secretary of State Marco Rubio. One Nation’s Pauline Hanson was rumored to be present, though her office declined confirmation. The party coincided with a US federal shutdown and Trump’s campaign to cut funding for a 42-million-beneficiary food aid program, even as he touts a privately funded $300m White House ballroom. Since Australia’s May election defeat, Rinehart has urged the Liberal Party to adopt Trump-style deregulation and tax-cut policies.

articles.title: The Nord Stream riddle: echoes of mistrust ripple through Europe
articles.trailText: Three years after explosion that crippled Russian-German gas link, Polish court’s refusal to extradite Ukrainian suspect reignited old tensions
articles.summary: Three years after the Nord Stream 1 and 2 pipelines were blown up in 2022, a Polish court refused to extradite Ukrainian diver Volodymyr Zhuravlev to Germany, ruling such sabotage could be seen as a defensive wartime act and questioning German jurisdiction. Polish PM Donald Tusk’s support for the decision and Hungary’s outrage have reignited East-West EU tensions over Russia, while Germany’s muted reaction and continued investigations, including Italy’s arrest of another Ukrainian suspect, underscore persistent legal and political fractures.

articles.title: John Lewis to open VIP lounge at Oxford Street store with free drinks and massages
articles.trailText: Waitrose chocolates will also be used to lure loyalty card holders in to the central London store
articles.summary: John Lewis will trial a VIP lounge at its Oxford Street store until Christmas, offering My John Lewis loyalty members free sparkling wine or hot drinks, hand and arm massages, Waitrose chocolates and Benugo cafe nibbles in a “VIP retreat” that holds up to 30 customers an hour and allows two guests per member. Bookable or walk-in, the lounge forms part of a wider £800m investment in store refurbishments and staffing to reverse trading headwinds after H1 losses nearly trebled to £88m. Membership in My John Lewis has risen 13% to 3.8m; a joint John Lewis-Waitrose loyalty card is planned.

articles.title: A million young people aren’t in a job or training. Britain has a problem | Richard Partington
articles.trailText: With the jobless rate now at 4.8%, ministers are urged to do more, especially for those with disabilities or health conditions
articles.summary: Britain’s youth unemployment and economic inactivity have surged: nearly 1m 16–24-year-olds are NEET, and the overall jobless rate has risen from 4.1% to 4.8%. Long-term ill-health and disability account for over a quarter of young NEETs—a figure that has doubled since 2005. Charlie Mayfield’s Keep Britain Working review urges businesses to invest in mental and physical health support, while the TUC warns against cutting disability benefits. Ministers must detail a “youth guarantee” in the upcoming budget, boosting training, apprenticeships and Access to Work reforms. Closing the UK’s NEET gap with top OECD rates could add £69bn to GDP.

articles.title: Victims robbed of £4bn in ‘insulting’ car loan redress scheme, say claims firms
articles.trailText: Financial Conduct Authority defends interest rate of 2.09% as critics describe proposals as ‘hypocritical’
articles.summary: Consumer groups and claims firms accuse the FCA of short-changing 14m car-loan customers by capping redress interest at 2.09%, risking a £4bn shortfall versus an 8% commercial rate. Borrowers would on average receive £700 rather than £1,030 under historic county court and Financial Ombudsman benchmarks. Critics argue the regulator’s proposal contradicts the 7% ‘commercial rate’ awarded in the Marcus Johnson Supreme Court victory and undermines fair compensation. The FCA insists linking payouts to the Bank of England base rate is “fair, proportionate” and open to challenge.

articles.title: Delivery firm DPD accused of ‘revenge’ sacking drivers who criticised pay cuts
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Labour peer calls for change in the law after company terminates contracts of strike ‘ringleaders’
articles.summary: DPD, which posted nearly £200m pre-tax profits in 2024, faced backlash after cutting delivery rates by 65p per drop and axing a £500 Christmas bonus, potentially costing drivers £6-8k a year. Around 1,500 self-employed drivers staged a three-day refusal, prompting DPD to defer but not cancel the cuts. Within weeks it terminated contracts of eight supplier firms and drivers deemed “ringleaders,” citing gagging-clause breaches and threatening to keep deposits to cover replacement costs. Labour peer John Hendy KC condemned the “revenge” sackings and urged legal reform to shield drivers lacking union protection.

articles.title: The London consensus is a timely challenge to Trump’s isolationism | Phillip Inman
articles.trailText: A debate on how to achieve fairer, greener growth could point the way to a successor for neoliberal capitalism
articles.summary: Renowned economists convened at LSE propose the ‘London consensus’ as a successor to the 1988 Washington consensus, challenging Trump’s nationalist, pro-privatization agenda. It advocates greener, inclusive growth: universal healthcare, sustainable spending, anti-inequality measures and wellbeing metrics—especially mental health—to gauge progress. It rejects high walls, low taxes and individualistic gains that fuel inequality. Empirical evidence cited shows that high inequality and neglect of communal welfare hinder economic dynamism. The book offers policy blueprints for state and subnational leaders to foster equitable prosperity and curb climate and social crises.

articles.title: ‘It’s brutal, they feel very attacked’: budget uncertainty hits Southampton boat show
articles.trailText: Rising prices and uncertainty over Rachel Reeves’s tax plans means this year many superyacht buyers are just browsing
articles.summary: At the Southampton international boat show, attendance and vendor participation fell by about 30% as high-net-worth buyers delayed purchases amid uncertainty over Rachel Reeves’s upcoming budget and potential hikes in capital gains, NIC on rental income and inheritance tax on pensions. Brokers report a 12% drop in sub-50m yacht sales—especially 30–40m sailing yachts—while 30–40m motor yachts remain flat. Bill Stringer of Key Yachting says clients have funds but are cautious, and Inspiration Marine’s average £400k sales have slowed. Despite a 7.9% decline in used yacht values, elite cash buyers still closed over €20m in deals.

articles.title: Nexperia halts chip supplies to China in threat to global car production
articles.trailText: Dutch-controlled company informs customers about suspension but is said to want to de-escalate trade war
articles.summary: EU-based chipmaker Nexperia has suspended all shipments to its Dongguan plant in southern China over alleged payment breaches, escalating a trade dispute rooted in the Netherlands’ national-security takeover from Chinese owner Wingtech. China swiftly banned exports from all Nexperia sites, threatening production at global automakers—Nissan, Honda, Mercedes and VW have warned of shortages of its low-cost power-control chips used in airbags, locks and mirrors. EU and Chinese officials plan further talks while Brussels accelerates its Chips Act strategy. Nexperia says it hopes to resume shipments once payments are resolved.

articles.title: JP Morgan warned US of $1bn in Epstein transactions possibly related to human trafficking
articles.trailText: Bank says it alerted US of ‘suspicious’ transactions just weeks after paedophile was found dead in New York jail cell
articles.summary: In 2019, JPMorgan filed a SAR with US authorities flagging around 4,700 transactions totalling more than $1 bn tied to Jeffrey Epstein—some potentially linked to human trafficking and transfers to Russian banks—just weeks after his death. The report, unsealed in 2024 following requests by the NYT and WSJ, highlighted Epstein’s ties to two US presidents and flagged transfers involving Leon Black, Glenn Dubin, Alan Dershowitz and $65 m in mid-2000s wire transfers via Leslie Wexner’s trusts. None have been charged. JPMorgan, Epstein’s bank for 15 years, settled US Virgin Islands claims without admitting liability, noting it filed SARs from 2013 on, but authorities took no action.

articles.title: Ministers’ claims to have helped JLR in doubt as £1.5bn support left untouched
articles.trailText: Exclusive : No cyber-attack assistance cash has gone into carmaker’s accounts or to struggling suppliers
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover has not drawn on any portion of the £1.5 billion UK Export Finance–guaranteed loan announced by Business Secretary Peter Kyle after a September cyber-attack halted production from 1 September to early October. Suppliers say ministers’ claims of supporting JLR’s supply chain are misleading—none of the funds reached JLR or its parts makers; instead JLR used its own cash reserves and prepaid parts. Tier 1 suppliers have been paid, but lower-tier firms face a critical cash-flow pinch with 60-day terms. MPs including Liam Byrne demand clarity on fund disbursement and monitoring.

articles.title: The Next wave: how the clothing retailer spread its wings and made sales surge
articles.trailText: From snapping up labels to growing its fanbase overseas, Next is dusting off its dull image while increasing profits
articles.summary: Next, the UK’s largest children’s clothing retailer, has rebranded into a multi-label fashion and homeware platform under CEO Simon Wolfson. Over five years it snapped up Cath Kidston and FatFace, took stakes in Reiss, Joules, Swoon, Sealskinz and Rockett St George, and holds UK distribution rights for Victoria’s Secret, Gap and Bath & Body Works. Non-Next brands now account for 40% of UK online sales (£1bn) and 20% of £930m international sales. A 39% surge in overseas trading drove profits to an expected £1.14bn.

articles.title: Champagne body attempts to buck Delevingne sisters’ marketing fizz
articles.trailText: Comité Champagne accuses Della Vite vegan prosecco firm of exploiting reputation and demands they stop referencing drink
articles.summary: Comité Champagne has demanded Della Vite, the vegan prosecco brand founded by Cara, Poppy and Chloe Delevingne in 2020, cease using "champagne" in slogans like "Cheat on champagne" and "Warning: This is not champagne," accusing them of unfairly exploiting and tarnishing champagne's reputation. After the sisters refused, Della Vite publicized a redacted cease-and-desist letter on social media. Poppy Delevingne said the cheeky campaign aimed to be provocative, while CEO Numa Heathcote argued that the backlash underscores how challenger brands are redefining luxury. Comité Champagne warns misuse of the protected term damages goodwill associated with the appellation.

articles.title: ‘The money machine is misfiring’: City blames Brexit for UK’s £20bn productivity headache
articles.trailText: Poor output since the leave vote has landed Rachel Reeves with a bigger-than-forecast budget spending gap
articles.summary: City of London productivity has underperformed vs EU hubs since Brexit, as 440 firms moved £1tn of assets to Frankfurt, Paris and Madrid. The OBR has cut its long-term productivity growth forecast from 1.25% to 0.9%, widening Rachel Reeves’s budget gap by around £21bn by 2030. Trade barriers with the EU have shaved 4% off output and finance exports have lost market share to the Netherlands, Ireland and Spain. Labour now blames Brexit in its fiscal plans, pledging planning reform, red-tape cuts and trade deals to reboot growth, but faces limits on re-joining EU single market. Reforms of financial services and smoothed regulation are central to raising productivity and tax receipts.

articles.title: Tinned tuna maker Princes floats at nearly £1.2bn in boost for London
articles.trailText: Business secretary calls IPO ‘huge vote of confidence’ but shares are launched at bottom end of target range
articles.summary: The Princes Group, a 150-year-old tinned tuna, tomato and olive oil specialist controlled by Italy’s NewPrinces, floated on London’s stock market at a valuation of nearly £1.2bn. Shares priced at the bottom of a £1.16–1.24bn range fell 1% on debut as the firm aims to raise £400m for expansion. The IPO follows a rebound in UK listings, with recent floats by Shawbrook, Beauty Tech and talks of Revolut’s dual listing. Business secretary Peter Kyle hailed the move as a vote of confidence in UK capital markets.

articles.title: Starbucks workers hold strike vote amid anger over pay and conditions
articles.trailText: Union says world’s largest coffee chain engaged in bad faith bargaining and stonewalled over contract
articles.summary: Unionized Starbucks workers at over 650 US stores (12,000+ employees in 45 states and DC) are voting (Oct 24–Nov 2) on authorizing a strike amid stalled contract negotiations, low wages (some under $16/hr vs. CEO Brian Niccol’s $97.8m pay), and alleged bad-faith bargaining and labor-law breaches. Starbucks Workers United, which claims management “stonewalled” economic proposals after tentative 80–90% agreement, plans 70 pickets in 60 cities; Starbucks counters that the union walked away and touts average partner pay/benefits above $30/hr. A strong vote could trigger a nationwide walkout and set a precedent for US labor organizing.

articles.title: UK house price growth slows as buyers ‘sit on sidelines’ before budget
articles.trailText: Amid talk of property taxes, average price of home rose by 0.3% in October to £272,226, Nationwide says
articles.summary: In October the average UK house price rose by 0.3% month-on-month to £272,226, down from September’s 0.5% gain, while annual growth ticked up to 2.4% from 2.2%. Analysts say buyers are ‘sitting on the sidelines’ ahead of the 26 November budget, which may introduce taxes on sales over £500,000. Despite sluggish high-end sales and muted autumn bidding, market resilience persists: mortgage rates remain above pre-Covid levels but interest-rate cuts are anticipated. Nationwide forecasts modest affordability gains if incomes outpace prices and borrowing costs ease.

articles.title: What – if anything – did Asian countries get out of Donald Trump’s whirlwind tour?
articles.trailText: Uncertainty surrounds the signing of this week’s trade deals amid the failure to secure reciprocity from the US to cut tariffs
articles.summary: During his Asia tour Trump secured non-binding trade frameworks in Malaysia, Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam under Asean, pledges to boost US imports and diversify critical mineral supply chains without immediate tariff cuts. He brokered a Thai-Cambodia ceasefire and positioned himself as peacemaker. In Japan he signed a rare earths security pact with PM Takaichi alongside ongoing tariff talks. In South Korea he pushed through a $350bn trade-investment deal, approved US-built nuclear submarines, and held a surprise meeting with Xi Jinping to pause the US-China trade war. Analysts note limited US reciprocity and risks tied to implementation.

articles.title: Two million energy customers are due £240m from old accounts, says Ofgem
articles.trailText: Regulator is urging anyone who has moved in recent years to check whether they are owed a refund
articles.summary: Ofgem estimates 1.9 million closed energy accounts over the past five years still hold £240 million in unclaimed credit. It urges anyone who has moved recently to contact their former supplier—some refunds exceed £100. At the same time, the regulator has lifted the UK price cap, increasing the average annual dual-fuel bill by £35 to £1,755, and confirmed a £500 m debt-relief scheme for around 195,000 low-income households, offering about £1,200 per account. The relief, funded by a £5 annual bill rise by 2027-28, aims to tackle a record £4.4 bn in unpaid energy debts amid ongoing affordability pressures.

articles.title: Ofcom criticises O2 for going ‘against the spirit’ of new pricing rules
articles.trailText: Bills for up to 15 million customers will rise by more than they were told when they signed contracts
articles.summary: Ofcom has criticised O2 for raising mobile bills by 70p above the £1.80 per month originally promised, pushing annual increases from £21.60 to £30 for up to 15m customers from April 2026. The UK telecoms regulator said this “goes against the spirit” of its new rules requiring upfront “pounds and pence” disclosures to prevent nasty surprises. MoneySavingExpert founder Martin Lewis warned other operators may follow suit. Ofcom has reminded operators of fair-treatment obligations and highlighted customers’ rights to exit penalty-free, while O2 insists it complied and invests £700m annually in network improvements.

articles.title: Novo Nordisk bids $9bn for obesity drug maker Metsera in challenge to Pfizer
articles.trailText: US biotech viewed as lucrative target partly because of its promising pipeline of weight-loss drugs
articles.summary: Novo Nordisk launched unsolicited $9bn bid for US obesity biotech Metsera, topping Pfizer’s prior $7.3bn proposal by offering $56.50/share plus $21.25 contingent on milestones. Metsera, with four ongoing clinical trials—including an amylin-based pill and injection—deems it superior. Pfizer calls the move ‘reckless’ and anticompetitive, vowing legal action while having four days to revise its $47.50/$22.50 offer. Novo Nordisk cites strategic expansion amid slowing profit growth and intensifying rivalry with Eli Lilly’s more potent Mounjaro; Lilly raised guidance as it eyes its own weight-loss pill approval.

articles.title: ECB keeps interest rates on hold despite eurozone inflation fears
articles.trailText: Key deposit rate kept at 2% even as recovery starts to drive up price growth across bloc
articles.summary: The ECB kept its key deposit rate at 2% for the third straight meeting despite eurozone inflation rising to 2.2% in September and 2.6% in the wider EU. Governing council sees inflation outlook unchanged, citing a strong labour market and solid private-sector balance sheets. President Christine Lagarde said the unanimous hold reflects balanced risks, aided by recent trade deals and ceasefire, though volatile global trade poses supply-chain risks. Eurozone GDP rose 0.2% in Q3, led by Spain (0.6%) and France (0.5%), amid divergent inflation from 0% in Cyprus to 8.6% in Romania.

articles.title: Volkswagen indicates shortage of Chinese chips would hit profits
articles.trailText: New EV models are offsetting a slump in demand but Europe’s carmakers are bracing for shutdowns
articles.summary: Volkswagen warned its full-year operating profit guidance (2–3%) is under threat from a looming semiconductor shortage triggered by halted supplies of China-made chips from Nexperia. The German carmaker, which sold 6.6m vehicles in the first nine months of 2025 (+1.8% y/y), has used cost-cutting and launches of new EV models, such as the Skoda Elroq, to offset a slump in Chinese demand. However, US tariffs on key models (€5bn hit) and a €1.3bn operating loss—following a €4.7bn EV-strategy writedown at Porsche—have weakened results. CFO Arno Antlitz blamed politically driven export bans, while EU manufacturers brace for potential plant shutdowns amid dwindling chip and rare-earth supplies.

articles.title: Virgin Media O2 teams with Musk’s Starlink to offer improved UK rural mobile coverage
articles.trailText: Service scheduled to launch in 2026 will be first in Britain to use Starlink’s satellites to connect to handsets
articles.summary: Virgin Media O2 will partner with Elon Musk's Starlink to launch O2 Satellite in H1 2026—the UK's first mobile service directly connecting handsets to satellites when terrestrial signals fail. Using Starlink's 650+ satellites, it offers messaging and data (voice/video excluded, though WhatsApp calls may work) in rural areas for an add-on monthly fee. CEO Lutz Schüler cites this UK-first innovation alongside £700m network investment; telecoms minister Liz Lloyd hails private-sector growth and rural inclusion. Starlink's UK footprint spans rural broadband, prepper use and Ukrainian support. Meanwhile, O2 eyes a £2bn bid for Netomnia.

articles.title: Shell’s profits pass $43bn after production hits new highs in Brazil and Gulf of Mexico
articles.trailText: Oil company plans to buy back shares for 16th consecutive quarter as protesters say its earnings are ‘horror show’
articles.summary: Shell’s year-to-date profits topped $43 bn after Q3 earnings of $5.4 bn (up 27% on Q2) powered by record deepwater output in the Gulf of Mexico and Brazil’s Whale platform, which delivered faster and higher volumes than forecast. With oil at $69/barrel, Shell still presumes one of the industry’s strongest balance sheets, launches a further $3.5 bn share buyback (16th straight quarter) to return 40–50% of cashflow, and incurs a £387 m UK windfall tax charge. Ministers may scrap the levy in 2029 pending investment guarantees. Fossil Free London protesters deemed the profits a “horror show.”

articles.title: Virgin Trains on track to challenge Eurostar cross-Channel monopoly with access to key depot
articles.trailText: UK rail regulator approves Richard Branson firm’s application to use Temple Mills site in London
articles.summary: The UK rail regulator has approved Virgin Trains’ bid to use Temple Mills depot in east London, unlocking £700 million of investment and 400 jobs to maintain and store international rolling stock on HS1. This critical step brings Richard Branson’s firm closer to ending Eurostar’s 30-year Channel Tunnel monopoly by 2030, with planned services from St Pancras to Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam—and future expansion into Germany and Switzerland. Further track-access and safety approvals are still required. The ORR rejected rival applications, while government and industry leaders back competition and explore additional depot capacity to boost cross-Channel growth.

articles.title: Business and charity leaders urge ministers to lead England’s transition to four-day week
articles.trailText: Open letter signed by more than 100 leaders comes after local government secretary criticised a council for switching to shorter week
articles.summary: Over 100 business and charity leaders, coordinated by the 4 Day Week Foundation, have written to the business secretary urging ministers to create a working-time council and lead England’s transition to a four-day week. Their appeal follows local government secretary Steve Reed’s criticism of South Cambridgeshire council’s trial, which he said harmed housing services—claims council leader Bridget Smith rejects, citing stable or improved performance and a £399,000 annual net saving. Campaigners like 4 Day Week director Joe Ryle argue the model boosts productivity; to date 430 UK firms and 200,000+ workers have adopted it, and 25 more councils plan trials.

articles.title: Benefits of a four-day week are ever clearer, despite Steve Reed’s stance
articles.trailText: Housing secretary’s criticism of trial in South Cambridgeshire council ignores its many positives
articles.summary: In a trial by South Cambridgeshire District Council, a four-day week showed stability or improvement in 21 of 24 performance metrics, despite Housing Secretary Steve Reed citing declines in rent collection, tenant repair satisfaction and re-letting times. Academics warn these dips may stem from external factors such as cost-of-living pressures, contractor shortages and housing market conditions, rather than reduced hours. Broader trials of 61 companies and 2,900 workers found four-day weeks cut burnout, improve work-life balance, reduce staff turnover by 57% and raise revenue by 35%, underscoring growing momentum for flexible working.

articles.title: ‘Patients will suffer’: tales from the frontline of the UK pharma crisis
articles.trailText: The pricing standoff between government and industry has stalled research and put thousands of jobs at risk
articles.summary: Chancellor Reeves signals an NHS drug price rise after Merck scrapped a £1bn London research hub. Government is weighing up to a 25% pay hike to end a standoff that’s paused or cancelled nearly £2bn of R&D and threatens over 1,000 biopharma jobs. Patient groups like the Spinal Muscular Atrophy charity warn delays in access—highlighting the £1.8m Zolgensma injection versus long-term care cost savings—will harm outcomes. Graduates face steeper competition amid a 35% drop in pharma hiring. Experts also flag low antibiotic returns and 10% vacant UK lab space, suggesting smaller biotechs or state support will be vital to sustain innovation.

articles.title: Pound sinks against euro and dollar as tax rises loom and growth slows
articles.trailText: Prospect of a tough budget is thought to have brought forward the likely date for a cut in interest rates to 3.75%
articles.summary: Looming tax rises in Rachel Reeves’s 26 Nov budget and downgraded productivity forecasts have pushed sterling to two-year lows against the euro (€1.13) and dollar ($1.32). Markets now price a BoE rate cut from 4% to 3.75% in February (vs March) – Goldman Sachs even flags next week’s meeting – as lower inflation (3.8% y/y) and falling food-price inflation bolster doves. ING raises odds of a cut in the early-Nov meeting to 35%. Meanwhile, the Fed trimmed US rates by 25bp to 3.75-4%, keeping dollar yields higher and weighing further on the pound.

articles.title: Fed cuts interest rates for second time this year amid economic uncertainty
articles.trailText: Central bank sets rates at range between 3.75% and 4% amid turbulence from government shutdown and Trump’s tariffs
articles.summary: The Federal Reserve on Oct 29 cut its benchmark rate by 25 bp to 3.75–4%, its second cut this year, citing turbulence from the federal shutdown and Trump’s tariffs. Chair Jerome Powell warned there is “no risk-free path” amid cooling labor markets and still-elevated inflation. Two dissenters—Stephen Miran (for a larger cut) and Kansas City Fed’s Jeffrey Schmid (for no change)—underscored division ahead of December. BLS furloughs obscure recent jobs data after weak August gains and a 32k ADP loss, while annual inflation has risen to 3%.

articles.title: EU carmakers ‘days away’ from halting work as chip war with China escalates
articles.trailText: Industry body says reserves of Nexperia semiconductors are dwindling after Beijing bans exports of key components
articles.summary: EU carmakers warn they’re days from halting production as China bans Nexperia chip exports after the Dutch government’s takeover of the company. ACEA members including BMW, VW, Fiat, Peugeot and Mercedes say reserve stocks are dwindling and alternative suppliers could take months to scale up. Nissan expects shortages to last into November. The ban follows Beijing’s controls on rare earth exports amid US-China trade tensions. High-level EU-China talks are scheduled in Brussels, but manufacturers fear diplomatic efforts may not avert assembly-line stoppages.

articles.title: UK must reform drug pricing to become life sciences superpower, says GSK boss
articles.trailText: Shares jump on higher profits as Emma Walmsley is ‘hopeful’ standoff with NHS can be resolved
articles.summary: Outgoing GSK CEO Emma Walmsley warns UK risks failing to become a life-sciences superpower without overhauling drug pricing amid talks to boost NHS spending on new medicines by up to 25%. A deal links UK plans to US pricing negotiations under Trump’s tariffs threat. Science minister Patrick Vallance signals inevitable price rises, prompting calls for extra NHS funding. GSK, which invests $30bn in the US but backs the UK strategy—unlike rivals MSD and AstraZeneca—raised 2025 forecasts as Q3 profit surged to £2.5bn, driving shares up 6%. Vaccine sales grew 2%, while US Shingrix sales fell 15%.

articles.title: Toyota denies promising to invest $10bn in US after Trump announcement
articles.trailText: The US president claimed he had been told the carmaker was going to be setting up factories ‘all over’ the US
articles.summary: Toyota Motor has refuted President Donald Trump's claim that the automaker pledged over $10bn in US factory investments during his visit to Japan. Senior executive Hiroyuki Ueda told reporters no explicit commitment at that scale was made, though Toyota plans to maintain investment and US job creation levels similar to its first term spending (around $10bn). Ueda noted talks with officials preceded Trump’s remarks and the chairman did not discuss new funding. The disclosure came as Trump and Japan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, signed rare-earths and trade deals.

articles.title: So it’s goodbye to lower interest rates – to be honest, the RBA was always looking for an excuse not to cut | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: The story this quarter was one of big jumps in electricity prices due to the end of the state subsidies
articles.summary: RBA abandons expected rate cut after Sept Q CPI jumped 1.2% (3.2% yoy), driven by a surge in electricity prices (+15% of CPI rise) as state subsidies expired. Core measures (trimmed mean 2.95%, weighted median 2.85%) remain within the 2–3% target. Rising property rates, dwelling-purchase costs and non-discretionary items (electricity, rents) inflict disproportionate pain on low-income households. Higher rates persist to curb inflation despite 4.5% unemployment, favoring established or mortgage-free borrowers over younger, poorer Australians.

articles.title: Profit upgrade at Next raises hopes UK shoppers still keen to spend
articles.trailText: Sales benefited from warm summer, M&S online shutdown after cyber-attack and supply improvements
articles.summary: Next upgraded full-year profit guidance by £30m to £1.14bn, its fourth upgrade in eight months, after sales and profits beat forecasts thanks to a warm summer, improved supply from Bangladesh and M&S’s multi-week online shutdown post-cyber-attack. UK sales rose 5.4% (vs 1.9% expected), led by 12.6% growth at Label online; UK stores +2%, Next online +4.2%; international sales +39%. Shares jumped 7%, and Next, which holds UK rights to Gap and Victoria’s Secret and stakes in Reiss and Joules, reported £369m surplus cash earmarked for a January special dividend. Analysts praise its resilience amid weak consumer confidence and budget uncertainty.

articles.title: Santander urges ministers to intervene in UK car finance compensation scheme
articles.trailText: Lender’s chief executive says redress proposals could affect jobs, supply chains and broader UK economy
articles.summary: Santander UK has urged ministers to revise the FCA’s proposed £11bn car-finance redress scheme covering 14m historic loans, citing risks to consumers, credit supply, auto sector jobs and the broader UK economy. CEO Mike Regnier, referencing last August’s Supreme Court ruling and a rejected chancellor bid to limit “windfall” payouts, delayed Santander’s UK results pending “greater clarity” despite reserving £295m. Lenders, claims firms and carmakers (Mercedes £371m, BMW £207m, Honda £62.2m) are racing to respond to consultation by mid-November. The FCA and Treasury maintain the scheme is the most efficient way to resolve liabilities.

articles.title: Aston Martin cuts investment plan by £300m as Trump tariffs bite
articles.trailText: Carmaker’s third-quarter losses bigger than expected at £112m, with weak demand in China also a factor
articles.summary: Aston Martin cut £300m from its 2025–26 capex after Q3 pre-tax losses of £112m (vs £12m a year earlier), hit by a 25% US auto tariff and weak Chinese demand. Q3 retail sales fell 13% to 1,430 cars; nine-month revenues dropped 26% to £740m. CEO Adrian Hallmark plans a product-cycle review to optimise costs, having delayed its first EV launch and cut 5% of staff. The firm starts delivering its 999-unit Valhalla hybrid supercar this quarter. Investor Lawrence Stroll remains confident despite macro headwinds; further restructuring details due early next year.

articles.title: Inflation jumps to 3.2%, dashing hopes of a Melbourne Cup day rate cut for homeowners
articles.trailText: The RBA has long anticipated a rebound in the headline inflation rate, driven by the rolling expiry of generous household power bill subsidies
articles.summary: Australia’s annual inflation jumped to 3.2% in September from 2.1% in June as the expiry of electricity bill subsidies drove a 24% rise in power costs. Underlying inflation rose for the first time in nearly three years, with the RBA’s trimmed mean hitting 3% annual and 1% quarterly versus a 0.6% forecast. Grocery costs climbed 3.1%, led by a 15% surge in coffee prices. The surprise spike dashes hopes of an October rate cut and likely delays further easing into 2026.

articles.title: ‘A stomach of steel’: amateur investors ride out dips amid talk of an AI bubble
articles.trailText: As one 23-year-old buys a house with his winnings, experts say risk-takers are fuelling an unsustainable market
articles.summary: Amateur investors like 23-year-old Jacob Foot have poured savings into AI-heavy Magnificent Seven stocks since 2020, holding through dips (“buy the f-ing dip”) and driving M7 valuation up 37% over 12 months vs 15% for the rest of the S&P 500. M7 now makes up a third of the index, with Nvidia trading at a P/E of 54. Despite BoE, IMF and JP Morgan warnings of an AI bubble, record retail inflows (e.g. $3 bn on 3 Apr) and low-cost trading apps fuel sustained price inflation beyond fundamentals.

articles.title: Ben & Jerry’s owner stopped brand developing flavour for peace in Gaza
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Co-founder accuses ice-cream brand’s parent of taking part in ‘corporate butt kissing’ of Donald Trump
articles.summary: Ben & Jerry’s co-founder Ben Cohen accuses Unilever of “corporate butt kissing” of Donald Trump and claims management blocked a board-approved flavour in solidarity with Gaza, in breach of its independent social-mission agreement. He’s launched a “Free Ben & Jerry’s” campaign to sell the brand to socially minded investors who’ll uphold its activism. Unilever and Magnum counter that the Palestine flavour wasn’t commercially viable and insist Ben & Jerry’s isn’t for sale. Cohen will now produce a small-batch Gaza solidarity ice cream under his Ben’s Best label, inviting public input on a watermelon-based recipe.

articles.title: BT ‘considering low-cost mobile brand’ as Revolut and Monzo plan launches
articles.trailText: Move into budget market could involve creating new brand in-house or buying virtual network operator
articles.summary: BT is considering a low-cost mobile brand—either launching in-house or buying a virtual network operator—to challenge fintech VNO entrants such as Revolut, Monzo and rivals like Klarna and Octopus-backed Fern Trading. Currently restricted to premium EE mobile and Plusnet broadband, BT aims to defend against VNOs’ 16.5% share by targeting budget-conscious and older users, potentially extending the core BT brand. The plan, backed by CEO Allison Kirkby and major shareholder Sunil Bharti Mittal, remains under review, with no changes confirmed.

articles.title: HSBC warns it could take years to settle Madoff case as bank takes $1.1bn hit
articles.trailText: Lawsuit over Ponzi scheme drags on London-headquartered lender, whose profits plunge by 14%
articles.summary: HSBC warned settling a lawsuit by investors in Bernard Madoff’s $65bn Ponzi scheme could take months or years after a $1.1bn provision cut Q3 pre-tax profit 14% to $7.3bn. CFO Pam Kaur flagged the case’s complexity, ongoing Luxembourg appeals over its fund administration arm and potential payout variability. The provision, plus a $1bn buffer for China–Hong Kong real-estate losses and restructuring costs from staff shake-ups, offset net interest income growth (+15% to $8.8bn) and fee income (+12% to $3.5bn). HSBC says its private-credit exposure is modest, focusing on second-order risks as CEO Georges Elhedery drives strategic simplification.

articles.title: Steeper UK productivity cut of more than £20bn makes tax rises more likely
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves faces bigger-than-expected hit in 26 November budget from revised OBR forecast
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves faces a £20–30bn shortfall in her 26 November budget after the Office for Budget Responsibility downgrades UK trend productivity growth by 0.3 percentage points—implying a £21bn hit based on IFS’s £7bn-per-0.1-point rule. The revision, reflecting post-2008 stagnation and Brexit effects, threatens Labour’s manifesto pledge not to raise income tax, VAT or national insurance. Reeves, in Riyadh, insists she won’t curb growth but is reportedly weighing a possible income tax rise and a planned £2bn boost from higher NI on professionals. The OBR forecast is due on 26 November.

articles.title: After my car was damaged in a Tesco car wash it has washed its hands of my complaint
articles.trailText: The tail spoiler and brake light were ripped off needing £750 repair, but it claims there was no fault with the machine
articles.summary: Regular user JM of Dumfries & Galloway had their car’s tail spoiler and brake light torn off in a Tesco automated wash, with repairs estimated at £750. Tesco refuses liability, citing a contractor’s maintenance report (not disclosed due to "policy") finding no machine fault and pointing to an entrance disclaimer. Similar cases prompted identical solicitor letters denying defects and claims. Tesco insists claims are reviewed case-by-case, advising the customer to claim via insurer or issue a 14-day letter before action, then pursue small-claims ("simple procedure") in Scottish sheriff court (or county court in England/Wales).

articles.title: CSL share price plummets amid shareholder revolt over executive pay plans
articles.trailText: US vaccination forecast leads to fall in stock price, while board survives spill in ‘second strike’ over pay concerns at AGM
articles.summary: CSL’s AGM delivered a second strike on pay, with >40% of votes against the remuneration report, but shareholders decisively rejected a board spill, keeping directors in place. The backlash came as shares fell 15% Tuesday, deepening a >35% YTD slide, after forecasts of weaker US flu vaccination (-12% overall; -14% aged 65+) hit outlook. Chair Brian McNamee called the US drop remarkable. Investors decry a pay–performance mismatch and the costly 2022 Vifor acquisition; CSL has been cited as paying more in CEO bonuses than Australian company tax. CEO Paul McKenzie earned US$6.06m; predecessor Paul Perreault once topped US$45m. CSL defends global-market pay even as Australia’s two-strikes rule pressures remuneration.

articles.title: RBA governor dismisses jobs fears but hints at rates hold after inflation uptick
articles.trailText: Michele Bullock plays down concerns about rising joblessness as economists pencil in February for next reduction in borrowing costs
articles.summary: RBA governor Michele Bullock downplayed a spike in unemployment to 4.5%, asserting jobs won’t “fall off a cliff,” but acknowledged inflation’s uptick could delay rate cuts. Following hotter-than-expected CPI and weaker labour data, markets slashed odds of a November cut from 60% to about 10%, though December still sits at 80%. Bullock signalled an interest-rate hold as the board weighs fresh forecasts, with economists now eyeing the first cut around February pending CPI’s trimmed-mean trajectory amid rising power prices.

articles.title: Cobar: two people killed in Endeavour mine explosion in far western NSW
articles.trailText: Woman and man confirmed dead and another woman airlifted to hospital after blast at Endeavour mine
articles.summary: An explosion at the Endeavour underground silver-zinc-lead mine, 40 km north of Cobar (600 km NW of Sydney), killed a man in his 60s and a woman in her 20s before dawn, and injured another woman, airlifted to Orange hospital with hearing damage and shock. All three were local residents. The NSW resources regulator has launched an investigation, while Polymetals has suspended Endeavour operations and halted ASX trading. Premier Chris Minns and the Cobar mayor described the community’s devastation and stressed the need for stringent mining safety.

articles.title: Shrinkflation hits everyday staples, piling more pressure on households
articles.trailText: Which? finds products shrinking while supermarkets keep prices flat or rising
articles.summary: Which? finds shrinkflation in everyday groceries: Aquafresh toothpaste fell from 100ml at £1.30 to 75ml at £2 (105% per-100ml rise); Gaviscon liquid from 600ml to 500ml at unchanged £14 (20% hike); Nescafé instant coffee down 5% from 200g to 190g; Quality Street tubs cut from 600g to 550g with price up from £6 to £7; McVitie’s biscuits now contain more palm and shea oil than cocoa. Brands cite cost pressures and retail discretion. Which? urges clearer unit pricing for informed choices. Meanwhile UK shop price inflation eased to 1% in October from 1.4%, led by ambient foods.

articles.title: First banker jailed over Libor interest rate rigging to sue UBS for $400m
articles.trailText: Tom Hayes claims he was ‘hand-picked scapegoat’ for the Swiss bank as it tried to avoid regulatory scrutiny
articles.summary: Tom Hayes, the first banker jailed over Libor rigging, is suing UBS for $400m in a Connecticut court, alleging he was a "hand-picked scapegoat" as UBS misled US regulators and branded him an "evil mastermind" to shield senior executives and reduce fines. Hayes served 5½ years of an 11-year sentence related to alleged rate-fixing from 2006–10. After the UK supreme court overturned his unsafe conviction in July, he accuses UBS of malicious prosecution and a flawed probe that ruined his family, health and career. UBS declined to comment.

articles.title: UK in £8bn deal to sell Typhoon jets to Turkey despite human rights concerns
articles.trailText: Starmer’s announcement on visit to Ankara comes as jailed opposition leader Ekrem İmamoğlu faces fresh charges
articles.summary: Britain’s new prime minister Keir Starmer sealed an £8bn agreement to sell 20 Typhoon fighter jets to Turkey during his visit to Ankara, praising it as a boost to NATO and UK defense jobs. The Eurofighter deal secures about 500 jobs at BAE Systems’ Lancashire plants and benefits European partners, with deliveries from 2030. Critics, including Amnesty International, warn the UK has overlooked President Erdoğan’s human rights abuses as jailed opposition leader Ekrem İmamoğlu faces fresh espionage charges, amid a broader crackdown on dissent and threats to civil liberties such as same-sex marriage. The sale reflects London’s export-driven strategy despite ethical concerns.

articles.title: Exxon sues California over climate laws, alleging free speech violations
articles.trailText: Oil firm asks court to block enforcement of laws that would require disclosure of planet-heating carbon emissions
articles.summary: Exxon Mobil has filed suit in federal court to block two provisions of California’s 2023 Climate Accountability Package, which mandate that large companies disclose their greenhouse-gas emissions, climate-related financial risks and global footprint using state-prescribed reporting frameworks beginning in 2026. The oil major says the rules violate its First Amendment rights, conflict with federal securities laws and improperly force it to adopt the Greenhouse Gas Protocol rather than its preferred Ipieca methodology. California officials and advocates defend the requirements as crucial to transparency and anti-greenwashing.

articles.title: US debt set to soar above Italy and Greece after Trump’s ‘big, beautiful bill’
articles.trailText: While the European countries have brought their spending under control, the US president’s tax cuts and defence spending will lead to increased borrowing
articles.summary: IMF forecasts US debt will rise from 125% to 143% of GDP by 2030, overtaking Italy (steady at ~137%) and Greece (cutting from 146% to 130%). Trump’s “big, beautiful bill” of broad tax cuts for middle- and high-earners and a $1 trn defence ‘golden dome’ drive persistent deficits above 7%, forcing heavy borrowing. By contrast, Italy and Greece have reined in post-crisis spending, aim for primary surpluses and will meet Brussels’ 3% deficit cap early. Economists warn that perpetual US shortfalls and Europe’s slower growth leave both regions fiscally vulnerable.

articles.title: Oil and gas firm Petrofac files for administration, putting thousands of jobs at risk
articles.trailText: North Sea contractor says move applies only to its ultimate holding company and it will continue to trade
articles.summary: Petrofac, a major North Sea oil contractor with ~7,300 employees globally and ~2,000 based in Aberdeen, has filed for administration of its ultimate holding company after losing a TenneT offshore wind contract, burdened by debts approaching $4bn. The move follows past bribery convictions and pandemic-driven losses. While it continues trading and its UK arm remains outside administration, it risks thousands of jobs and heightens political pressure on the government’s North Sea licensing and climate agenda. Energy secretary Ed Miliband’s DESNZ is coordinating support, and the UK unit could attract buyers.

articles.title: UK watchdog raises competition concerns over Greencore-Bakkavor deal
articles.trailText: Proposed £1.2bn takeover of Tesco, M&S, Sainsbury’s, Waitrose and Asda supplier is being examined by CMA
articles.summary: CMA raises concerns that Greencore’s proposed £1.2bn acquisition of rival Bakkavor—suppliers to Tesco, M&S, Sainsbury’s, Waitrose and Asda—could substantially lessen competition in the UK supermarket own-label chilled sauces market. The watchdog’s phase-1 review, completed ahead of a 3 November deadline, flagged chilled sauces as the only contested segment out of a combined £4bn convenience foods business, noting no issues with 99% of revenues. If unresolved, CMA will launch a phase-2 probe. Both CEOs called the process constructive and aim to close the deal early 2026.

articles.title: AI can help authors beat writer’s block, says Bloomsbury chief
articles.trailText: Publisher last week reported jump in revenue in academic and professional arm thanks to AI licensing deal
articles.summary: Nigel Newton, founder and CEO of Bloomsbury, says AI tools can spark creativity and help authors overcome writer's block by drafting initial chapters, and could extend to other arts like painting and music. He cautions that fully AI-written books may lack authority, and readers will gravitate to established names. Bloomsbury's shares jumped as much as 10% after a 20% revenue rise in its academic and professional arm—driven by an AI licensing deal—though its consumer division fell 20% without a new Sarah J. Maas title. Meanwhile, authors are challenging AI firms like Anthropic over training data disputes.

articles.title: Supermarkets tell Reeves tax rises could push food prices higher
articles.trailText: Households would ‘inevitably feel the impact’ of a surtax on business rates, say retailers in letter to chancellor
articles.summary: UK supermarkets warned Chancellor Rachel Reeves that including large grocers in a new business‑rates surtax on properties with rateable value above £500,000 at the 26 November budget would raise costs and push food prices higher, prolonging elevated food inflation into 2026. Bosses from Tesco, Asda, Sainsbury’s, Morrisons, Aldi, Lidl, M&S, Waitrose and Iceland signed the letter, citing April’s £25bn employer NICs hike and a 6.7% national living wage rise. The BRC urged exempting supermarkets—shifting burden to offices/industrial sites at no taxpayer cost. Headline inflation is 3.8%; food inflation eased to 4.5% in September. Treasury: boosting incomes, cutting some shop rates.

articles.title: Does your boss have the right to time your bathroom breaks when you work from home? | Gene Marks
articles.trailText: For remote work arrangements to be successful, managers and employees need to meet somewhere in the middle
articles.summary: Gene Marks uses a viral New York Post anecdote—a manager imposing a five-minute rule requiring WFH staff to notify the team whenever stepping away, even for the bathroom—to critique micromanagement. He calls the policy absurd, yet says it exposes unresolved tensions over remote productivity. Older small-business owners and some CEOs (JPMorgan’s Jamie Dimon, Amazon’s Andy Jassy) argue office work yields more output; studies are mixed. Marks urges a middle ground: employees should treat WFH as an earned benefit—be reachable, hit goals, accept IT oversight, avoid Monday/Friday optics, stay professional at home—while employers stop surveillance, skip monitoring software, and trust that autonomy and flexibility (especially for caregivers) boost success.

articles.title: Trump sanctions have swift impact but will world stop buying Russian oil and gas?
articles.trailText: Analysts say president’s war on Russia’s fossil fuel revenues is a chance to bring peace to Ukraine and profit to US
articles.summary: Trump sanctioned Rosneft and Lukoil, threatening dollar access for buyers, to choke Russia’s war funds. Oil jumped 6%; reports said Indian refineries and Chinese SOEs paused Russian cargoes. Asia took 86% of Russia’s crude Jan–Sep; losing India/China could cut $7.4bn revenue and $3.6bn taxes monthly; India’s state refineries’ imports fell 38% in Sept. Russia’s fossil earnings hit post‑invasion low, aided by “shadow tankers.” China blasted “economic coercion”; Modi gave no pledge. EU is largest buyer of Russian LNG and pipeline gas but plans a 2027 phaseout; US LNG supplies 55%. Enforcement will decide. Hungary and Slovakia lead EU gas buys.

articles.title: Peer trying to derail UK smoking ban discussed bill with relative at tobacco firm
articles.trailText: Lord Strathcarron says he and an in-law ‘high up’ at British American Tobacco discussed bill, which he aims to weaken
articles.summary: UK peer Lord Strathcarron, who tabled 1 May amendments to scrap the Tobacco and Vapes Bill's generational sales ban (for anyone born after 2008) and instead raise the age to 21, discussed the bill with an in-law "very high up" at British American Tobacco. His stance mirrors BAT lobbying; tobacco firms have threatened legal action. He hadn't declared the link, calling the relative "barely family". He called cigars "harmless" and disclosed a separate tie: a minority investor in one of his firms makes vapes. He says peers rely on lobbyists and works with Action on World Health (co-founded by Nigel Farage), Free Speech Union and Big Brother Watch; he met an industry representative at the July British Grand Prix. BAT denies awareness and says a generational ban would fuel illicit trade. AWH denies bill talks. The Lords code requires declaring relevant interests.

articles.title: The world dropped the ball on critical minerals and China pounced. Is it too late for Australia and the US to close the gap?
articles.trailText: In the wake of Covid, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and China’s assertion in global markets, western countries have realised they can’t afford such concentrated supply chains
articles.summary: Australia and the US unveiled a $13bn pact to seed domestic rare-earths and critical minerals, aiming to break China's chokehold (roughly 70% mining, 90% processing). Triggered by supply shocks and tariffs, China's June export halt even paused Ford's Chicago line; magnet exports are now restricted. Canberra will back Alcoa's WA gallium project (from 2026; China supplies 98%) and invest $100m in Arafura's Nolans NdPr project (135km north of Alice Springs), already with $1.2bn support, targeting 4% of global NdPr by 2032. ASX rare-earth stocks have tripled. Experts warn catch-up needs guaranteed buyers, price floors, and full-chain refining despite pollution; 80% foreign ownership heightens returns scrutiny.

articles.title: ‘If you use chocolate, you’re in crisis’: the surprise ingredients being used to beat costs
articles.trailText: As costs and demand for chocolate rises – but cocoa yields fall – companies are innovating with surprising alternatives
