articles.summary: Scotland’s Hagshaw Hill repowering replaced 30-year-old, 55m blades with 14 larger turbines generating 5x power, spotlighting blade waste. Non-recyclable glass/carbon-fibre blades are being processed by Belfast’s Plaswire into hybrid polymer for precast concrete/virgin-plastic substitution. WindEurope sees 14,000 turbines decommissioned by 2030, yielding 40k–60k tonnes of blades (Germany 23.3k, Spain 16k, Italy 2.3k). US waste could reach 200k–370k t/yr by 2050. Solutions: Iberdrola’s Iberian plant (10k t/yr) recovering fibres/resins; repurposing blades as shelters (e.g., Dundee EV bays); Ørsted interim storage. ORE Catapult/RWE tests suggest extending blade life by ~50%. 500 UK offshore turbines near end-of-life within five years. Correction: Hagshaw blades moved to NI in spring.

articles.title: Boomers think their wealth came from wise choices – this myth needs busting | Phillip Inman
articles.trailText: If Reeves swipes some of the huge gains amassed from property and pensions, the lucky generation cannot argue – but will
articles.summary: Phillip Inman argues UK baby boomers’ wealth stems less from prudence than structural transfers. Pensions aren’t “pots”: returns depend on today’s workers, dividend extraction over R&D, and, via gilts, retirees charging governments. Tax relief exceeds £50bn annually; higher-rate savers enjoyed 40% top-ups. Property gains mostly reflect state-funded amenities, transport, schools, policing raising land values. With ultrarich hard to tax, Rachel Reeves may target middle-income boomers’ property and pension windfalls in November’s budget, prompting backlash from a cohort already least likely to back Labour. Inman cites a 2009 German hostage case as a warning against entitlement.

articles.title: ‘Dagenham is worried’: London borough in limbo after Smithfield and Billingsgate move axed
articles.trailText: Halting of dock redevelopment is big blow to area already hit by uncertainty over Ford site’s future
articles.summary: Dagenham faces limbo after the City of London Corporation scrapped a £741m plan to relocate Smithfield and Billingsgate to a 17-hectare Dagenham Dock site, despite about £230m already spent. The halt erased a promised 2,700 jobs and a ‘food school’, in a borough of 220,000 ranked fifth-worst for deprivation. The Corporation, which collects £1.3bn in business rates, formed a regeneration team and says the site could host other uses, but offers no timeline. Wider uncertainty looms: Ford’s 450-acre plant still builds about 1m diesel engines as the technology winds down; Beam Park rail station was shelved; Thames Freeport is drafting a masterplan. One bright spot: Eastbrook Studios opened, touting up to 5,000 jobs.

articles.title: Inside the Jaguar Land Rover hack: stalled smart factories, outsourced cybersecurity and supply chain woes
articles.trailText: Being a carmaker where ‘everything is connected’ has left JLR unable to isolate its plants or functions, forcing a shutdown of most systems
articles.summary: Late-Aug cyberattack forced JLR to shut interconnected IT, halting production in the UK, Slovakia, Brazil and India. Three weeks on, plants idle; losses likely hundreds of millions; West Midlands suppliers in distress. DBT and NCSC engaged; minister Chris Bryant briefed; government weighing supplier support (furlough unlikely). TCS, under a £800m/5‑year outsourcing deal, runs JLR IT/cyber and SAP upgrades; connectivity prevented isolating sites. Speculation points to Scattered Spider/Lapsus$/ShinyHunters; JLR won’t confirm ransomware. JLR has ~£6bn cash; CreditSights sees £900m Sept burn, £1.7bn working‑cap swing; options include debt, banks, UKEF. Staff sent home; CAD/PLM down; payments/spares continue. Over 1,000 cars mid‑build complicate restart; recovery weeks, maybe months; EV launches may slip.

articles.title: Optus confirms fourth death after CEO reveals warnings of failed triple zero calls not escalated
articles.trailText: Emergency calls were offline for nearly 14 hours, during which four people died – including an eight-week-old baby
articles.summary: Optus CEO Stephen Rue confirmed a fourth death linked to Thursday's outage, with triple zero unavailable for nearly 14 hours - far longer than first disclosed. Two customer warnings that emergency calls were failing were not escalated. The disruption occurred during a planned upgrade (began 12:30am; halted 1:50pm after SA Police alert). Up to 600 attempted triple zero calls failed. Victims include an eight-week-old boy (Gawler), a 68-year-old woman (Queenstown) in SA, a 74-year-old WA man, and another WA fatality under investigation. ACMA will investigate. Opposition flagged camp-on diversion failures; leaders slammed Optus' communications. Optus will appoint an independent reviewer and create formal notification protocols. The telco was fined $12m after a 2023 outage; Rue became CEO in 2024.

articles.title: ‘Incompetent’: SA premier slams Optus as eight-week-old baby among three who died when triple zero calls failed
articles.trailText: Peter Malinauskas criticised the telco for its communications after two people in South Australia and one in Western Australia died during the network upgrade
articles.summary: Optus CEO Stephen Rue confirmed a network upgrade blocked triple-zero (000) calls, affecting ~600 households in SA, WA and NT, with three deaths: an eight-week-old boy in Gawler, a 68-year-old woman in Queenstown (Adelaide), and one person in WA. SA premier Peter Malinauskas called Optus incompetent and reprehensible, alleging the state learned details only during a press conference; Optus denies. The outage began after midnight Thursday and lasted at least 10 hours into Friday. Rue apologised, said normal calls worked but 000 failed, and is probing why calls weren’t handed to another network. Regulators are involved; fines could exceed $10m. The failure echoes a Nov 2023 000 outage that drew a $12m ACMA penalty. Welfare checks continue.

articles.title: Value of Australia’s coal and gas exports will plunge 50% in five years, treasury modelling forecasts
articles.trailText: Figure amounts to a $60bn fall by 2030 under any future scenario of emissions reduction in Australia, modelling predicts
articles.summary: Treasury modelling, released with Australia’s 2035 target, projects coal and LNG export values fall from ~A$130bn in 2025 to under A$70bn by 2030 (a drop of 60bn+ across all scenarios), and to under A$30bn by 2050. Gas output declines 24–27% by 2035 (66–68% by 2050); coal 42–51% by 2035 (71–74% by 2050). Scenarios: baseline, renewable-exports (green hydrogen etc), and disorderly. Exports of green commodities rise from ~A$30bn today to at least A$80bn by 2035 and A$109–178bn by 2050. CCA/CSIRO: fossil outputs -30% by 2035 under 1.5C (-13% under 2C). Industry cites strong regional LNG demand; IEA sees SE Asia LNG imports up eightfold by 2050.

articles.title: Overbaked prices? What a Greggs sausage roll and Pret meal deal say about how much Britons will pay
articles.trailText: Food inflation pushes consumers to the limits of what they are willing to spend, costing retailers sales
articles.summary: UK on-the-go food prices are testing demand. Greggs’ sausage roll rose from 66p (2012) to £1.30 (2025) as takeaway prices climbed 33% since 2020. With inflation at 3.8% and food inflation set to top 5% this autumn, shoppers are balking; Greggs’ share price has halved on slower growth. Firms blame a £25bn rise in employer NICs, but pricing power is fading. Pret launched meal deals after owner JAB cut its valuation by a third; it faced backlash to £12.95 salads while defending £5.50 baguettes and £3.95 flat whites, and trimming some prices. The poorest fifth cut food spend 5% in real terms; wage gains are fading, confidence falling, and spending is shifting to experiences; hot weather, health trends hurt sales.

articles.title: UK borrowing hits five-year high for August at £18bn
articles.trailText: Worsening public finances mean Rachel Reeves will almost certainly announce tax rises in November budget
articles.summary: UK public sector net borrowing hit £18bn in August, a five-year high, exceeding City (£12.75bn) and OBR (£12.5bn) forecasts ahead of the 26 Nov budget. YTD borrowing rose to £83.8bn (highest since 2020), £16bn above 2024 and over the OBR’s £72.4bn. Sterling slipped to ~$1.35; gilt yields climbed to 27-year highs. OBR blamed local-authority revisions and weak VAT; sees H2 relief from CGT and lower interest. NI receipts rose after a £25bn employer-rate hike, but spending and £8.4bn debt interest offset. Economists flag tax rises; Capital Economics pegs gap at £28bn. BoE held 4% and cut QT to £70bn.

articles.title: Retail sales rise in Great Britain as warm weather boosts clothing purchases
articles.trailText: Increase of 0.5% in August helped by back-to-school shopping, while food stores also given lift
articles.summary: UK retail sales rose 0.5% month on month in August, beating 0.4% forecasts, as heatwaves, the August bank holiday, and back-to-school demand lifted spending, ONS said. July growth was revised to 0.5%. Clothing sales rose 1.3%; non-food stores gained 1.1%; food stores rose 0.5% as specialists rebounded; non-store (online) also increased. Despite August’s uptick, sales fell 0.1% over the three months to August versus the prior quarter, driven by weakness in non-food (antiques, auction houses, tech) and lower fuel sales. Retailers fear a 26 Nov budget with possible tax rises could hit Christmas; BRC says food and drink spend reflects higher prices, not volumes.

articles.title: Nvidia to invest $5bn in Intel after Trump administration’s 10% stake
articles.trailText: Deal gives Intel a lifeline as firms team up on AI datacenters and PC chips after Trump stake sparks market surge
articles.summary: Nvidia will invest $5bn in Intel, buying stock at $23.28 pending approvals, and partner on AI datacenter and PC chips. A month after the US government took a 10% Intel stake, the pact has Intel building custom chips for Nvidia’s AI platforms and PC processors integrating Nvidia tech, with architectures “seamlessly connected.” Intel shares jumped ~23% after-hours; Nvidia rose >3%, near a $4tn value. Intel lost ~$19bn last year and $3.7bn in H1 2025, and plans 25% layoffs by end‑2025. SoftBank recently put $2bn into Intel for 2%. Trump has threatened 100% chip tariffs and cut deals permitting limited AI chip sales to China for a 15% take. Wedbush sees $3–4tn AI infra spend by 2030.

articles.title: What is quantitative tightening and how has it affected UK finances?
articles.trailText: The Bank of England’s disposal of the bonds it bought after the 2008 financial crisis is being slowed down
articles.summary: The Bank of England will slow quantitative tightening, trimming planned bond disposals from £100bn to £70bn over the next year. With fewer maturities, active sales will rise to £21bn (vs £13bn last year). Since 2022 the BoE has cut its QE stock from £895bn to £558bn, disposing of £100bn in the past year. QT adds upward pressure on gilt yields as increased supply lowers prices, contributing alongside global factors to 27-year-high UK borrowing costs. Fiscal impacts: higher debt-interest, realised losses from selling below purchase price, and cash losses on the remaining portfolio as reserve remuneration exceeds asset income. The OBR sees £108bn losses over five years, offsetting £124bn prior profits.

articles.title: Bank’s interest rate vote and bond plans are little help to Reeves before budget
articles.trailText: Holding borrowing rates and continuing bond sell-offs were widely expected but an alternative was available
articles.summary: Bank of England kept Bank Rate at 4% with inflation at 3.8%, despite two MPC externals, Swati Dhingra and Alan Taylor, voting for a 25bp cut to 3.75% on growth concerns. It trimmed quantitative tightening to a £70bn gilt runoff (from £100bn), but thinner maturities mean active sales rise from ~£13bn to ~£21bn. With gilt yields at 27-year highs, some urged halting sales, which IPPR says could save the Treasury >£10bn a year—helping Rachel Reeves before a tough autumn budget after a £25bn employer NICs hike. Next MPC is 6 Nov; markets see little chance of relief.

articles.title: Novo Nordisk shares climb after positive results for anti-obesity pill
articles.trailText: Danish drugmaker jumps by about £9bn as trial shows ‘significant weight loss’ with tablet version of Wegovy
articles.summary: Novo Nordisk shares rose >6% (~£9bn) after phase 3 data showed its once‑daily oral Wegovy (semaglutide with absorption enhancer) achieved 16.6% mean weight loss over 64 weeks in 307 adults; ~1/3 lost ≥20%; side‑effects resembled the jab. It’s the first oral GLP‑1 filed with the FDA; decision due year‑end; US production has begun. The rebound follows a ~60% share slide, profit warnings and plans for 9,000 layoffs under new CEO Mike Doustdar. Rival Eli Lilly’s orforglipron (n=3,127) delivered 12.4% mean loss, 20%+ in 1/5, no fasting; analysts see $10–25bn peak vs Novo’s ~$5bn. Pills may be cheaper, widening access despite UK price hikes/NHS limits.

articles.title: UK faces years of anaemic growth amid tax and regulation burden, says Next
articles.trailText: Retailer says economic outlook clouded by fall in job opportunities and government overspending
articles.summary: Next warned the UK faces years of anaemic growth, blaming four drags: declining job opportunities, competitiveness-eroding regulation, unaffordable government spending and a rising tax burden. Shares fell up to 6% despite robust H1 to July: statutory pre-tax profit +18% to £509m on sales +10.3% to £3.3bn, and a £99m dividend (87p/share). The FTSE 100 retailer, which distributes Gap and Victoria’s Secret, benefited from warm weather and M&S cyber-attack disruption; vacancies are down 35% in two years while applications are up 76%. CEO Lord Simon Wolfson said AI will cut entry-level roles and criticised the Employment Rights Bill, warning it could curb flexible hours. Peel Hunt remained positive.

articles.title: Bank of England holds interest rates at 4% and slows scheme to sell stock of UK bonds
articles.trailText: Decision on government debt holdings could reduce market jitters and Treasury’s borrowing costs
articles.summary: The Bank of England kept Bank Rate at 4% (7-2 vote) and slowed quantitative tightening, cutting its annual gilt run-off target to £70bn from £100bn amid volatile yields and market-functioning risks. With fewer maturities, active gilt sales will rise to about £21bn (from £13bn), skewed toward shorter-dated paper. Inflation was 3.8% in August (vs 2% target); unemployment is at a four-year high; MPC estimates zero jobs growth, partly from last year’s £25bn NICs hike. Swati Dhingra and Alan Taylor backed a 25bp cut. Policy diverges from the Fed’s 25bp cut. QT losses lift Treasury borrowing costs; Rachel Reeves urged DMO coordination; OBR flags fiscal-rule risks before 26 Nov; DB pension decline weakens long-dated demand.

articles.title: The Federal Reserve’s independence is about to be tested like never before
articles.trailText: Donald Trump wants drastic rate cuts – and his campaign to exert greater political control over the Fed continues
articles.summary: Donald Trump is intensifying efforts to influence the Federal Reserve, pushing deep rate cuts and moves to reshape its leadership. Stephen Miran—who argued last year to ban the White House–Fed “revolving door”—joined the Fed board while on unpaid leave as Trump’s CEA chair and immediately dissented for a 50bp cut. The Fed delivered 25bp to 4–4.25% and signaled more, citing upside inflation risks after August reacceleration and tariff uncertainty. Trump seeks to oust Governor Lisa Cook and will be able to pick Jerome Powell’s successor next year. Powell insists policy is data-driven and independence intact.

articles.title: Tax rises in, two-child limit out: what Resolution Foundation’s boss is urging Reeves before budget
articles.trailText: Pensions triple lock should also go, says Ruth Curtice, a former civil servant who says it’s ‘nice to be allowed to say what you think’
articles.summary: Ruth Curtice, ex-Treasury fiscal chief now leading the Resolution Foundation, urges chancellor Rachel Reeves to boost fiscal credibility in November’s budget by widening the £9.9bn headroom—even if that means breaking Labour’s tax pledges and considering broad-based tax rises. She rejects a new wealth tax, backing capital gains tax alignment with income tax and better inheritance tax. Curtice calls to scrap the pensions triple lock for earnings uprating, and to lift the two-child benefits cap (£3.5bn/year) to curb surging child poverty—projected to hit records, with half of large-family children in poverty. She warns of broad living-standards stagnation (pensioners +21% vs non‑pensioners +7%).

articles.title: Are the stars finally aligning for the ‘new golden age’ of nuclear? | Nils Pratley
articles.trailText: Let’s not be too cynical about the US-UK agreement to build new power plants – but costs must fall if nuclear is to make headway
articles.summary: A US‑UK pact to mutually recognise nuclear safety regimes could cut licensing to two years (from 3–4), tackling nuclear’s biggest delay. Centrica signed a development deal with US‑based X‑energy to build up to 12 80MW advanced modular reactors in Hartlepool by the mid‑2030s—the UK’s first AMR push—alongside three 470MW Rolls‑Royce SMRs and a privately funded off‑grid “micro” plant at London Gateway port. Yet economics loom: no SMR has been built; mega‑plants remain costly. Sizewell C, a Hinkley C replica, is priced at £38bn, with customers paying before completion; Cornwall Insight says non‑exempt large users face £200k+ a year. Britain Remade notes France/Finland deliver similar designs at about half the price; South Korea at ~one‑sixth. A taskforce blames outdated regulation and risk aversion. Costs still dominate, but 2025 may prove pivotal.
